movie_review_blurb: "Captain Phillips" will grab and hold your attention from its first few minutes to its startling conclusion.
"John Carter" may not be a perfect movie, but it's one where you can safely plunk down your money, grab your box of popcorn and come away reasonably satisfied when the closing credits roll.

The game is now afoot with Holmes' arch-nemesis, Professor James Moriarity -- and that makes a notable difference. This time, Holmes is up against an equal, and it's elementary indeed that muscle and firepower alone won't carry the day.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The film is loaded with everything Muppets fans love: loopy musical production numbers, very funny montages, some hilarious asides and weird little moments.
For all its virtues -- or, perhaps, because of them -- J. Edgar is a disappointment.
If you are looking for something more intellectual, and certainly more accurate in its portrayal of a rich period in English history, you will have to go elsewhere.
This is intelligent filmmaking, and a provocative moral fable. It may not be perfect, but it stands as one of the better, most realistic movies about the way we elect our leaders.
There is enough to like and to savor in Cowboys & Aliens that it makes for an enjoyable two hours in the dark with a big bag of buttery popcorn.

Tears are shed for the lost, cheers are raised for the (often unexpectedly) brave and noble, and, in the movie's final moments, there is a sense of satisfaction and fulfillment rarely achieved in filmmaking.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: [Pixar]t has set such a high bar with what it has done with animation and storytelling over its 25 years that when it falls short -- and it does fall short with Cars 2 -- the disappointment can make a perfectly good, entertaining movie seem like a letdown.
What's truly perplexing about the failures of How Do You Know is that the film was written and directed by James L. Brooks, a master of the rom-com genre.
Much of the heavy lifting falls to Watson, and, in such moments as the one where she must wipe out her family's memories of her to protect them, she is more than up to the task.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: You will know The Social Network is something very special from its first scene.
For most of its hour and 53 minutes, it's a dazzling and thoroughly engaging ride through a fantasy world born of Wright's (and O'Malley's) vivid imaginations.
Hayward and Gilman are newcomers who are asked to carry much of the film and pull it off with lovely understatement and extraordinary believability.
In a summer that will be littered with bad sequels, bad 3-D and bad storytelling, it is a movie to be heartily embraced.

It may be, as Fowley says near the end of the film, that the Runaways "were a conceptual rock project that failed." But as a film about a certain time and place in rock history, The Runaways largely succeeds.
I started glancing at the time well before the midway mark.

Perhaps the best way to approach it -- at least for those who are not total Jackson fans -- is to view it as an often-fascinating document on how the sausage (or magic, if you will) is made for a mega-concert tour.
The characters are all representative of the period but they come off as one-dimensional, more symbols than individuals.
Sometimes a meal can be less than perfect but still so thoroughly enjoyable that a missed ingredient here or a bit of overcooking there doesn't really matter.
Half-Blood Prince shows the Potter film franchise and Rowling's story are in very good hands indeed.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Do the flaws diminish Levees? To a degree. But the story Lee tells is so powerful, so important, that the lapses aren't a reason not to pay heed to what this passionate film has to say.
movie_title: When the Levees Broke: A Requiem in Four Acts (2006)

movie_review_blurb: If you're willing to loosen your grip on reality, it is a grand journey to a place where Gothic is cross-wired with modern sensibilities.
A fascinating film from a director of great skill and even greater promise.
Although it shares some basic plot points with Sixth Sense, it is more of a traditional thriller and plows some very different emotional areas.
A mountain of bad writing, a confusing plot, atrocious jokes and surprisingly bad special effects.
So breathtakingly bad, so unintentionally funny that it could take on the status of a camp classic.
An intense, haunting, often beautifully crafted character study and meditation on the nature of death and life after death.
There is no happy ending for the Shrek franchise.
A good, often entertaining work that kids will love.
Not just matches, but actually surpasses a delightful original.
In filmmaking, as in Hushpuppy's world, everything must fit together just right. And in "Beasts of the Southern Wild," everything does.
This is a powerful, engrossing film that transcends the normal constraints of its genre and is worth your investment of both time and attention.
There is no depth to the piece and, while it might be asking too much of any film to show the "real" Jobs, it barely hints at the complexity of his ambitions and emotions.
For all its flaws, Elysium is an often-absorbing and largely entertaining film from a young director with a great future. That makes it worth seeing -- if not a complete success.

Allen's best movie in some years and certainly his finest drama with comedy since 2005's "Match Point," it is a tale of wealth, greed and corruption -- and the shock waves that occur when crimes lead to punishment.

Working with cinematographer John R. Leonetti and editor Kirk Morri, Wan carefully crafts each setpiece so that each visual punch has maximum impact to a nerve-shredding musical soundtrack from composer Joseph Bihara.
In the end, The Lone Ranger is one hot mess -- an entertaining one, to be sure, but still a mess.
"Monsters University" is fine family entertainment with something for the adults and a lot for the kids.
The result is a film that, while relentlessly grim and badly in need of humor, manages to be a smart, nuanced take on the Superman mythology.
Somehow much -- if certainly not all -- of the film works. Levy largely avoids the cynical and the crude, which is refreshing. Some bits are legitimately funny.
If you're expecting another "Midnight in Paris" -- and you may well in the first moments of the new film -- you will be disappointed.
Phillips has lost all of the sharp humor, keen sense of debauchery and still plain fun that marked the original.
Abrams gets considerable help from a cast who go after their roles with great zest.
It's decent popcorn entertainment -- just fine for the summertime, but nothing more than that.
If you want a sense of a true all-American hero, this film is a fine place to start.
Bits of the plot, including the environmental science of the new Earth, make no sense. The dialogue is leaden. And the special effects are surprisingly unconvincing ...
There's no question that you will laugh at times throughout "Burt Wonderstone." But if you are looking for something truly magical, you will come away disappointed.
As a cop tells a younger partner when Batman first reappears, "Boy, you're in for a show tonight, son." And, indeed, it's been quite a show.
It's going for the truth in people's lives and, for the most part, it finds it.
"The Sapphires" is a bit like a puppy you're trying to house break. It may have its bad cinematic moments but it's just so darn appealing that you have to love it.
"Trouble with the Curve" may not be the Game 6 of the 1975 World Series, but it's a fine afternoon or evening at the ballpark.
"Cloud Atlas" is a film where the creators' admirable reach exceeds their grasp. You may be getting six films for the cost of one, but it may not really be worth the price.
It's a fine piece of moviemaking that has a little something for kids who don't remember when games were played in arcades and adults who will delight in the tweaking of a bygone era.
It is a likable, warm film that brings a welcome reassurance: Even if you fail spectacularly as a comedian or as a human being, it really can turn out OK in the end.
One of the finest historical dramas ever committed to film. It's a triumph for Spielberg, Kushner and, most of all, Day-Lewis.
Remaking an old film is rarely a good idea, but sometimes the idea is so spectacularly bad that the reasoning behind it defies all comprehension.

Hitchcock once famously said that a good filmmaker should always "always make the audience suffer as much as possible." I don't think he meant the kind of suffering "Hitchcock" inflicts on its audience.
In a bit of irony, Bilbo Baggins says at the end of the movie: "I do believe the worst is behind us." We can only hope so.
A wrenching film that is sure to bring tears -- a lot of tears -- to your eyes and manages, in many ways, to affirm that love is worth sharing and life is worth living even in the most final of days.

This is a brilliant reboot of the canon, mixing a sense of melancholy, the shock of changing times and the darkness of loss with thrillingly staged chase and fight scenes and clever references to all that has come before.
Yet, the film does a remarkably good job of capturing an artist's process, while making a satisfying connection between Letscher's not always easy life and his art.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Lance Letscher (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Every single moment of the story rings true, aided by uniformly excellent performances by the unknown cast, particularly Katherine Ceilo as the aimless young protagonist.

It offers the action of a balls-out sci-fi while grabbing the audience by its character development and has cinematography so beautiful it will make you feel grand to be alive. These Final Hours is a gorgeous call to humanity.
The Will Cannon-directed movie is a whodunit come haunted house caper come satanic stormer and despite these being familiar themes, the actors and editing ensure that it's a scream.
With their tale of petrified friends, governmental gods and roaming murder, Jeruzalem is a terrific and terrible vision of what, for all we know, may well be.
Thoughtful and oddly poignant.
Fury of the Demon works wonderfully because it presents a little known aspect of the life of a man who changed the world to an audience it expects to be intelligent.
movie_title: Fury of the Demon (La Rage du Démon) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Hostage to the Devil fascinates with its focus on a renegade, dinner-party darling exorcist and the social factors that made him a star.

What it lacks in some seasoned performers it makes up for in pure, putrefied pizzazz. Yet, for all its 'ard man posturing, it is an equal opportunities stalkathon and is all the more intriguing for it.
[My Bloody Banjo] has genuinely hugely enjoyable segments.

The Killing of America manages to be harrowing today as its stark warnings have gone unheeded. The killers it showcases have gone on to become pop culture and the editing of them alongside scenes of violence truly cuts to the quick.

It teeters on the edge of camp pretension before whipping out its raison d'etre and being unapologetically political. That said, the sheer amount of bodily fluids displayed before it forecloses means it slightly outstays its welcome.

Parallels with everything from Shaun of the Dead to What We Do In the Shadows go down a treat. There's even a nice little bit of social class dialogue bubbling under the surface that results in a final and very wry political money shot.
The lustre of Lowlife is that it doesn't pull its punches but finds beauty and a curious humanity in the chaos of the crime-ridden city.
The Terror of Hallow's Eve mixes old-fashioned movie magic with psychologically more daring horror. That said, more monsters don't make things merrier but if the psychology exists, they're real.
Better Watch Out plays the audience at their own game. It pleasures and punishes them for trying to pre-guess its gifts. It is deeply unnerving and adorably sinister.
IT is horror with heart and high jinks. If taking on a killer clown and all IT's compadres leads to the adventure the Losers have, you'll float, too.
Cannibal Fog is a finely mixed, jangling masterpiece of humanity masquerading as merry mayhem.
Cult of Chucky takes the franchise to its (psycho!)logical conclusion. There is daffy, orange Easter eggs aplenty and enough blood to entertain the (as yet) uninitiated.
Gracia succeeds brilliantly in delivering a chilling warning about where Putin and his spooks might go next, by giving Fedor full licence to act the biblical prophet.
The passion and idealism oozes off the screen, even if it's ultimately a rather sad story.
A brave and engrossing look at the 2015 football tournament from the perspective of the stadium construction workers.
Is it a crime documentary? A satire of prurient crime documentaries? A drama? A piece of avant garde theatre? Casting JonBenét is all of these, and a brilliant original in multiple dimensions.
Last Men in Aleppo is one of the most difficult documentaries you'll see this year.
For those who haven't noticed their freedom of speech ebbing away, this film is certainly an important warning, but they should probably watch some more news videos and read some more papers.
movie_title: Nobody Speak: Trials of the Free Press (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Heineman may have made the definitive contemporary documentary about the tragedy of Syria, as well as an epoch-defining piece on modern media tactics.

This narrative is at its best when we hear direct from Williams, in intimate interview recordings in which he reflects back on life with seriousness that might surprise fans who knew him only as a manic clown.
movie_title: Robin Williams: Come Inside My Mind (2018)

movie_review_blurb: An irrational documentary for irrational times.
The film comes from a place of deep admiration for MIA, but unlike more fawning biographies, it makes a convincing case that this admiration is well earned.

But this is so much more than a film about a film, it's about young women breaking the rules set in a conservative country - the process of doing that was a lot more powerful than finishing the actual film.
The documentary won't bring William Ford back, and it may give Yance Ford some catharsis, but more importantly it could and should lead to greater justice and empowerment.

"If you're willing to be puzzled, you're able to learn," Chomsky says...To his credit (and without affectation), Gondry doesn't cloak the fact that he is often perplexed by his subject. Because of his confusion though, we are able to learn quite a lot.
movie_title: Is the Man Who Is Tall Happy?: An Animated Conversation with Noam Chomsky (2013)

movie_review_blurb: "Jersey Boys" is wall-to-wall fantasyland showbiz, expertly shot and boasting fine performances, but it is in the spirit world between stage and screen where it loses its footing.

Dave Boyle's "Man From Reno" is the type of film where alleyways are home offices, every bar matchbox has an unknown number inside, and if a character enters a bookshop, you better believe old issues of "True Detective" are hanging visibly in frame.
"Cut Bank" fades into the background while its veteran actors look for ways to keep interested.
However muddled the line between reality and fiction stands in any documentary, an extra pause for skepticism occurs when the filmmaker steps in front of the camera.

...in mounting his feature directorial debut, Transcendence, Pfister has chosen to tackle familiarity head on, carving out a new arena for himself while rigging the grounds with pitfalls at every step.
It is...a grounded journey outwards on ideas of regret, mercy, and revenge, and at 139 minutes the film makes every attempt, coherent or not, to thoroughly address each one.

The film is a laser-focused fable threatened occasionally by its drifts into character shorthand, but equaled by a wrenching lead performance by Rachel Mwanza that results in one of the finest of the year.
"One of the most frustratingly accomplished disappointments this year."

There are themes of familial connection and responsibility drenched across every frame of it, but aside from a few performances and amusing asides, Delivery Man is a bland translation of a sweet, but already flawed original.
Mark Webber's "The End of Love" connects and lingers by making incredible effort seem natural.

Loyalty and consequence collide in the "Crazy Heart" director's sophomore feature...but while those themes eventually result in payoffs that are noticeably muted and confused, the film is luckily powered by a powerful trio of performances at its core...

A wonderful document of inner-city oppression and two young actors' beginning steps, The Inevitable Defeat of Mister and Pete struggles to establish a cohesive center, and ultimately fumbles any tension on the path toward its title's possible fate.
movie_title: The Inevitable Defeat of Mister & Pete (2013)

movie_review_blurb: It takes a lot of effort to take the underdog stomping grounds of New York's top punk acts and turn them into the Central Perk from Friends-albeit with slightly more stain-but CBGB does it with total conviction.

Wilson's new role is that of stock Lifetime-movie aggressor, veering between tortured monologues and ham-fisted apologies to the hysterical Byrne, who stumbles through the film like a Mr. Magoo caught in cobwebs.

...Macdonald's signature intensity, combined with another sneak attack performance from Saoirse Ronan, assembles a thrilling genre entry that stands firmly alongside its contemporaries in terms of quality.
Goyer and Nolan have crafted in Man of Steel a taut, exploratory vision...Together, they've humanized an icon...although they've undervalued the integral supporting roles in much of the same manner.
Upside Down is a film built on binary elements -- lavishly and ambitiously executed -- yet with its laughably undercooked romantic core, it remains foolishly stubborn towards anything more nuanced.
"The Condemned" is nothing but a creaky façade.

What Coscarelli's achieved doesn't feel like an adaptation. It feels more like he seems he skimmed the source material, burned it, and then assembled a vague recollection on film after three days of untold indulgences.
"The Gambler" is a flawed, well-shot throwback that feels swayed by studio interference, full of performances serving a script that limits their efforts to one-liners.
A deeply intense, detached museum piece -- hosting a small, intriguing plaque that might lead you to the denser story elsewhere, if you so wish.
Four or five stunning sequences in "American Sniper," including an intense firefight finale set during a sand storm, prove Eastwood still has his own capable handle on cinema.
"As a mainstream sci-fi film, this enjoyable, occasionally poignant effort too often feels messy in the wrong ways."
"Trainwreck" allows a new development and angle to Apatow's trademark anxieties through a unique point of view, and is one of his most hilarious and finely-tuned films to date.

With an enjoyable atmosphere, solid performances from Hawke, Travolta, Farmiga, and one gifted canine, In A Valley of Violence ends up a solid entry in a genre gradually fading from mainstream cinema.
Don't Breathe indeed reaches a unique destination in horror filmmaking. Unfortunately it fails to deliver a worthy emotional hook to pin its savagery onto.
A confounding misfire.
An entertaining, thoughtful portrait of friends in crisis when success is near.
...a patchy mix between kidnapping crime comedy and glorified cat video.
The strength of Linklater's films have always been their ability to capture the textures of lived experience, and "Everyone Wants Some!!" is no different in that regard.

The end result may read as a gussied-up Funny or Die conceit at times, but through a surprising dramatic focus and well-written script it still performs wonderfully as an absurdist crime comedy with a wicked streak.
"Selma" is vital correspondence, filmmaking lived on the streets where brutal facts were ignored then reported, and now snatched back from history to sustain a spirit few films can or will possess.
There are shades of activism, real heart, and an inspiring tone, delivered entertainingly with a group of expertly chosen subjects.
The Trust is many [...] things - darkly funny, flawed, with an eminently watchable dynamic between Cage and Wood - but from frame one it reasonably entertains.

The film's brief 83-minute running time only compounds Krishna as a sharp breath with no exhale; shot and paced like a thriller, the film is a dreamlike view into a woman's inner life that ensures a tragic end.
A lack of pace and illuminating insight are what keep "Concussion" from lasting resonance, its flaws threatening to dull the issue for drama in a way that the NFL could only appreciate.
Intimate, singular, and hallucinatory on all aesthetic levels, the film strips politics down to the bone, not always successful but never opportunistic.
There's a charmer in here that's a fake-out of the most welcome kind.
It's a fascinating angle on a multi-faceted individual.

There is enough in 6 Years from Farmiga and Rosenfield's performances to warrant a watch, and Fidell's ideas and subtle developments around such a challenging story are heartfelt and mostly well-rendered.

A touching expression of loss, worth repeat viewings for its poetic visuals alone.
This is a film that challenges us to accept a flawed protagonist. His faults do not negate his charitable work, but it is up to us to decide whether they make him less of a hero.
Hilarious, charming, and slightly traumatic.
Entertaining but underwhelming.
Tramps won't stay in your mind for days after, but it's a genuine delight.
I can understand this coming across as dull, but Ocean Waves' embrace of the everyday is really its strength.
Fan of [Park's] will no doubt be sucked in by the distinct style, cinematography, and lush colors.
It's a gorgeous treat.
movie_title: Long Way North (Tout en haut du monde) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Pushing aside the earlier predatory male character in favor of a "women eat each other alive, but literally" story makes it fall short for me.

With so much going on, this is a coming-of-age that doesn't really slow down.
movie_title: My Entire High School Sinking Into the Sea (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There are a lot of genuinely devastating moments in the film.

As we continue to see animation progress and become more and more realistic, the French animated film The Girl Without Hands or La Jeune Fille sans mains is a reminder that the medium can be just as compelling with simple and evocative strokes

movie_review_blurb: It will be a welcome relief to see Pattinson one day cast in a film not primarily targeted at women, or, indeed, one where he is forlorn and lovesick most of the time.
Surprisingly engaging. Biased, but by no means a bad film.

Against all the odds, Blade Runner 2049 is a majestic, uncompromising science-fiction epic that stands shoulder to shoulder with its predecessor as a film of wondrous images and thought-provoking reflections on what it means to be human.
The D Train certainly takes you on a fun ride.
Do we really need a "gritty" British version of The Sixth Sense?

The city looks good enough to dive into. If only the humans in the frame weren't so shallow.

So confusing (especially if you're a football dolt) that you may have trouble identifying the different narrative strands. It's still gripping.
When the mood takes him, he's still on song.
Whether in the fights or the love scenes, we don't know where to invest our emotional energy.
Lowery falls back on a number of clichés in his indie romance-cum-Western, drowning the actors in melancholy sunshine and letting them mumble like mad. What he gets right are the characters.
A gritty, if ultimately underwhelming, drama from Iceland, based on real events that took place in 1984.

The performances are excellent. The script is a dud.

Pablo Berger's brainchild is truly enchanting.

Maggie Carey's feature film debut is full of lazy shots, duff lines and dodgy acting. But it also contains fresh ideas and hilarious gags.
Hopkins has been filming this group for five years and is eager to help. As boundaries blur, you wonder if she's now part of the madness.

movie_review_blurb: Solidly crafted. Totally pointless.
Those who've read Escape from Camp 14 will know all about Shin Dong-huyk. Everyone else will be left slack-jawed by his account of prison-camp life in North Korea.
Newcomer Paul Wright's poetic, if not entirely convincing, attempt to make sense of Scottish folklore, family bonds and mental illness.
Aidan Gillen is so good in this Irish thriller it makes your skin tingle.

movie_review_blurb: A cult classic about fading dreams that has curiously improved with age.

If anything, it improves with age.
This may be the first film noir to revolve around a lonely granny.
Self-defeatingly "Tarantino-esque".

On the plus side, the real-life, Veronese back-drops are awesome. And the male cast are as beautiful as the day.

We Steal Secrets is much concerned with conspiracy theories and may well wind up fuelling new ones.
movie_title: We Steal Secrets: The Story Of Wikileaks (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Big wedding? Big fat nothing, more like.
[Kiarostami] almost throws up something magical, here.
Like waves beating on a shore, the guff just keeps on coming.
Wheatley, clearly, is a visionary. He just needs to push himself harder, because this so-called experiment sees him operating very much within his comfort zone.
Implausible climax aside, this fast-paced, fizzy summer blockbuster leaves us with food for thought.
A laboured, mawkish plug for Google.
Documentaries, like thrillers, need charismatic leads. And a twist. This smart British project delivers on both fronts.
An initially promising, increasingly glutinous buddy comedy that exploits and squanders the talents of its starry cast.
They're perfect American drama queens. All that's missing is a last act.
Blithe, beautifully acted and refreshingly free of fancy SFX, This Is The End pokes fun at generic film-making, without ever seeming self-righteous.
It's a tad inconsequential, but Travis Mathews offers a believable slice of San Franciscan life with his graphic debut feature.
A more apt title would be World War Zzzzz...
A slick, grungy espionage thriller so in tune with the times it's almost uncanny.
The colours are so vivid you ache to reach out and touch them). It's also painfully funny and full of surprises.
A witty, inspiring documentary that charts Billie Jean King's drive to put women's tennis on the map.
It's really just an over-blown fashion shoot. Let's hope Jason got to keep the clothes.
Time and again, you're hooked back in by jagged details.
The whole thing is laugh-out-loud dumb.
If the film-makers' aim was to close the gap between viewers and "victims" of motor neurone disease, they have done themselves proud.
The piece as a whole gets bogged down in rites-of-passage cliches and, ultimately, seems out of time.
Snitch wants to be Breaking Bad. When the camera's on Johnson, it's just bad.
The plot is preposterous, offering up not one, but two, saintly females for our hi falutin' delectation.
movie_title: Io sono Li (Shun Li and the Poet) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: There's no need for Pierre Coffin and Chris Renaud's animated sequel to exist, but is there a parent alive strong enough to resist the pull of "The Minions"?
His desire to understand conflict, his gnawing away at the question of what young men get out of violence, sets our own brain whirring.
movie_title: Which Way Is the Front Line from Here? The Life and Times of Tim Hetherington (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Aaron Eckhart plays the thoroughly modern monster, caught up in a battle between good and evil that threatens all mankind. Somehow he finds time for romance.
All three of the film's central characters are challenging. But they're so recognisable (and beautifully performed) that, despite yourself, you can't give up on them.
If you want to understand what's going on in Egypt right now - or simply love raw, in-depth documentaries - seek out Jehane Noujaim's dissection of a revolution.
Steel uses animation, crispy cinematography and interviews with Boyd's protégés and friends to chart the depths of this one-of-a-kind businesswoman.
It would be interesting to know what, if anything, Beth B wasn't allowed to film. Striptease is a game. You wind up hoping that the wounded Wood managed to keep something under wraps.
Both infuriating and haunting, The Missing Picture leaves us desperate for other testimonies. Panh's vision is so tantalisingly incomplete.
Arnaud des Pallières's pompous historical epic is a waste of good scenery.
movie_title: Age of Uprising: The Legend of Michael Kohlhaas (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Children, as well as adults, may find the atmosphere dangerously addictive.
movie_title: Beauty and The Beast (La Belle et la bête) (1946)

movie_review_blurb: The one ray of sunshine: surely anything with the word "Last" in the title is incapable of spawning a sequel?
Markus Imhoof's bee documentary is so stuffed with surreal tableaux it makes your head spin.
Who knew baby laxative had so many uses?
movie_title: How To Make Money Selling Drugs (2013)

movie_review_blurb: This vanity project certainly isn't worth the price of a cinema ticket.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: If you've never seen Jack Clayton's 1961 adaptation of Henry James's Turn of the Screw, hurl yourself into a cinema ASAP.
Honestly, I couldn't stop grinning.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: One of the worst films of the year, by a country mile.
A maniacally muddled and maudlin thriller, co-written and produced by Sly Stallone.
I found it hard to care. Still, the bit where the title gets explained is sweet.
Unfortunately, director Virginia Gilbert doesn't trust us to handle the chill winds and opts for something that has no temperature at all.
A genial but somewhat pretentious attempt to explore Seventies movie tropes and the gossamer fine line between fact and fiction.
An inept, often ludicrous, take on Langston Hughes' 1961 musical-play.
A real one-off.
Alas, the hero is played by Vince Vaughn, a limited actor whose range extends from petulant to homicidal.
For reasons best known to himself, director Jonathan Teplitzky has turned Lomax's grim, modest, devastatingly tender memoir into a tall tale of derring-do.
Cera's chin may be weak, but his strength as an actor cannot be denied.
A bizarre, moving and witty how-dunnit that makes you look twice at the work of Johannes Vermeer.
Whenever Jarmusch lets his soundtrack - and his stars - do the talking, the right notes get struck.
Once Lombard starts throwing stilettos, you know it's time to get off the line.
Because Hiddleston is a genius and the scriptwriters obviously adore him, the ocean-bound scenes are less nightmarishly tedious than non-fans of the genre might expect.
This is by no means a short film, yet somehow none of the characters, or any of their detective work, has time to make an impression.
Though not everything about The Lego Movie is awesome, you'll leave the cinema wearing a real smile.
Sanitised re-make of Zeffirelli's cult dud.
Cuban Fury should be to salsa what Blades of Glory was to ice-skating but Frost insists on playing it straight.

Fiennes has neither disgraced, nor distinguished himself, with this solemn soap. He wants to tell Nelly's story but the real woman - and the man she spent 13 years of her life with - slips through his fingers.

It's actually based on characters from Sixties TV series The Rocky and Bullwinkle Show, yet there's nothing dusty about the first 60 minutes of the script (the ending drags but hey, you can't have everything).
Sex, drugs and rock n roll. It's all here. And, best of all, there are no bloody weddings.
The fifth and final instalment of the Twilight saga has the best climax of any blockbuster this year.
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Efron turns out to be the weak link. He's a fun guy but are audiences ready to commit to him as a dramatic lead? Silence? That's what I thought.
An occasionally smart script - and four excellent actors - keep the project grounded.
Power must never be mistaken for virtue, warns Gibney, and self-regulation doesn't work. Even the best of us need to be kept an eye on.
There's a sweetness to the proceedings that makes you sort of glad it wasn't strangled at birth.
Ambitious but also confusing and often trite ...
A black-and-white hymn to the energy of the dispossessed, made in the late 1990s, but still horribly relevant.
This is a movie about crummy mummies in which everyone looks their age. That will strike many as a downer but I was left wanting more.
Boasts a bellyful of unintentional laughs.
Jan Ole Gerster's debut often feels reminiscent of last year's Frances Ha. But something's missing.
Has moments of magic, but you can't help feeling that an outsider would have fashioned something with more bite.
A misguided, if visually polished, remake of Park Chan-wook's violent revenge thriller.
Foster is wonderful as the watchful, weak Burroughs, at ease only when drugged, with a mouth like a cat's bum. But DeHaan is even better.
The glitz will satisfy militantly feminine sprogs, but is completely at odds with Elsa's gutsy character and Frozen's pioneering message.
His friends and fans - clearly upset by his recent stroke - eulogise him to death.
The couple are thriving, but, given what we learn about Alex, the up-beat ending jars.
It all rings horrifically true.
Short Term 12 wants to shine a light on these under-paid, under-valued figures and cheats, just a little, to get the job done.
The acting and improv, by the whole cast, is sublime ...
Lelio's film isn't like other films...
What's all the fuss about this franchise? Trust me. Once you've met jokey Loki, you'll understand.
Some lines have juice and many performances impress - Öyeniran has potential.
The film isn't full of revelations but it's playful and makes trees look very huggable indeed.
Looks as tasteful as can be but, in terms of emotion, lacks any kind of finesse.
A wee bit special.
This London-set political thriller is a damp squib.
The anecdotes work without the music, but if you like the music... Dang, it's a stairway to heaven.
The film works as the simplest of fairy tales, so scrumptious you'll want to devour it whole.
movie_title: Okami kodomo no ame to yuki (The Wolf Children Ame and Yuki) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: When Knoxville's bad, he's very very bad. But when he's good, he's wicked.
This film runs on cute ... and the result is a trip that goes nowhere at all.
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Game on.
A fable that, by the time the credits roll, will have you in bits.
Stallone spoils the dumb-fun mood. He wears the stoical gaze of someone who knows he's being buried alive.
Kore-eda captures the surreal, delicious mundanity of modern life. Alas, in the second half ... tension fades.
It's ultimately wearing, yet somehow memorable.
Haewon is the kind of thing Eric Rohmer used to churn out in the Eighties and Nineties; a masterpiece so quiet you barely notice it's there.
movie_title: Nugu-ui ttal-do anin Haewon (Nobody's Daughter Hae-Won) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Nice try, guys, but no deal.
Christopher Payne's low-key, almost-romance.
I watched it with a nine-year-old who said: "This film is so annoying I want to kick it!"
Ultimately embarrassing and even offensive but has an offbeat premise, some neat characters and plenty of guffaw-worthy gags.
A wilfully opaque, if undoubtedly pioneering, documentary from British-French husband-and-wife team Lucien Castaing-Taylor and Verena Paravel.

A tense, shocking US documentary that plays out like an episode of The Wire, though in this case it's not a war on drugs that's being fought (and lost), but the war on terror.

In which Danny Dyer proves he's a brilliant actor in a heartbreaking work of staggering genius. Just kidding.
The 24-year-old's malnourished lips, and politeness, are what stick in the brain.
This inspirational, unexpectedly hilarious film is a patchwork of archival footage that takes us up to the present day.
It's slick and well acted (by Paul Giamatti, Zac Efron and Billy Bob Thornton, among others), but this attempt to make new sense of the death of JFK feels staggeringly pointless.
Like early Cronenberg, but funnier and sweeter, Computer Chess brings a dysfunctional, pioneering community to life. Bujalski must do a sequel.
At a party for Emma, a Louise Brooks film plays in the background. Brooks was a natural screen icon and both of these astonishing actresses share her intensity.
The success of this sequel will demonstrate, beyond doubt, that flesh-and-blood females can dominate the boysy, blockbuster landscape. How apt.
Think of it as a Trojan horse. Apparently harmless, it takes key myths about the land of the free and inflicts an impressive amount of damage.
That Grant didn't shove the script straight in the bin suggests he's purely desperate.
It's one of the year's best horror movies, full stop.
If you want to see corruption in the raw, track down Utopia.
A cockamamie project, yet somehow lovely, too.
Alas, I didn't buy a word of it.
Clearly, De Niro is happy to cannibalise his glorious past, but for those of us who love him, it's like sucking on old bones.
Cheering. Churning. No wonder Harvey Weinstein raced to pick up this little gem.

movie_review_blurb: One's final impression is that aging legends make unreliable puppet-masters. And that it's all too easy for a desirable young actress to be left dangling in mid-air.
movie_title: La Fille Coupée en Deux (The Girl Cut in Two) (A Girl Cut in Two) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The film is exquisitely shot. Yet something's missing. The figures in Maria's photographs are uncannily substantial. The characters in the film, by comparison, seem like fragrant ghosts.
movie_title: Maria Larssons eviga ögonblick (Everlasting Moments) (Maria Larsson's Everlasting Moment) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: There's no shortage of movies about Britain's mean streets and, for the most part, Awaydays runs with the pack.

Three Monkeys is a noirish thriller - boasting an explosive beginning, middle and end. The pace is still slow and the kiss-kiss bang-bangs take place off camera, but the effect is seismic.
Possibly the most excruciating comedy of the year.
At the start, Kudrow's character tells the time-wasting kids, "You owe me 30 seconds of my life." I'm owed rather more.
The beast of high-budget horror can be vanquished only if we starve it of cash. Stay out of the cinemas, my friends, and Jason and his kind will finally be able to rest in peace.

Director Jonathan Demme, who says he wanted to make "the most beautiful home movie ever made", didn't rehearse scenes before filming. He and Hathaway, as much as Lumet, deserve praise for creating a pariah at once close-to-home and unique.

Even if you hate it, the only thing you'll be wasting is your time.

Yes Man is not the edgy hit it so longs to be. When you look into the eyes of Stamp and the rest, what you see is embarrassed amusement. They said yes - to a big fat paycheque - and laughed all the way to the bank.

Twilight, a fantasy romance involving a self-loathing vampire and his sweet-blooded soul mate, is the kind of movie that gets pop culture addicts excited. Surrender to its daftness and you'll emerge covered in something very like a cold sweat.
The casting is fine, but the film's strange and potentially heartening story desperately needs a bolder touch.
Drag Me to Hell is simultaneously gritty and goofy, brightly coloured and down-to-earth.
An ingenious Spanish thriller about maths, sex, ambition and dog poo.
A watchable but ultimately blah family drama.
This does pretty much what it says on the tin, though the interactive "3D" element does introduce a twist of sorts.

Purportedly offering a slice of cultural history, this documentary is basically a big plug for fancy-schmancy "neo-burlesque" stripper Immodesty Blaize. Shameless stuff and about as sexy as a poke in the groin with a blunt stick.
The first time we see heads roll it's entertaining. The second time it's boring. The eighth time...
Essential viewing for people fascinated by the Nineties music scene of the Nineties. Pop history is written by musicians who get on with journalists. Watch and learn how it's done.
movie_title: Blur: No Distance Left to Run (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The Boys Are Back is frightened of being frightening and, as a result, has no sense of momentum.
As rowdy, democratic and open-ended as a Robert Altman saga, Brothers breathes life into the clichés surrounding traumatised vets.
As the last shot lingers, you long to find out what happens next.
Departure's cynicism, ironically, is what makes the optimism of its last act so moving.
This interminable, Soho-based gay relationship drama is especially marred by the dire acting of Luke de Woolfson, who plays a bad actor.
If Paranormal Activity is not quite as scary as the publicity would have us believe, it is at least witty, thought-provoking and -in a woozy, stark sort of way - beautiful.

Stiller has an ear for mainstream projects that keep a few steps ahead of the crowd, like Meet the Parents and Tropic Thunder. Escape 2 Africa is tame by comparison but it never treats us like dumb animals.

Fish Tank feels electrifyingly bold. And yet, taken as a whole, it's frustrating.
In common with so many Polish directors, Andrezej Jakimowski is obsessed with the peculiar magic of fate and coincidence but unlike Kieslowski, say, he avoids grandly ecstatic/gloomy set-pieces.
It's a black comedy, full of great lines and it deserves to be a mainstream hit. What a shame that it's often unnecessarily graphic.
Despite the group's many successes, self-pitying tears are rarely far from their eyes. It's fascinating stuff and unfathomably bleak.
Vincent Cassel is superb in the lead, craggily handsome, steely and volatile.
It's all a bit silly. There are lots of chases, curses, kisses and the odd fancy gadget.
It was made 33 years ago but Nagisa Oshima's doomed lust classic doesn't look in the least bit dusty. Quite the opposite.
movie_title: In the Realm of the Senses (1976)

movie_review_blurb: It's a film that is more ambitious than Knocked Up or The 40-Year Virgin and yet somehow more frustrating, too.
[Almodovar] frames with the greatest passion and, here, with muse Penélope Cruz dominating a story of erotic obsession, he surpasses himself.
Julie & Julia is a very American kind of money-spinner. Crucially, though, it is never dumb.
Happily, it's not only a return to form for the one-time Mormon and agent provocateur, it also offers Samuel L Jackson his first decent part in years.

Julia, by and large, is a tale of desperate opportunists, fugitive souls who survive by living on their wits, taking risks and making it up as they go along. It sometimes feels that a similar person is behind the camera as well as in front of it.
More cold than cute, De Niro's brilliance actually makes the film more confusing than it needs to be.
This ultra-hyped adaptation of the ultra-successful Helen Fielding novel sends you out with a smile on your face.
Ironically, what jeopardises the transaction is Ryan.

Does it matter that every time Jolie's offscreen the film wilts a little? Ryder should be perfect as the bright spark; her lines are sharp as a knife. There's a gap, however, between what we hear and what we see.
Sadly, Sheen doesn't even look profound. Like a zombie who's spent too much time in the gym, he blunders heavily from one stunt to the next, his pursed lips conveying nothing more than pique.
Much of the best dialogue, you suspect, was improvised by Tucker and Chan, who seem truly taken with each other and make a delightful, ordinary-extraordinary pair.
What saves the film from abomination is the basketball.
If you cut the beatings, you wouldn't be left with much.
The use of Plowright as a middle-aged frump wanting to get in on the sexy action is deeply patronizing.
Equally unengaging are hero Tim (Davidson), the wimpish buppie who loves her, and his male buddies, who provide the requisite quota of chauvinism.
Broomfield has great visual style, exposing-Britain's ugliness and beauty at every turn.
Myers exploits every vicious, self-hating line that comes his way.
And so we leave the cinema happy, our heads full of Gareth and gangsters-at-sea. Context, of course, is all.

movie_review_blurb: Vermeer's great gift as an artist was to imbue ordinary life with a sense of mystery. Alas poor Webber. The immaculate consummation witnessed here idles in a middlebrow limbo, neither earthy nor divine.

In its eagerness to give voice to the overshadowed daughter, the film never allows the mother to live.
The Talented Mr. Ripley is worth more than a peep.

Both Winfrey and Demme get a lot wrong.
You've Got Mail has much in common with Sleepless in Seattle but ultimately pales by comparison.
This is a film with all the itchily sweet passion of a Shangri-Las anthem, cranked up to full volume.
Nothing much about Mike Judge's creation has changed.
Armored is based on a first-time script which, thanks to a bit of industry hype, became the subject of a bidding war among the studios. Sony won the day. Guys, you were robbed.
I imagine someone like Gareth from The Office watching it, a big grin on his face, a box of tissues by his side.
It's easily the best of the trilogy and, for my money, one of the most enjoyable films of the decade.
Director Djamshed Usmonov frames his story beautifully.
movie_title: To Get to Heaven, First You Have to Die (Bihisht faqat baroi murdagon) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The performances are excellent - low-key and nuanced - but the set-up is so contrived that you never feel involved for long.
Yet for all the imperfections, Flawless is a film you find yourself rooting for. Heists involving a keen sense of history are pleasant to stumble across.
Año Uña feels like a calling card from a promising talent - but, as with a summer romance, it's not built to last.
Vince Vaughn and Reese Witherspoon play the leads. Do they convince as lawyers or lovers? No. Do they convince as space aliens trying to infiltrate the human race? Yes.
Sometimes the grimness and grandeur gel; sometimes they just add up to pompous soaps.
It feels like a spoof, yet this documentary, which follows the fortunes of a monumentally rubbish Iraqi band called Acrassicauda, is for real.

RocknRolla did not leave me wanting more (the last shot promises a sequel is on its way). Still, its confidence is impressive. London's property bubble may have burst but Ritchie's career is definitely on the rise.

In fact, Lopez deserves praise for pushing this project. The recently deceased Puchi (who helped generate the script and pushed for Lopez to play her) is not the kind of character you see on screen every day.

Plays like an unravelling of the Eighties comedy hit Trading Places. Instead of a smart-Alec street hustler who turns the tables on his seemingly benign patrons, we have a smart saint who simply wants to join the club.
He has tried to make Georgiana's quest for independence - her attempt to gain power via the media and the Whigs - just as gritty. Against the odds, he mostly succeeds.
A good-looking, sophisticated, if somewhat pointless addition to the slasher-horror genre.
Dude, the film so totally happens to be great.
French director Mathieu Kassovitz was once touted as the next Scorsese, thanks to his gritty debut, La Haine. Alas, this action-adventure epic suggests he has settled for being a Hollywood wannabe.
A week is a long time in cinema. Last Friday saw Branagh being all but written off thanks to the ludicrous Sleuth. This week, he's hitting the high notes.
The film's target audience - dummies everywhere - will be blown away.
Fred Claus tries desperately for a Bad Santa meets Elf vibe. Five minutes in, the man sitting next to me was sound asleep.
If you like schmaltzy, music-saturated family movies, This Christmas will set all the right bells jingling.
Let's avoid such extremes, and note merely that he's made a film that's funny ha-ha as well as funny peculiar; an exercise in navel-gazing that tickles all the senses.
I came, saw, had my retinas fried, and was conquered.
One day someone will make a film about a lone-wolf killer who gets offered One Last Job, turns it down, retires rich and lives happily ever after.
Ar-go see them in action.
Julian Temple's messy, whimsical look at the rise and fall of the British pub rock band Dr Feelgood packs a bigger punch than expected.
You'd have to be crazier than Joaquin Phoenix to see this film as ground-breaking. But when it's good, it ain't too bad at all.
A rom-com with brains that - at key moments - feels as sly and sweet as Annie Hall.
Are the camera moves graceful? Of course they are. Hypnotically graceful. Even the cigarette smoke looks like it's taken ballet lessons. But there's a bit more to the drama than meets the eye.
Thanks to the posturing, intrusive soundtrack and implausible, clichéd script, it's hard to take any of it too seriously.
The Silence is one of the most excruciating, paranoia-inducing films you'll see all year. Spread the word.
As with so many of Spielberg's blockbusters in the past 20 years, this one boasts technical innovation yet falls back on the most conservative kind of storytelling.
The problem lies with writer/director Arjun Rose, whose opportunism is matched only by his indifference to logic.
A haunting exploration of emotional and financial dependence that leaves you wondering if anyone can truly be said to stand on their own two feet.
Some movies are hard to spoof.
These smart actors are deconstructing their own glamour and seem far more scrumptious as a result.
Jespersen is a veteran comedian and he uses all his gravitas and dry wit to make us care about a lonely man on the verge of a crisis of faith.
I almost died laughing.
Jaunty, sad, poetic, Kes is so humane it makes you tremble.
If you're fascinated by the fall of Salvador Allende (who, of course, started his career as a physician) the wounded bodies on display will almost certainly break your heart.
A glossy fudge.
Why is the whole thing so watchable? Farrell is extremely good value. So is Toni Collette as the sex-starved but sensible single mom of high-school hero Charlie.
One of the funniest and most discombobulating films of the year.

The Hackney-bound pals sulk, flirt and hoover up vast quantities of cocaine.
Cast and crew spin a twilight magic.
As in Todd Haynes's 1995 masterpiece, Safe, we are in a world that can't be pinned down.
What we're left with is a sporadically entertaining mess. Moneyball is unsure about what (if any) risks it should take.
Paquin, whose squirmy style of acting I've never liked, is astounding here...
This isn't the real Thing; keep it at bay.
Tim Burton loves paying homage to other movies. Here, just for a change, he does so to one of his own.
Flirtatious, hyper-aware, funny. What a champ.

Like Martin Scorsese's The Last Waltz, this is a documentary about a farewell concert.

This whole caper is about as gritty as a babywipe.
One of those films you need to see twice, Miguel Gomes's subtle and bizarre little masterpiece unfolds slowly. Very slowly.
[Siegel] is now suing Greenfield for "misrepresentation". Well, I know whose side I'm on.
Certainly has its moments, yet lacks the tension of a real classic.
It's always dramatically satisfying when film-makers become part of the story; in this case, it's also politically instructive.
movie_title: Just Do It: A Tale of Modern-day Outlaws (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The film is about law vs chaos. Via its images, it manages to take both sides.
Proof that you can create nerve-scraping twilight zones without A-list stars or CGI.
Here's something truly weird: as soon as I was back in the real world, Cosmopolis knocked me sideways.
Tari is headed for college; Sriywati is headed nowhere. By the time the credits roll, you ache for them both.
Pooley could have been more probing in her interviews with the twins and their supporters. But the fact of the duo's success is so astounding you're gripped all the same.
If originality were a crime, this film's screenplay wouldn't need a lawyer.
The script's central paradox - that dogmatic believers are the most adept at switching allegiance - is arresting.
A frustrating documentary about a frustrating man.
