movie_review_blurb: The chemistry between the actors is gorgeously unhealthy; Oedipal, spiteful and sexy.
It shouldn't work, but somehow it does.
I found myself lurching forwards and rocking with laughter.
Yusef's trials feel exquisitely urgent.
It's a neat, topical set-up and, initially at least, Cell 211 possesses the sweaty, coiled intensity of Un Prophète. Alas, the second half is hokum. Que paso?
Bobby Fischer Against The World could be six times as long and still have you on the edge of your seat.
One of the most annoying things about the film is its smugness.
Basically very silly and wastes the time of some talented celebrities (including Lindsay Lohan, as an addled nymphet). But it has its moments.
You don't need to be interested in football to find Stewart Sugg's slick portrait of super-rich Manchester City FC involving.
Edward Furlong plays a depressed, catastrophe-hit loser who goes to a party in a haunted house and is duly pursued by demons. You feel the part wasn't much of a stretch.
French-made zombie flick The Horde isn't up there with Night of the Living Dead but still induces some unexpected gulps.
Just about bearable.
Director Nick Moran obviously feels strongly about the material but fails to create a consistent tone.

The Coen Brothers' O Brother Where Art Thou? was the last film to make such delirious use of mountain music. The rest of the world can start drooling over Lawrence. I'm gonna git me a copy of that soundtrack.
Cast and crew seem committed to making a simple point: "unhealthily close" relationships can be enriching. And the result is a movie that feels both small and deep.
As well as being conventional, The Girl Who Kicked is also confusing, dull and grubby (do we really need to see examples from a child-porn site?).
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's not so much a shock to the system as a series of practised strokes, yet -- for moments at a time -- it makes you squirm happily in your seat.
Breillat's ideas owes much to Angela Carter, yet The Bloody Chamber author would surely be depressed by the lack of dynamism on display.

When it comes to the things this brand is famous for -- angsty canoodling, ethereal rocking out, truckloads of male beauty, Duran Duran-style make-up and culturally savvy jokes -- Eclipse actually goes one better than the last offering.
I'd rather rot in a New Orleans jail than watch it again. And yet its epiphanies are outrageously sharp, it is beautifully shot by cinematographer Peter Zeitlinger and the ending is a joy.
movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It could have been a match made in heaven. The snake in the garden is a tired script from Rob and Mark Cullen, which purports to "spoof" Eighties buddy movies (Beverly Hills Cop, Lethal Weapon, etc) but lacks any real brain power of its own.

With great support from Eddie Marsan, Timothy Spall and young newcomer Nikita Mistry, humour and horror finally take a convincing hold of the plot and -- bibbidi-bobbidi-boo! -- an original idea gets transferred to the screen.
Streetdance (which, as the title subtly suggests, is shot in 3D) is being hyped as the first British dance movie. In other words, it's going where a gazillion American movies have gone before.
Blakeson has a good eye for the material world, a knack for making ugly-beautiful textures seem purely cinematic.
You realise that Martel knows exactly what she's doing and your heart starts to race.
movie_title: La Mujer sin Cabeza (The Headless Woman) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Authentic and hyper-real, a reflection of a young girl's inner life that never strays into hysteria.
A reference to the Holocaust feels awkward, but otherwise the blend of personal and political is electrifying.
The film is full of rows between Lev and his stagily irate wife. She's meant to be OTT - that's not the problem - it's the film itself that creaks.
It's Washington's Everyman who keeps the film honest.
Funny films are short on the ground and this one - which has already been dubbed a flop by US critics - deserves to be bigged up.

Treacle Jr won't win Oscars or swell the bank balances of cast and crew. In other words, it ain't The King's Speech. But I'd choose it over Tom Hooper's film any day, because it shows a London I recognise.
Fans of the genre will relish the ironies (or, as it's known in the trade, the chance to have your cake and eat it).
The word sexy is horribly overused. When it comes to this pair, though, it's the only word that will do.

Schmitz shoots the kids with dreamy respect. The adult actors have less to work with. Still, their agonised faces, not to mention their voices, create their own kind of texture and ensure we leave the cinema in tears.
Even those allergic to dance and/or the young will find themselves seduced.
Not so much triumphalist as upbeat, saucy rather than slick, Fire in Babylon is the kind of film that makes you proud to be a human being.
Win Win is slighter, and sappier, than it might have been. Still and all, it's a joy.
This cannily uncanny film resonates.
All three men give searing performances and young cinematographer Robert Hardy dwells with palpable relief on their expressive features.
This reboot may not be as revolutionary as it thinks, but it's definitely worth a second glance.
If Vidal The Movie were a haircut, it would be a peek-a-boo fringe. Now you see him, now you don't.
As culture clashes go, this one should be filed under rout.
Werner Herzog's latest documentary is scintillating. Sort of.
Writers Tony and Joe Gayton feed the trio just enough lines to make it seem like a team effort.
It seems guaranteed to infuriate anyone over seven.
Low expectations are the key to enjoying Wake Wood. You have been warned.
Harmless fun.
Chu has called Never Say Never "the origin story of a hero". Which is cobblers, obviously. But the film did convince me that Bieber is a dramatic figure.
Agonisingly slow and laughter-free.
movie_title: Big Mommas: Like Father, Like Son (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Director Hideo "The Ring" Nakata never connects with the script (by Enda Walsh, adapting from his own play).
PlanEat is on a serious mission but its lack of focus is infectious. My big question as the credits rolled: why are so many vegan chefs covered in tattoos?
If these actors felt they owed Goldsman a debt, they've paid it in full.
A stage-managed yet weirdly gripping documentary that tracks the final tour of DJ trio Swedish House Mafia.
The direction's so crude, and actress Yana Studilina so 24/7 pouty, that you'll be more tempted to laugh than cry.
This is a gory love story. It's a real gift.
movie_title: The Girl With All the Gifts (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Bridget Jones's Baby, ultimately, snatches victory from the jaws of defeat.
Furman is obviously working in the long shadow of Martin Scorsese and the Breaking Bad team. Still, he's learned all the right lessons, especially when it comes to music.
If you're scared of twigs this movie will have you urinating in the aisles.

The beauty of the film lies in its refusal to paint Ben as a deluded tyrant or principled pioneer. He doesn't have two faces - thanks to the script, as well as Mortensen's squirrely brilliance, he has hundreds.
As with Starred Up, Mackenzie's family-centric prison drama, Hell or High Water is full of grim nooks and crannies.
Like a wry scientist, wading through the jungle, Guiraudie notes every tiny, unwritten law. It's infectious stuff.
Allen's script throws together familiar elements (ruthless hoodlums, respectable hypocrites, insecure film buffs) but lacks pace, belly-laughs or texture.
Mia Hansen-Love's precise script, perfectly in tune with Huppert's methods, works like a sharp knife, gently able to slip between our ribs.
It's hard to explain how cleverly the film is structured without giving away crucial twists.
Never dull.
Solondz loves revisiting his creations (he did it in Life During Wartime and, glancingly, Palindromes). Alas, he never improves on the originals.
Finding Dory is inferior to Finding Nemo (and both Toy Story sequels). Those films are tesseracts, this one's a cube. That said, to label it average somehow misses the point.
Becomes so wedded to stodgy melodrama that you wind up thinking it's a bore to be that blue and just want to hear the man play.
Black lives matter. So does nuance.
The scriptwriters fall back on that most exhausted of dynamics, the tension between a doting father and his potential son-in-law, and can't even do it with charm.
Jackson is the film's greatest asset. He's also its biggest problem. He's just too charismatic.
Summer blockbusters used to be reliably homophobic but, thanks to Johnson, this one's approach to love and lust seems genuinely new wave.
Both predictable and confounding.
This is one of Burton's minor dreams but its yukky-yummy fragments are still doing cartwheels in my head.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A great story, galumphingly told.
The Babadook's villains and victims are still running amok in my brain. I think they might be there for some time.
There are so many fascinating things about this film.
When presented with the script, Boyle et al should just have said no.
Google Earth has blind spots and so does Lion. Still, it covers an awful lot of ground and the views are stunning.
It's far from perfect, but where so many modern horror movies are anonymous, Split has personality and then some.
It ain't rubbish, but Affleck's fly-by-night operation is still one to avoid.
If you like weird bedtime stories, hunt it down.
Crude but crafty ...
This lovely ode to change (which gets you thinking, not just about gender but all hierarchies) contains two powerful youngsters. It should really be called The Eaglet and her Girl.
Williams's wrenching yarn dissects various betrayals and offers a useful reminder: when it's all about the brand, we're all fair game.
Stone's film is about as suspenseful as a trip to Ikea.
Elvis and Nixon are fascinating - if only we were allowed to spend more time with them.
In the next election, can I just vote Disney?
Shinkai is one to watch but doesn't quite yet deserve to be a household name.
I'm glad Indignation exists. In its own, quietly explosive way, it leaves a very human stain.
At least, in its determinedly populist way, this violent character study makes you think.
I defy anyone to leave in a bad mood. James and Bob seem like good people. Or good cats.
Tom Cruise's latest action spectacular is so dull that I found myself willing on the baddies.
Queen of Katwe mostly does what you expect it to do (albeit vivaciously). Then, like its Ugandan heroine, Phiona Mutesi, it jumps eight moves ahead.
Silly plot. Fancy locations.
A popsicle-coloured, 3D cartoon with a pertinent, if somewhat hard to explain conceit.
There's so much going on - too bad not a single encounter feels plausible or the least bit dangerous.
True, some of Paterson's poems are just dull-dull. And the whimsy can be cloying. But the acting is fantastic.
You won't forget Remainder in a hurry.
Great. So now, along with being spooked by claps, dolls and nuns, I'm tisantaphobic too. Thanks for everything, James Wan.
While Guerra clearly owes a debt to Herzog and Coppola, he blazes his own trail. I can't wait to take this trip again.
movie_title: Embrace Of The Serpent (El Abrazo De La Serpiente) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Some may find Longoria's wry tone offensive but his playfulness is what make him worth watching. If laughter kills fear, this man is quite the slayer.
Chiwetel Ejiofor's new movie is a mess. Even the title - why are there more eyes than secrets? - induces brain ache.
True, your average broody careerist might struggle to find a gym-toned-cutie with a secret yearning to be a stay-at-home dad. Then again, what film doesn't encourage fantasies?
Hillcoat is clearly fascinated by the ever-increasing gap between America's rich and poor. A shame he can't turn that crisis into a credible drama.

Moore gets to wear a striking wig but has no dialogue that makes you look twice. And the more Stacie cries over her saintly lover, the more guiltily conscious you become that your own eyes are water-free.
A Bigger Splash isn't about how the other half live. It's rooted in something much closer to home.
It's entertaining at first that our heroine and hero can slay zombies as expertly as they parry quips but the joke wears thin.
Goosebumps combines cynicism with sweetness. If you can get past the slow start, woefully blank hero Zach (Dylan Minnette), and hit-and-miss special effects, you'll be charmed.
One day, perhaps, an HBO mini-series will tackle this cultural face-off and blow our minds. In the meantime, check out Trumbo.
The film is simultaneously sweet, simple and savvy.
Its horrible message: the old are only interesting when they're capable of aping the young.
Bullock is hilarious as well as unsettling in the lead.
Creed is a sure-fire hit that's impossible to hate but I may have to punch the next person who tells me it made them cry.
Larson delivers every line to perfection and, as it happens, there's not one weak link in the cast.

Like the anti-war saga In the Valley of Elah, A War explores a misuse of power that has horrific consequences. What's different is that here the crime takes place under our noses and, even more disturbingly, feels justified.

Given the circumstances, Read has done a wonderful job. Instead of promoting or smearing a celebrated brand he's created a portrait of a workplace that feels both pertinent to Putin's Russia and universal.
The voices are too gloopy, Linus has been given an unnecessary hair transplant and, worst of all, Snoopy's plot thread (technically a story-within-a-story) is dull and dodgy.
The landscapes are gorgeous; the ironies stark.
The huge, whale-sized problem is that Howard can't decide if this is dark, adult fare or a rollicking tale of derring-do.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: I love nature but halfway through Sunset Song I began to suffer from field fatigue. Cinematographer Michael McDonough shoots the soil and its various fruits with reverence - too much reverence.
Sorrentino wants to say something profound about illnesses that bury loved ones alive. But the pompous lines kill the mood.
Deluded-yet-indomitable, Kenny is just too familiar a figure and the absurdly upbeat twist ending is the final insult.
Aware that gender, as much as faith, remains a burning issue, Eggers makes our hearts swell and our brains sweat.
The film feels like a riposte to Trump-ism. It also contains some of the best sloth-related humour you will ever see.
The confidently modest McCarthy creates her own happy endings. Make a date with this woman and you'll TF it's Friday.
Jones commands the SFX but (for now) he's lost the power to move.
Me Before You is old-fashioned and cosy. It's also part of a highly-charged and very 21st-century debate.
This yummy film feels like a healthy choice for growing girls. Though it probably won't earn a billion dollars, what it offers is priceless.

There's much to recommend X-Men: Apocalypse - its best sequences knock the crap out of anything and everything in Batman v Superman. But its bad moments are worse than the worst bits in Captain America: Civil War.
For all the high-tech lingo, there's nothing new to feel or see.
Carney nails every quirky detail.
How can you resist a film that, metaphorically, throws Simon & Garfunkel, Fugazi and Slayer into the same moshpit?
Everybody Wants Some!! is obsessed with seduction. Don't let me stop you going all the way with Linklater. I'm just here to warn you that, with regards to this film, he doesn't go very deep.

More befuddled, plot-wise, than just about any other superhero epic of the last decade, Batman v Superman nevertheless deserves points for creating a vision of modern America that feels truly fractured.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Bleak biopics don't have to be grim (think of Raging Bull). But this one is neither illuminating nor able to make the most of the dark.
The central debate is topical but it cries out for input from some of Marvel's newer creations (if only there was space for Ms Marvel, aka Kamala Khan, a Pakistani-American teen from New Jersey).
Actor Don Cheadle, the star, director and co-writer of this ambitious biopic, doesn't want to play nicely. He wants to play.
Is it possible that Natalie Portman can't act?
The film's generous spirit keeps digging it out of trouble.
movie_title: The Brand New Testament (Le tout nouveau testament) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This new Jungle Book, upon closer inspection, may not have what it takes to survive. Still, right now, it looks wonderfully fit.
It's a Frozen-meets-Hunger Games-meets-X-Men rip-off, but I'm prepared to cut it some slack because it contains a truly novel character: a cool female dwarf.
I can't see many people trekking to the cinema to see this but if you stumbled across it on TV you'd feel really chuffed.
Schipper and his young team may not be up there with Hitchcock but they tell a good story. When it comes to pain, these kids cut to the chase.
Whatever the state of your mental health, you'll want to follow Alice down the rabbit hole.
A fitfully hilarious comedy sequel from Seth Rogen, the kind of man who can get away with pointing at a pregnant Hasidic woman and saying: "Look, another little Jew in the oven!"
It's a pleasure and an honour to spend time with the interviewees (Miguel, Enrique and Simon are especially adorable, articulate and open) but there's something disingenuous about Chemsex.
Boasts two fascinating characters and a string of surreal set-pieces that you can't afford to miss.
This is a portrait of a doomed marriage that allows its stars to explode.
People have a right to make godless films. Bean's made one, and it's as brilliant as it is humane.
It's a must-see. Mainstream epics routinely privilege the father-son bond... In The Hours, patriarchs barely figure, and the only phallic weapon on display is Virginia's pen.

That Zellweger can make us believe in Bridget's heaving inner world is par for the course -- she's a supremely talented comic actress. That she was willing to risk her own status as sex symbol by looking like an everywoman is really impressive.
It's a topical treatise on memory and artificial intelligence that asks how the human brain works (or doesn't).
The camera, if especially respectful towards the children, refuses to demonise any of the characters.
Bad Moms 2, in that it could have been so much worse, winds up not being bad at all.
Keoghan is crucial to the unsettling mix. By turns inscrutable, vulnerable and ruthless, he has squished eyes and a nose that looks like it's just been punched.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Grace Jones's intelligence, integrity and vulnerability come through as never before.
What makes this film special? Aside from the fluid script, inventive camerawork and three uncanny songs by Sufjan Stevens, it's surely the acting, which seems scooped from the performers' marrow.
Whenever things take a turn for the surreal, as opposed to the sentimental, Breathe expands.
It's hard to make gripping a character who hasn't found their voice. Yet Mulubwa does.
Landon's scary movie offers a short, sharp shock to the system. Let it make your day.
What are neural networks? I have no idea. But the team's delight in their creation is something any idiot can understand.
There's a lot here to love.
It's soft, wrong and very, very long.
If you're a fan of Bridesmaids, Obvious Child and/or TV shows such as Girls and Fleabag, you'll feel a tingle of rapture, roughly 10 minutes into the proceedings. That feeling won't go away.
This film could have been so much better.
Maybe pre-teen girls will go for these unnervingly sanitised shenanigans.
Cruel, spineless, virtually laughter-free and, above all, dull. Even putting the plot to paper makes my head ache.
A more serious problem is that Parker doesn't trust his material and - under the guise of pointing up Wilde's subversive wit - has opted to play safe.

Hunter and Hunsinger show what can happen if you opt instead for the humour that accompanies can-I-feel? quiet. Turns out wit and warmth and keen observation produce their own euphoria -- what you might call a natural high.
The Heart of Me, inspired by Rosamund Lehmann's anguished classic The Echoing Grove, is a costume drama that wants to be more than the sum of its wardrobe.
What it feels like is a 10-minute short that's been yanked every which way but loose.
A hilarious, knowing bit of schlock ...
I'd happily pay to see this movie again. And again. Phoenix and Ramsay are demonic upstarts. And for most of this movie it's just heaven to be by their side.
A Fantastic Woman asks us to embrace all things fluid and, thanks to the superstar at its centre, it's a pleasure to go with the flow.
The spoofy action set-pieces are ho hum. What's special is the minutiae-based, casually political banter.
This is a silly old film but its vulnerable characters are a blast.
Like many wonderful actresses with a gift for words (think Julie Delpy, Sarah Polley and Lake Bell) Gerwig has slipped behind the camera to create something quietly political.
Firth laps up the ambiguity, expertly conveying the mess - the brilliant mess - inside Crowhurst's head.
The latest from Leviathan director Andrey Zvyagintsev is a fluffy romcom perfect for St Valentine's Day. Just kidding.
Think of it as a really, really, little gem.
The film works (for much of its running time, at least) because the myth being peddled is an appealing one.
Funny, irreverent and eye-popping. It will also make you want to cry at least once but possibly as many as three times.
Three Billboards is great.
Sorkin, directing for the first time, has made an outrageously self-righteous thriller.
If you're a fan of Spirited Away's Chihiro, you will be enchanted by gentle Ethel.
After meeting the first few characters I was gripped by an overwhelming desire to nod off. Then I saw the light.
Feels like a bone-headed clone of Fargo.
It's as raw a slice of escapism as you could wish for.

His theories are fascinating, but if his ex-girlfriend is anything to go by, he had terrible taste in people. She and her husband blaze with self-importance, but secrete frustration and disappointment from every pore.
movie_title: Thomas Pynchon: Journey Into the Mind (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The acclaim is justified.
MacKinnon's too timid to explore this in any depth. Pure is basically a morality tale, which sends out the Harry Potter-ish message that pluck, rather than luck, saves the day.
Lili Fini Zanuck's documentary gives us plenty of time to ponder Clapton's physique but if you're hoping to get inside the rock legend's head, look elsewhere.
movie_title: Eric Clapton: A Life in 12 Bars (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's one for the quietly desperate - a grim fairytale that suggests it's possible to keep the wolf from the door.
movie_title: On Body and Soul (A Teströl és Lélekröl) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: The epilogue suggests Mitch has a bright future. Back in the real world, everything about him looks dim.
Just spending time with this motley crew makes the world seem a saner place.
Snatched is the kind of movie that makes long-haul flights whizz by. Its heroines are dumber than they should be and smarter than they know.
It's a shame Raymond Carver is not around to watch this.
EU rules. Insurance scams. Infectious diseases. These are all serious topics, yet it's when Leach fools around that The Levelling feels like it has something truly important to say.
Elizabeth Sloane's a real piece of work - and so is this film.
The Seventies footage is electrifying. But what makes this documentary special is that it doesn't put its subject on a pedestal.
Barratt's delightfulness can't disguise the mediocrity of Mindhorn.
The sets look phoney. The relentlessly sun-dappled skies are naff. The "action" lacks momentum and Tom Hollander's eyeliner is mad.
It's a tiny movie but it feels like a big deal.
Tony and his frenemies are a peculiar bunch. Hang out with them while you can.
Small children often experience the world as simultaneously solid and fantastical; De Wit's beautiful film tugs us into that mindset.
In the words of Kurt Russell's FBI maverick, Mr Nobody: "Rule number one. Know your audience." The powers-that-be certainly know us.
Though brand new, The Lost City of Z already feels out of date.
Within five minutes, I was shivering with boredom.
It's wellacted and full of low-key pain and humour (you would expect nothing less from the man behind A Separation, one of the most excruciatingly humane and nuanced films of the decade).
The script, along with Roger Goldby's direction, is numbingly inept.
The CGI Kong is cool.
Fighting a stealth war on conventional thinking, Chadha offers us a tantalising epic, what you might call a halfway house.
Its rhythms and performances are built to last. If you don't seek it out now, it'll catch you later.
Unanswered questions pile up, until only one remains. Could this be the stupidest third act EVER?
Seydoux, Cassel and Baye, though hampered by character arcs that feel a shade too familiar, are more than adequate.
movie_title: It's Only the End of the World (Juste la fin du monde) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Mostly [Peele] creates a lovely, off-kilter mood, riffing with tremendous visual poise on all sorts of classics, including Seconds, Guess Who's Coming to Dinner and The Stepford Wives.
Feels like something farted out of the backside of the Eighties.
Cynical and gross.
This isn't a weepie but as you realise what's happening you may want to cry.
movie_title: After the Storm (Umi yori mo mada fukaku) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Wind River ticks all the right boxes. It also leaves a bad smell.
Charlie Plummer, 18 playing 15, with the looks of a teenage Christopher Walken, brings great presence to Charley - and we're rooting for him all the way.
Some will file God's Own Country under F for fantasy. Others will see it as a portent of rapprochements to come. Either way, it's a winner.
Jasper's point is that being oneself is always a performance. If we know how to tell a story we all have the right to get up on stage.
It's director Doug Liman's refusal to spoon-feed that makes the story so potent.
Wildly entertaining.
Watching this Judd Apatow-produced romcom is like clicking on a for-real YouTube clip of a kitten juggling spoons. Cute. Clever. No wonder The Big Sick has gone viral.
Psychologically impressive and fiendishly involving.
If you can detach your noggin from the proceedings, there are definitely bright spots.
My Life as a Courgette isn't perfect (some of the adult characters lack nuance) but its attempt to redefine innocence is stirring.
movie_title: My Life as a Zucchini (Ma vie de courgette) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: I didn't find the anecdotes especially revealing and was unimpressed by much of the art.
It's not exactly scary but it made me so tense I could hardly breathe, let alone think.

Holland probably has five more years in which to dazzle us, and it'll be a crime if Batalon and Zendaya aren't by his side. This franchise is now all about Peter and his friends. Here's looking at you, kids.
Watching Agnes is like emptying five packets of Space Dust into your mouth: guaranteed to induce tingles.
Here's a prediction. First-year drama students will soon be Blu-Tacking the hell out of posters for Baby Driver, which will make Edgar Wright at once embarrassed and proud.
Bong's slick and slippery offering is a game-changer. Call it Netflix's first great film. Call it, simply, great.
Though convoluted and mostly indistinguishable from piffle, it's by no means the worst of the bunch.
Keaton and Gleeson are sweet together (I like the sweaty, studenty-vibe they create in Emma's attic). It's also nice to see London's housing crisis being discussed.
Emotional manipulation gets a bad press. But, hey, sometimes being milked for tears is fun.
You get the sense of a woman battling so hard to impress white America that her moral compass has gone haywire.
If you like this kind of thing, The Death of Louis XIV is fascinating.
movie_title: The Death of Louis XIV (La mort de Louis XIV) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The set pieces combine great performances with slyly clever writing.
The animation? Well, it robs you of breath, over and over again.
After a slow start Noé's self-referential soap proves more-ish.
A beautiful movie about fame and family.
Arterton, blonde sister of Gemma, is pallid from every angle, while Scholey feels like a backing singer who, for some reason, has been booted centre stage.
Throughout it all, Binoche's face shivers with emotions that Claudel herself cannot pin down.
For every nauseating moment in this cancer-related weepie, there's a lovely, thought-provoking exchange of ideas.
Asante's own work of art is lamentably cautious but does, ultimately, throw up things we haven't seen before. It's pretty, in other words, but not entirely vacant.
TS Spivet looks wacky but is, in fact, purely bland. Films like this work best if you ignore the dialogue. Bring ear buds and you'll be fine.
movie_title: The Young And Prodigious T.S. Spivet (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Jordan doesn't beg for our sympathy and is all the more magnetic as a result. The finale is devastating.
Never mind life, death and supermarkets, this is a film about a diva. If you're in the mood to pay homage, you're sorted.
movie_title: Pulp: a Film About Life, Death & Supermarkets (2014)

movie_review_blurb: There's no denying this project's peculiar, landscape-changing power.
This summer blockbuster is almost ready to conquer the world. But not quite.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: There are far worse ways to spend 88 minutes of your life.
The script rings false from the off.
To ensure long-term survival, this franchise needs to evolve. In terms of the competition, however, it's still light years ahead.
The sense you get of this man is that he was trying to heal his own wounds by winning.
movie_title: Pantani: The Accidental Death Of A Cyclist (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It boasts a fantastic turn from TV veteran Robin Weigert and is visually reminiscent of Todd Haynes's Safe (it's beautiful to look at).
The film at times resembles an Agatha Christie movie - the kind of classy product TV companies love to show on a snoozy Sunday afternoon.
Arnie does his best but, as so often, turns out to be limited in scope: when called upon to look upset, his inner cyborg punctures the mood; when he sighs, we snigger.
It's being billed as Hayao Miyazaki's last film. He can't leave us this way.
Low on feel-good pizzazz but absolutely brimming with love and respect.
I was determined to loathe the immaculate Charlotte yet, thanks to Peake, I found myself willing her on.
Keating's film career has barely started. Alas, it may already have jumped the shark.

Admittedly, in director/star Noel Clarke's low-budget sci-fi actioner, the acting and script do provoke surprise: both are so bad, you find yourself wondering if what's unfolding is some kind of parody.
Woohoo! Discombobulation is fun.
'71 hurtles along, visceral and daring.
It's an age-old story. Boy loses girl. Boy finds girl. Boy realises girl is undead.
While we're waiting for the next batch of monster make-overs - we're surely only one step away from Leatherface in Love - there's quite a bit to enjoy here.

It's almost as if the film has been designed to make fans of Downton Abbey realise the error of their ways. Are you impressed - aroused, even - by the stinking rich? If so, get ready to hold your nose.
If Mick Jagger attempted something like this, it would be excruciating.

Dunston does not, in fact, check in.
Melancholia is not about the end of the world, but the end of a feeling: happiness.
The Girl splashes Abbie Cornish's fantastic acting, but the film is dead in the water.
Stallone dresses in drag for his first onscreen appearance as a cop. This is one reel bad dude.
A mixture of unhinged brilliance, idiocy, unsettling confusion, and a whole lot of chaos.

Life is full of funny little moments, full of heartbreak and sadness, and full of love. Love, happiness, and finding peace take a little time. Afternoon Delight captures these feelings in the most sincere way possible.
An unforgettable coming-of-age comedy that's sweet, witty, and brings back the joys of being young and full of life.
Upstream Color is a very layered and complex movie. But it's also rich and beautiful. I expect nothing less from the crowded and radiant mind of Shane Carruth.
THE NECESSARY DEATH OF CHARLIE COUNTRYMAN is the unnecessary death of a potentially good movie.
Experience is the best teacher in Kyle Patrick Alvarez' riveting portrait of self-discovery, C.O.G.
The Way, Way Back is everything you want in a laugh out loud, crowd-pleasing, coming-of-age movie.
The most important adult-oriented film about the victories and woes of high school life in the last decade.
Gutsy, sexy, and hilarious. Don Jon's Addiction bulks up the body and career of Joseph Gordon-Levitt.
An almost likable movie about unshackling the past.
Prince Avalanche marks David Gordon Green's triumphant return to compelling storytelling. Welcome Back, dude.
In the opening scene, an unnamed narrator claims Lester is, "a child of God much like yourself perhaps." If this is true, jokes on us because only Satan could spawn a man like Lester Ballard.
Highly illogical and silly. The main disadvantage with Lucy is that it's trying to be too smart for its own good.
Brick Mansions starts to crumble before the movie really begins. Somehow, the writers of the original film managed to screw up everything they got right the first time around.
One the most transcending films you'll see in a theater in your lifetime.
The Hateful Eight isn't a western as wacky as Django Unchained, but it's everything you want from a Tarantino movie: unbearable tension, deft and intuitive dialogue, and sudden, grisly violence
Out of this world.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: An energetic beast packed with bullets to the head, hyper-violence and well-choreographed ass kickings.
It's wild, it's bold, and the final act is an exhilarating force that will leave you slack-jawed. Star Laia Costa is a virtuoso of talent and her nuanced emotional range is going to make her a star.
Dark, dirty, and dangerous. Black will do for Belgium what Gomorrah did for Italy, what City of God did for Brazil, and what pretty much every Martin Scorsese gangster picture does for America.
Regina Casé mesmerizes. You will not see a better performance this year.
movie_title: The Second Mother (Que Horas Ela Volta?) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A Brave Heart is a tender and soulful movie about being confident in your own skin. Prepare to be moved and exhilarated.
movie_title: A Brave Heart: The Lizzie Velasquez Story (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Beautiful and soul-stirring. One & Two is a magical and transcending experience about the strength of sibling love
Gillian Flynn's Dark Places left me slack-jawed. Gilles Paquet-Brenner's film adaptation is gutless and misbegotten.
Cop Car is a deftly written and directed movie with car chases, violence, mayhem, and a cold and ruthless Kevin Bacon. This movie is absolute madness.
Fiery, raw, and packed with Hope, Southpaw is an exuberant punch to the gut.
I Am Chris Farley is a rigorous, emotional watch, but also a tender and sterling tribute to a man who was once one of the funniest people on the planet.
Looney and hilarious, Trainwreck thrusts you deeper Inside Amy Schumer.
Amy is one of the most important, tragic and compelling documentaries I have ever seen. If you have a chance to see this in theaters, I say go, go, go.

Terminator Genisys​ prospers in sublime action and special effects, but they are outweighed by too many plot holes and erroneous events in the new timeline. My soft heart for the franchise still liked it despite the plethora of flaws.
Big Game is a bonanza of big fun.
A fast-paced adrenaline shot to the heart that shows the underbelly of the streets of L.A., but somehow, along the film's journey, it becomes strangely endearing and quite lovable.
Jurassic World bites off more than it can chew but has enough meat to chomp on for a roaring good time.
A Woody Allen-esque movie Woody Allen would hate.
Most natural disaster movies are dated because the effects age so badly. San Andreas is a movie with careful CGI that will still look powerful as the years go by.
A nail-biting, edge-of-your-seat wallop, The Wailing is the most frightening movie of the year.
A sweet and poignant examination of finding solace in the art world hustle. Don't Think Twice is one of the best films of the year.

HUNT FOR THE WILDERPEOPLE, the most endearing buddy comedy adventure you'll see this year. It has all the wit and its crafty humor will keep you laughing and entertained from beginning to end. See this movie as soon as you can.
A Sweet and Poignant Examination of Finding Solace in the Art World Hustle.
In his ever-growing oeuvre, Dunkirk ranks as one of Christopher Nolan's best.
Harold and Lillian: A Hollywood Love Story paints a delightfully layered rags to riches story.
movie_title: Harold And Lillian: A Hollywood Love Story (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A poignant and hilarious story of brotherhood and finding love in a hungry place.
Uwais puts in 110%. He wants a jazzy show for his audience and never disappoints. However, his charm and killer choreographed fight scenes aren't enough to save Headshot.
The Edge of Seventeen is a must-see for anyone who's slogged through the purgatories of high school. So...everyone?
I Don't Feel at Home in This World Anymore. is punk rock, effortlessly cool.
movie_title: I don't feel at home in this world anymore. (2017)

movie_review_blurb: John Wick 2 is old money for a new generation. An explosive, well-organized action movie. We no longer need James Bond. Our new dressed to kill cinematic savior is John Wick.
Incredible fist-pumping fight scenes.

Snyder knows how to paint a picture but perhaps needs to stay away from the writing process. Watch the Ultimate Edition when you can, and see if it changes how you feel about the movie. It sure did me.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Invite your BFFs over for a back-to-back FURY ROAD extravaganza, then debate which is better. It'll drive you all mad.
movie_title: Mad Max: Fury Road: Black & Chrome (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Buckle up tight, moviegoers - Mad Max: Fury Road is one hell of a ride.
The pets' decorum emphasizes jokes adults will appreciate, and there are enough gratifying gags that will surely make the kids laugh.
LA LA LAND La La Lavishes with joy and warmth. This is a movie I want to live in.
Worth the price of admission.
The student becomes the teacher, and it works.
Chucky's back and Scream brought the mass-murdering doll back to the small screen with their Collector's Edition of CHILD'S PLAY, stuffed with all the extra features you would kill for.
Criminally underseen yet solid gold.
Worth the buy for one scene: watching a young Robert Downey, Jr. elbow-punch a couch.

Slow, then bloated, and explodes with boredom, and will probably lull you to sleep before you even get to the end. I don't know where it went wrong since the director is the one who made the X-Men franchise super popular, but we all have our bad days.

Wildly entertaining if you can put up with the relentless farting - Paul Dano bangs out a charming performance as a desperate, maybe delusional, man trying to get off the purgatory of an island he's stuck on.

THE WAILING doesn't rely on many jump scares and what makes it so horrifying is the story. It challenges Heaven and Hell, good versus evil, God, and the Devil, and faith. I'm certain this would be John Milton's favorite film if he were alive today.
Wildly impressive, Claire Carré's science fiction indie, Embers takes visceral cinema with a small budget and colossal imagination to exciting new heights.
The best and most violent in the HOME ALONE series.
Terminator 2 will always be his best film and most memorable role, but as far as acting goes, Maggie features Arnold Schwarzenegger's finest performance of his career. He crushes it.
One of the most magical films of Pete Docter's career.
BLUE VALENTINE shows us the present will never be as fun as the past.

What could have been a really exceptional movie on the great fight for water and a horrifying portrait on lives lived in isolation just kind of limps along to its finish with all the conviction of a dismissive shrug.
Jason Reitman has made a movie that bears no wit or soul. That's a sentence I never thought I'd write.
Sharp, sadistic and sensational.
The Equalizer is a bit flat and by-the-numbers, but it's also good old-fashioned shoot-'em-up splatter fun.
I want to high five the person who cast Benning and Moore as a couple. They're scenes are the most delicious parts of the film.
Sin City: A Dame to Kill For relishes style over substance. But, man, it's ugly.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A cool and kooky love story.
Action packs a mean punch in Expendables 3, but the franchise is running on fumes.
Cowabummer.
Guardians of the Galaxy is one of Marvel Studios' best and certainly the most punk rock.
Tanks may drive slow, but the action in Fury comes fast and furious.
The jury has reached a verdict: Alex of Venice is guilty of being great.
Self-serving and juvenile.
The special effects are breathtaking. And, in turn, they make this film the most confident, engrossing and fierce Apes-released movie to date.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Impressive and pretty amazing. This is how you make a film.
This is one song-and-dance that should have stayed stuck in the jukebox.
[Director David] Michôd's bravura is an intimidating reminder that he's ahead of the audience every step of the way.
The Fault in Our Stars isn't really a movie about cancer or death. Rather, it's quite-excellent film about finding love in a hopeless place.
Edge of Tomorrow is a delicious reminder that Cruise still has all the right moves.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Large and in charge.
Blue Ruin is violent but it impressively avoids the glorification of bloodshed; instead, [director Jeremy] Saulnier deftly shows just how terrifying, unnerving, sad and awful it is to take a life.
If there's something in this movie that needs saving, it's the film itself. And that's an order above even The Amazing Spider-Man.
A soulful movie about soulful people. You just can't help but fall in love with it.
Whiplash is an emotionally draining and spiritually challenging watch. But, in the end, it's one that's well worth every beating.
Despite some really vile scenes, Wetlands is a marvelous achievement in filmmaking. There's no denying it's one of a kind.
Nightcrawler features the craziest, creepiest, coolest sonofabitch Jake Gyllenhaal has played on screen yet.
It's interesting, it's funny, it's heartfelt, it's heartbreaking, and it's dirty. Everything Rivers wants to be known for.
movie_title: Joan Rivers: A Piece Of Work (2010)

movie_review_blurb: An exceptional directorial debut by Philip Seymour Hoffman, JACK GOES BOATING is a touching story about how of love is awkward, funny, and important.

Age of Ultron is a feast of visual delights, but plot wears thin. If Anthony Russo and Joe Russo (Captain America: The Winter Soldier), who are now taking over the Avengers series, want to keep the audience fully invested, some re-Assembly is required.
Knowing Albert Maysles made the film already gives it instant credibility, but Iris' flamboyant personality is animated enough to make the film sweet, enchanting, and quite lovable.

Birdman is a strange, beautiful and loony story about passion and pain but also a crazy cool celebration of filmmaking, movie magic and all of the glorious reasons why we love watching motion pictures.
Adult Beginners has a lot of missteps and it doesn't seem to know where it's going. For me, it's going in the "never watching again" pile.
A dark, erratic, and wacky new entry into the Coming-of-Rage sub-genre, Just Jim is just strange enough for me.
Magical, beautiful, and soul-stirring.
The pulverizing My Life Directed by Nicolas Winding Refn has given me a newfound respect for Only God Forgives.
movie_title: My Life Directed By Nicolas Winding Refn (2015)

movie_review_blurb: MAPS TO THE STARS forgets its initial goal and winds up being what it hates the most: a Hollywood movie.
A vampire mockumentary that bites into the same vein of Spinal Tap comedy and cranks it up to eleven.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Marion Cotillard Proves Herself An Undeniable Force In The Emotionally Jarring Two Days, One Night.
Weak, uninspiring and tame, political satirist Jon Stewart makes a mediocre directorial debut with Rosewater.
It's not as smart as the original, but Dumb and Dumber To is still fun enough.
Writer-director-star Ari Gold understands the diversity of humor and does a superb job balancing the absurd with the laugh out loud funny. He just gets it.
Foxcatcher is an arresting look the pitfalls of the American dream. Steve Carrell mesmerizes.
A profound meditation on loss, regret, acceptance and rediscovery, Wild takes some Impressive turns.
The major handicap of Mockingjay - Part 1 is that just that -- part one of two films made from one book.
Angelina Jolie shuts up the naysayers and flashes colossal promise with Unbroken.
Wacky, wild and just as loony as Thomas Pynchon's novel it's based on.
An Exhilarating, Fresh Take On Gangster Movies Emerges In J.C. Chandor's A Most Violent Year.
Mark Wahlberg deals a cool hand, but THE GAMBLER still loses big.
A grand, richly achieved fantasy epic that exalts such previously uncool virtues as honor, loyalty, self-sacrifice and chivalry.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: King Arthur is another big, expensive opportunity inexplicably wasted by an army of extremely talented movie people.
A crackerjack B-movie sci-fi adventure.
Almost everything about this movie looks and feels right.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A travelogue pretending to be a movie.
Runaway Jury may curdle into sentimental message-mongering in the closing minutes, but up to then it's a pungent potboiler cooked just so by skilled professionals.
[Nair] has achieved a near-miracle of literary transmutation, taking a supremely rich, complicated and clear-eyed 19th century novel and turning it into a coherent and highly entertaining movie.
Red Dragon restores to Hannibal the dignity of pitiless evil that so terrified and enthralled us in Silence of the Lambs.
Together, Williams and Romanek have made a stalker thriller that's as much in sympathy with the loneliness and alienation of the putative villain as it is with the jeopardy of his potential victims.
That avalanche, which Diesel's character causes on purpose, is one of the most impressive action sequences I've ever seen.
The movie makes absolutely no sense. Its underlying mythology is a hodgepodge of inconsistencies that pose the question: Since when did dumb entertainment have to be this dumb?
Too much worn-out shtick, too little detail and way too little Dave Barry.
The grandest spectacle since David Lean hung up his light meter.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Lovers of Waugh should be generally satisfied by the clever wordplay, inventive madcap situations, and, most of all, by the profoundly conservative message that the frivolous society elites sober up only when confronted with a disaster.
The emotions evoked by this Bridges are in a minor key compared to the book, but they are honestly earned.
Really, there will be no reason for anyone to make a comic-book movie ever again. Miller and Rodriguez have pushed the form as far as it can possibly go.
Anyone familiar with Rudyard Kipling's stories will be forgiven for spending the first half of Rudyard Kipling's Jungle Book squirming with outrage and confusion.
This setup is ludicrous, but actually it's the most credible thing in this whole sorry, dishonest film.
As Lecter, Anthony Hopkins gives an astounding performance -- eery, menacing, creepy, believable.
The special effects are as spectacular as anything in Star Trek, but Howard shows wise restraint in not inflating the drama and tension inherent in the true story.
It would be impossible for any director to jam that much story into a 2 hour and 18 minute picture, but the elisions favored by Yates and screenwriter Michael Goldenberg are particularly unfortunate.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Misery should be a big hit. It deserves to be.

An impossible-to-follow story crammed full of cursed women, wily bloodsuckers, Highlander-style warriors, vortexes of crows, incoherent fight scenes, and more music-video-inspired action than any one movie can comfortably contain.
As Harry, Ron and Hermione enter the awkward stage, the young people portraying them -- Daniel Radcliffe, Rupert Grint, Emma Watson -- grow ever more confident as professional actors.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The heart and soul of Foer's novel are sacrificed in the process. By trucking in broad Holocaust clichés, Schreiber repudiates his more nuanced source material.
The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy does prove there's nothing more painful than antic comedy that isn't really funny.
movie_title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (2005)

movie_review_blurb: For those who love the fantasy genre known as sword and sorcery -- and I count myself in their number -- sitting through the movie version of Eragon will suck the will to live right out of you.
The brow may be low, but it's perfectly manicured: Grade A production values abound, as does superior kung fu choreography.

It's no Rosemary's Baby, but for teens looking for a quick fix on All Hallow's Day, it will do.
With luscious cinematography and awe-inspiring humanity, 10 Questions for the Dalai Lama is one of the most electrifying documentaries to be released this year.

movie_title: The Keeper: The Legend of Omar Khayyam (2005)

Grandma's Boy isn't just a movie, it's a weapon of mass destruction. Audiences across the country should run for cover.

An earnest attempt to bring social realities to the forefront amidst an onslaught of patriotic hypocrisies, Luk'Luk'I does not fully coalesce.
Faces Places is a wonderful film overall. But it is equally a refreshing counterpoint to the number of films about health, disability, and death that lack a tangible sense of understanding.
[Sebastian] Lelio's film isn't perfect, but through [Daniela] Vega's presence, it does its best to give full cinematic agency to a woman traditionally marginalized.
The Breadwinner offers no respect or agency to real women; it's almost as if Twomey et al were consciously trying to set feminist postcolonial theory back by 20 years.
While The Time of Their Lives has its charm, the lack of kindness between its characters makes it a less than successful road trip film.
Rather than engaging with the genre in a meaningful way, [Guillermo] del Toro's film is boring, broad, and unoriginal, without any magic or charm.
Fast-paced, funny, and sweet, The Royal Hibiscus Hotel proves that playing within genre doesn't have to result in a mediocre film.
The end product is heartfelt yet complex, a story which is refreshing in its simultaneous narrative simplicity and psychological depth, but unfortunately it is just not very well made.
While Aronofsky's artistry is at an all-time-low, it's his misogyny that makes the film abhorrent.
The last moments of the film greatly diminish Mary Shelley's subversive critique.

. . .when a film centres its plot around a radicalised socio-political problem but still focuses almost exclusively on white protagonists, its ability to provide an in-depth look at these issues is further diminished.
Though Ryoo excels at both action narrative and harrowing history, the combination of the two feels strained.
Perhaps a cliché'd premise, but director Malcom D. Lee's Girls Trip manages to work with the well-worn narrative to create something fresh and fun.
From the Land of the Moon's greatest crime is how boring it is.
movie_title: From the Land of the Moon (Mal de pierres) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: [Maggie] Betts might have made a great miniseries; instead, her film, while skillful, ultimately feels stilted.

Choosing to ignore abuse, and taking away Anne's voice and agency in order to give a fuller view to Hazanavicius' beloved, Le Redoutable becomes much worse than a simple empty pastiche, verging into its own misogyny.
Beautiful, intelligent, and sensitive.
Sweetly reverential and irresistibly eager, Ramen Heads is a heartfelt love-letter to ramen that can teach the world the joy of this dish.

[Warwick] Thornton is exceptionally skilled at intertwining genre, formal innovation, and political revisionism; what finally undermines Sweet Country is that his skill does not extend to more fully depicting Aboriginal women.
Though From Hollywood to Rose has promise, this seems to be largely found in Annenberg's performance within an otherwise clunky, unenjoyable film.
... an unsatisfactory psychodrama presented with a smirk.
Presenting itself as a balanced satire of everyone, Östlund's "I hate all people equally" take is never satisfying.
It's only an empty reflection on the abuse of power, which is just as focused on CK's self-proclaimed stature as a great comedian as it is about his regret for how his actions make him feel.
With an objectivity, which is too cold, and a disjointed style, The Quiet Zone does little to make its subject matter engaging.
A compelling film on the phenomenon, Hobbyhorse Revolution celebrates its subject matter with enthusiasm, resulting in a doc which is both deeply moving and endlessly amusing.
The Ritual misses the mark: working in a longer format, [David Bruckner] comes up with a confused and unsustainable tangle of typical horror tropes.
Gorgeously shot and with great emotional depth, Life to Come is a satisfying and intense experience.
movie_title: Life to Come (La vie à venir) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: While an overall beautiful and intelligent film, the humor, unfortunately, is in poor taste.
movie_title: A Skin So Soft (Ta peau si lisse) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Do Donkeys Act is a remarkable work of anti-anthropocentrism, subverting human presumptions and power to glorify donkeys in a unique way.
With absorbing narrative variety paired with great aesthetic unity, Maison du Bonheur reverentially depicts the significance of a feminine legacy.
Never didactic, but never losing the importance of politics, Les Vies de Thérèse depicts death with vitality.
Spettacolo is a charming film, aided greatly by the warm, rustic village in which it is set, as well as the passion of the people who put on their play.
Not content with a simple erasure of colonial violence under the veil of a feel-good prestige pic, Stephen Frears opts for full-on degradation in his latest film Victoria & Abdul.
... paired with its lack of nuance in characters necessitating complexity, the film moves from formally boring to potentially offensive and absurd.

ABC's remake of the 1987 romantic drama Dirty Dancing is, well...not good. If it were a Taco Bell sauce packet or a chicken wing flavor, it would be mild. Nobody wants to watch a movie called Mild Dancing.
The breakout film ... is part fable, part action flick and part lovable animal drama.

A family-friendly version of The Rocky Horror Picture Show isn't bad. Fox is modernizing a cult classic for a new generation, full of quirky, lovable characters plucked from a far-off planet here to tell you, Don't Dream It, Be It.
movie_title: The Rocky Horror Picture Show: Let's Do the Time Warp Again (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Like other documentaries, it covers Diana's challenging life in the spotlight and behind the royal curtain with Prince Charles. But it also delves into new conspiracy theories surrounding her tragic death.
It's a bit of a mess. A tense, sometimes fun mashup of classic sci-fi, but often overwhelmed by absurdity and chaos.
It provides a heartbreaking, yet insightful glimpse at who Diana was when she wasn't a beloved princess.
movie_title: Diana, Our Mother: Her Life and Legacy (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Hannes Holm's Swedish comedy drama beautifully explores the life of the neighbourhood's resident old grump.
movie_title: A Man Called Ove (En man som heter Ove) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Kerem Sanga's teen romantic drama, First Girl I Loved is a beautiful portrayal of the joys but especially the fears that come with love when it takes an unconventional form.
That's what makes the film so endearing - it captures that strange relationship between film subject and filmmaker, something that is carefully hidden in most documentaries.
Overall, The Collaborator is the type of film that rewards repeated viewings.
An odd mix of blatantly comedic moments and strangely serious scenes, Why Stop Now finds itself stranded on an odd middle ground between comedy and drama.
Anyone who is interested in the history of film technology and cinema can certainly take something away from Side by Side, even if it is just learning the opinion of Robert Rodriguez or Danny Boyle.
This is a film that doesn't stick with any genre, but instead clumsily navigates between three, ultimately leaving the viewer feeling shortchanged in every area.
By the end, we realize that the 10,000 kilometers have nothing to do with the physical distance between the two lovers and everything to do with the emotional gap that is created in their lives.
Getting a film like The Black Tulip filmed, produced and out into the public is an impressive feat -- it's just a shame the effort didn't yield a better film.
By the film's conclusion, you can't not be in love with this man, and, of course, his pictures.
You'll spend most of the film rolling your eyes and wishing it lived up to its varied cast.
Subtle yet striking, this is a film that is filled with the power of exquisitely executed storytelling.
It is time to let this series rest in peace, or at the very least, spend the rest of its doomed, immortal days sinking to the bottom of the ocean.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It probably won't restore your faith in studio animation. But it may make you laugh.
The film feels fitting for the final work of Stanton, and one, I would imagine, he would feel is a superb punctuation mark to a remarkable career.

With the exception of Buster Moon's best friend, a sheep named Eddie and his once-famous theater star grandmother, Nana, every other character in this grand charade is a stereotype, and in the worst way possible.
The unremitting jokes and insults between blacks and whites, gays and straights, might make the hair on your head (and arms) press and curl from all of the crass and overdone sass.
Gives you a sympathetic understanding of what's going on in Tibet, it may be one-sided, but it's effective and interesting.
movie_title: Tibet: Cry of the Snow Lion (2003)

movie_review_blurb: It's hard to get excited about watching a real estate deal go down, even if it is with a bunch of ghosts.
There are plenty of movies out there that deserve to be re-released for a whole new generation of moviegoers to enjoy - this is not one of them.
A definite tearjerker, but it's one of those feel-good cry movies where you leave the theatre with a smile even while you're wiping away those last salty tears.
The Missing has the look but not the feel of a terrific movie.
With this much intrigue and planning, passion and conviction, political and religious controversy, this story should have been riveting, but it's not.
A nice mix of science-fiction and action-adventure with a little romance thrown in.
Honey, there's just too much plot getting in the way of the dancing.
When a movie is working for me, the story engages me and I don't sit there trying to figure out what is going to happen next. Most of the time, this works.
Doesn't deserve all the hype it's getting, but kudos for the battle scenes, the cinematography, the music, the costumes, the sets, and some incredible moments.
It's a paint-by-numbers movie in a Van Gogh world.
Oh Nutcracker, Nutcracker - give me a break. Fans of the ballet are going to very disappointed by this.
This is a thought-provoking movie that will have you taking sides after the credits roll. It's set back in the 40's, but the story has relevance today.
It's funny, heartfelt, and has something to give - entertainment.
A one-joke movie - pretty tame for a Farrelly brothers' movie with none of the usual gross-out humor and more attempts at a heartfelt story.
The Embalmer is a movie that will keep fresh on your mind for a few days but probably won't be preserved in your memory for all time.
This sounds like a gloomy subject with gloomy music, but it's not a gloomy movie. It's engaging and has a very satisfying ending.
The final chapter has more emotion and expands on the character development, not just the action. It is a fitting end for our travelers.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Billy Bob is not just Bad Santa, he's really bad, despicably, horribly rotten Santa - and he's so good at it you can't help laughing.
It's funny, inspirational, and entertaining - there's never been a more empowering 'girlie' calendar .
Just because something is degrading and disturbing, doesn't mean it's art. This dog doesn't deserve a day.
A bittersweet family story with a great deal of warmth and humor.
Mediocre melodrama - if you take away all the talk about incest, rape and murder there would be about ten minutes of door-to-door campaigning and a couple of dinner parties.
The Cat In The Hat might make some money, until folks find out it's not very funny.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' The Cat in the Hat (2003)

movie_review_blurb: In The Cut doesn't make the cut when it comes to the list of must-see Meg Ryan movies.
For the select audience that likes The Rocky Horror Picture Show and just wishes that it had more of a family story and less singing.
Vile characters plus a bad script doesn't add up to girls just having fun - it's more like you've been drugged and raped without the fun part.
You will either buy into the 'big surprise' or you'll be left thinking 'that's totally unbelievable'. We split down the middle on this one.
This is such a wonderful film - you'll want seconds!

This story is like the shot of the passing train that keeps repeating - it's loud, but it's not going anywhere, and the moment that it's gone, you forget you ever saw it.
It succeeds in generating discussion, but leaves you with a distasteful feeling. If you ignore the content and look merely at the quality of the film, it's lacking in focus.
Trying to adapt a lengthy period novel is always a bit ambitious and you end up skimming the surface of the story - visually, it's stunning but a bit heavy on the melodrama.
A cheesy romance novel with some artsy editing.
Climb aboard this train, it's an entertaining ride... Some of these musicians may be gone, but they won't be forgotten as long as footage like this exists.
This L.A. story is more like a straight to video kind of movie than one to rush out and see on the big screen.
An eye-opening look inside television news. The big lesson seems to be - don't believe everything you see on television (and probably only half of what you see at the movies).
movie_title: Outfoxed: Rupert Murdoch's War on Journalism (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Once the action starts, you can forget about character development, but by then - who cares. You won't get big surprises in the outcome, but it's still entertaining.
I liked the first movie, but please, let the game be over before it gets any stupider.
Oshri Cohen has such a gentle way about him - it works well for a character that would gladly be the caregiver for the world.
It's funny, fast-paced, and sharp - as entertaining in English as it was in Spanish.
It's a shame, because this could have been one of those little movies that made you feel so much for a young girl's struggle to find her place - this didn't.
This is not a great movie, but it has some nice moments. It shows Goth kids need love too.
It has some rough spots - but the more you think about this movie, the more you care about these characters.
There is a reason everyone is calling this The Osama Witch Project - it's pretty hard to swallow this one - no matter how 'true'.
In the mood to contemplate life, the universe, and everything? It will either make you think profound thoughts or make your brain hurt trying to grasp what they're saying.
movie_title: What the Bleep Do We Know!? (2004)

movie_review_blurb: It takes Vincent Gallo an hour to drive across America (it's seems much longer)... all the way you feel like a kid trapped in the backseat wondering, 'Aren't we there, yet?'
A fascinating discussion about something that we take for granted, often amusing, and enlightening.
A wartime drama that's more about the drama than about the war - you keep thinking you know where the story's going, but it keeps surprising you by taking a different turn.
It's a sweet story, but there's a melancholy feel to this film that sticks with you after you leave the theatre.
I enjoyed the first 90 minutes and was ready to give this a recommend, but the last 30 minutes sent the movie straight to hell for me.
If you're entertained by the toy where 'The cow goes -- Moo,' you'll get a kick out of this movie. Otherwise, wait 'til the cows come home -- on video.
It's a 'chick-flick training film' for all the young girls who want to grow up with romantic comedies.
Walking Tall doesn't measure up. Hopefully, next time The Rock will pick a role that stretches more than his biceps.
Chapter 10, in which we realize we just sat watching a movie for 3 hours that's a little pretentious but didn't really mind - that says something.
Interesting mix of violence, humor, and touching little moments about love and the lengths people will go to get it.
It's fascinating to watch these two young men start down the same path and end up in such totally different circumstances... also to see our country from their point of view.
Color me amused and delighted.

I'll bet you can't figure out how this is going to end... it has moments of inspired genius but it's inconsistent.

An enchanting little story that will make you smile.
I wish I could remember The Alamo for being a great movie, but I'll have to settle for remembering when I saw it.
A recycled, unfunny, dumbed-down version of a really good movie - maybe a dose of that nitrous oxide would have helped .
An 83-minute rock block of interconnected music videos... it feels like a giant marketing ploy to sell more albums.

Less action, more story - all Tarantino.
Rip off? We say who cares - it makes you laugh, you'll want to sing along - and in the perfect world you would be able to eat dinner while you watch.
It's not a punishment to sit through this movie (well, it might be to some people who hate comic-book action films), but it's not quite the reward it could be.
A beautifully sad, heartwarming family drama.
About the only thing you get out of this film is the fact that everything can be resolved over a good cup of tea.
The movie goes back and forth between being melodramatic and genuinely moving
This movie is a little raunchy with lots of off-color humor that's bound to offend somebody. It's all done with... not exactly good taste, but in the spirit of good fun.
While it's clear that this movie is trying to making a general anti-war statement, the story elements don't add up to a big picture about anything in particular.
I love your other work - this one I'm not so crazy about.
A horse is a horse, but Hidalgo is a legend. The movie almost lives up to his name. It's just too much of the same thing, it becomes a test of endurance for the audience.
If you're curious about fashion, it's okay. If sitting through two documentaries about fashion sounds as exciting as, well watching people sew on buttons, skip it.
movie_title: Yves St. Laurent: His Life and Times (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Somebody must have used a mind-control device to convince people this was a movie worth making.
What makes this movie work is the smart script and the outstanding cast that gives these characters depth.
It's a bit sparse for Mamet and this talented acting ensemble...but I was still entertained by the action and Val Kilmer's relentless pursuit.
If you think the premise is silly, wait until you hear the dialog that goes along with it...hilariously campy.

Iceland may be cold, but the people are sure friendly enough (most of the time). This group certainly made me smile.
It's an out-of-body experience that you'll find hard to erase from your memory.
movie_title: Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A good script without any of that banal horror-movie dialog that makes you cringe, a cast that can act, and zombies that are scary and quick without being robotic.
It isn't as bad as it could be or as good as it should be - I would wait to see this on video.
I was a little disappointed in the amount of scientific information divulged, but there is no denying the excitement of flying along with the thrill-seekers. It's a rush.
The story is an interesting one, so I wanted to like this. I guess with three movies on the screen, I must have been watching the wrong one.
First you're laughing, then you're crying, and you leave with a smile and a strong desire to do something nice for your mother.
This understated and delightful little film will grab you from the silly opening to the bittersweet end.
It almost works as a nice little film, but it's not the kind of story we want from Kevin Smith.
It has all the elements of a classic Coen comedy - the more times you see it the funnier it becomes.
Completely forgettable (at least, I'm trying to forget it).
Zoinks! It's a rare case of a sequel being better than the original. Maybe by the time they get around to Scooby-Doo 3, they'll get it right.

Heath Ledger makes this good guy gone bad seem worthy of his legendary status - he makes it easy to root for the outlaws.

movie_title: My Mother Likes Women (A mi madre le gustan las mujeres) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: All fluff and no substance, and even though it's nice fluff (pretty pictures and nice tribal music), the message is so convoluted it doesn't even know what it's trying to say.
Isabelle Adjani owns this movie... her every mannerism screams diva. It's a juicy role and she plays it for all it's worth.
I don't think I would want to fly the big purple plane sitting on spinners, but it would be cool as the in-flight movie.
A funny and interesting look at independent filmmaking - no matter what color. It's hard to do the movie justice - it's plays much better than it sounds.
Disturbing and visually compelling at the same time. This movie leaves a lasting impression.
They did manage to achieve the near-impossible: to show all that coffee drinking without a single Starbucks, but that certainly doesn't qualify as entertainment.
This movie sat on the shelf for years over a distribution dispute - they should have let it slip away quietly.
What we found is a bleak, but interesting look into a world where the line is blurred between good people and bad. Judith Ivey's performance is the real jewel of the film.
The best Harry Potter adaptation so far... more emotional, scarier, and demands more from the actors portraying the young wizards, but they all deliver.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: In the end, you may not know Ray Johnson any better than his friends - you know stories, but not what motivated him to do what he did... Still, an interesting portrait.
If the intention is to transport the audience to a world we've never seen, mission accomplished. You'll either find it extremely creative or an insufferable bore.
movie_title: The Saddest Music in the World (2004)

movie_review_blurb: They leave the ending wide open for the next episode in the chronicle of Riddick. We can only hope that Vin decides to save the universe... from another bad movie.
This is one cat they need to put back in the bag.
If this movie was a Stepford Wife, it would be pre-procedure - where the flaws are visible if you compare them to the other wives.
An interesting story about a fascinating man and his struggling nation.

The second act is a bit too ordinary, but the smart satiric first half saves this from being drab and makes it worth checking out.
Seeing this movie is like being seasick on your cruise to the Bahamas - you're going to see some cool things, but it's an adventure without a lot of laughs.
If you only see one movie about dodgeball this summer - make sure it's this one! They take this silly game to a whole new level of silly - and it works.

For all its flaws, it's still pretty effective, thanks to Scott Speedman and James Marsden.

You don't have to be 13 or 30 to have fun with this entertaining escape.
There is nothing to overcome (no way to stop the storm) - the big payoff is to do nothing but wait it out. Where's the fun in that.
Fine performances, but it feels like they are being reined in to keep their emotional distance - from each other and from the audience. Still... it can be devastating.
A coming of age story with some very interesting twists. The film moves a little slowly but it does engage you.
movie_title: I'm Not Scared (Io non ho paura) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Good performances, good story, but with stylistic overload... It should be called Man On Fire Who Won't Be Deterred By Gunshots Or Bad Direction.
There are a couple of laughs, but it would take a lot of VaPOOrize to get all the crap out of this movie.
The only thing that's a godsend about this movie is when the closing credits finally start rolling.

These girls make the animals in Africa look like the belong in a petting zoo - props to Tina Fey for writing a script that's smarter than your usual teenage fare.

I cheated during this movie - by thinking about other films I liked better.

Valentín makes you feel like you do when you get a note from an old friend just to say hey.
Gorgeous men in skirts... it should be better but I didn't fall for that Trojan horse bit - where they disguise an average script by surrounding it with talented actors.
A fascinating movie in its own right, more relevant because of today's world situation.
movie_title: The Battle of Algiers (La Battaglia di Algeri) (1967)

movie_review_blurb: Entertaining in a naked real world, train-wreck kind of way... the pranks are often funny, never actually cruel, but at the same time, there's something sad about these games.

movie_title: What to Do in Case of Fire (Was tun, wenn's brennt?) (2001)

Required viewing for fans of the band, but I didn't know anything about Wilco and I was amused and entertained by their story.

Ze movie starts out so funny, then she is nothing.

movie_review_blurb: They do a good job of painting this family dynamic for the audience but they tried to squeeze too many elements into the film.

This is one bizarre movie, but I like it anyway.

Me no lika da accents so good, but I thoroughly enjoyed the love story. Scott Baio is turning in some delightful work on indie projects.
The performances of the four main actresses bring their characters to life. A little melodramatic, but with enough hope to keep you engaged.
Yo, it's The Days Of Our Lives meets Electric Boogaloo.
Not a great movie, but it was entertaining.

Ok, I saw the whole 'tape' and when I got home my phone was ringing and this creepy little girl told me if I didn't give the movie a good review, I would be dead in 7 days. It wasn't too bad!!!

This movie may not keep you up at night, but it will keep you guessing until the very end.

There is pathos in funerals, family issues, and loneliness but it helps the audience connect with the characters and makes them more real - they manage to find laughter even in the darkest of situations.

Witty dialog between realistic characters showing honest emotions. It's touching and tender and proves that even in sorrow you can find humor. Like blended shades of lipstick, these components combine into one terrific story with lots of laughs.

The Ya-Ya's have many secrets and one is - the books are better. Translating complex characters from novels to the big screen is an impossible task but they are true to the essence of what it is to be Ya-Ya.
movie_title: Divine Secrets of the Ya-Ya Sisterhood (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Check your brain and your secret agent decoder ring at the door because you don't want to think too much about what's going on. The movie does has some entertainment value - how much depends on how well you like Chris Rock.
A beautiful movie about everyday people that seem so real they could be your neighbors. It's like being invited round to the pub for a couple of pints with some mates.

I wanted a great movie or something like that (and didn't quite get it). But if you're looking for a movie to watch on a rainy day when you want to skip work and stay home in bed with someone you love, it's not bad.
This is a gorgeous film - vivid with color, music and life. Delight your senses and crash this wedding!

There is so little love in this movie - it's really depressing. It's hard to buy into the rapid transformation that Billy Bob Thornton's character makes. You either believe the chemistry between the two actors, or you don't - I didn't.

There are several images that will haunt you after the movie is over. Not an easy film to watch, but worth the effort.
