The film captures the essence of the 60's and of the sci-fi adventure movies of that time.
The effects are top-notch, the military equipment they use is pretty amazing, and the story is intense, but as a fan of the book I was a little disappointed.
If you ignore the cheesy dialog and the political mumbo-jumbo, the power of the force has returned to the franchise.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones (2002)

movie_review_blurb: We want the funk - and this movie's got it.
Your spirit will soar with this movie, no matter how young or old you are.
Robin Tunney tackles a role that goes from romantic comedy to thriller to race-against-time action - all set to the beat of an 80's soundtrack.
What a great way to spend 4 units of your day.
A charming, modern-day fairy tale - tucked in the frames are wonderful little surprises like eating strawberries from your fingers and clouds that look like bunnies.
If they broke out into elaborate choreography, singing and finger snapping it might have held my attention, but as it stands I kept looking for the last exit from Brooklyn.

Take away everything that was original about BLADE, add some exploding vampires, bad acting, and vampire night at the WWF - you get BLADE II, a knock-off, rip-off waste of film, released to suck the blood (and money) out of audiences everywhere.
A beautiful mind, a beautiful heart - a beautiful movie.
Terrific performances, great to look at, and funny. A little uneven to be the cat's meow, but it's good enough to be the purr.
With a cast like this I expected much more - like to be entertained. I was hoping that they would just kill each other so I could get in my car and go home.
Beautiful photography. Too bad the film is like a custom car up on blocks - nice to look at but it doesn't go anywhere.
Quirky and understated office comedy with Crispin Glover as the guy who would prefer not to work, but likes to hang around.
It may be historically accurate, but there's nothing interesting about this lady, this duke, or this movie.
Rainy days and movies about the disintegration of families always get me down.
There are some dazzling water effects, but there's not enough to like about the movie to recommend it.
Poetry in motion captured on film. While it can be a bit repetitive, overall it's an entertaining and informative documentary.
Eric Schweig and Graham Greene both exude an air of dignity that's perfect for the proud warrior that still lingers in the souls of these characters.
The movie starts with a legend and ends with a story that is so far-fetched it would be impossible to believe if it weren't true. This is the stuff that Disney movies are made of.
Don't judge this one too soon - it's a dark, gritty story but it takes off in totally unexpected directions and keeps on going.
The additional storyline is interesting and entertaining, but it doesn't have the same magical quality as the beginning of the story. I like the new footage and still love the old stuff.
If you thought the history of Napoleon was boring, the movie version certainly livens things up.
If this sounds a lot like one of those angst-ridden teen movies: My Trip To New York With My Dying Girlfriend, that's because it is one of those movies.
The behind the scenes series is more interesting than the resulting movie, but it's still worth taking a look.
Nijinsky says, 'I know how to suffer' and if you see this film you'll know too.
It's stupid and silly, but funnier than the original - exactly what you'd expect from a summer blockbuster.
Like Mike isn't going to make box office money that makes Michael Jordan jealous, but it has some cute moments, funny scenes, and hits the target audience (young Bow Wow fans) - with nothing but net.
Going to this movie is a little like chewing whale blubber - it's an acquired taste that takes time to enjoy, but it's worth it, even if it does take 3 hours to get through.
This is a good story that is told very well - the film has polish even at its most sinister moments.
People were cheering, but I was cheering because it was over.
If you're not fans of the adventues of Steve and Terri, you should avoid this like the dreaded King Brown snake. Personally, I'd rather watch them on the Animal Planet.
Redo the first movie, add a reality show element where everybody wears a personal cameras so not only do we get overacting, we get fuzzy video feeds and bad camera angles.
Several plotlines with familial duty, greed and desperation as the central themes with a mix of serious topics and small-town humor.
Lots of charm and likeable characters add up to a delightful movie.
These spiders can outrun a motorcycle and wrap a person in a sticky cocoon in seconds, but they fall short of being interesting or entertaining.
This is not as good as the first but it still has entertainment value and nice messages about families and friendship and adventures.
Russian sub, nuclear meltdown, Harrison Ford & Liam Neeson as dueling captains - the Cold War was a lot hotter than we thought!
Dark and disturbing, yet compelling to watch.
The first five minutes are hilarious, but some of the jokes are getting tired. Enough to make it worth a look? Yeah, baby.
How good can a movie be when it's based on an attraction at Disney World - The Country Bear Jamboree? The answer is not very good.
The problem with this film is that it lacks focus. I sympathize with the plight of these families, but the movie doesn't do a very good job conveying the issue at hand.
Lots of nice, funny, poignant moments, but it just doesn't add up to a lovely or amazing movie.

Wes Anderson and Owen Wilson have proven once again they can write smart, clever dialog. They assembled an incredibly talented cast, underscored by a great soundtrack to make this a unique movie experience.
This movie wouldn't be worth paying to see even if you had 40 billion dollars.
A tale of unrequited love and a young woman's courage to make a place for herself in a man's world, but this is much more than just 'Yentl' goes to the Middle East.
A sports movie with action that's exciting on the field and a story you care about off it.
The Iditarod lasts for days - this just felt like it did.
If you ever wanted to be an astronaut, this is the ultimate movie experience - it's informative and breathtakingly spectacular.
A thrill ride blown up to gigantic mind-blowing proportions; played out over a booming rock 'n roll soundtrack.
A movie about sex, obsession, and murder should never be boring.
This is an incredible story badly told.
The last 20 minutes are somewhat redeeming, but most of the movie is the same teenage American road-trip drek we've seen before - only this time you have to read the fart jokes
Bourne, Jason Bourne. He can scale a building like a super hero, he can out-stealth any agent, he'll get the girl. He's Super Spy!
From the first round of gunfire that shocks the audience out of their seats (literally), the war wages on...this is a powerful movie about men who discover what it means to be comrades in arms.
Ryan Gosling gives an amazing performance. It's powerful, disturbing, and terribly tragic. You cannot watch this without being affected by it.
Take a friend (invisible or real) to see this one... it's laugh out loud funny
Amazing performances from some pretty unlikable characters. Never underestimate the willfulness of a Jewish mother.
Pretend like your SAT scores are below 120 and you might not notice the flaws.
While this may not be a diamond-in-the-rough, it's certainly better than cubic zirconium - it's a likeable film that fizzles at the end.

Ruh-roh. Would I see this again for a Scooby snack? Like, uh, I don't think so.
A first-rate sci-fi, action thriller with great futuristic toys and a premise that has more substance than your average sci-fi film.
It lacks a certain polish, but it has a nice message and an interesting look.
Juwanna know what we think of this movie? It stinks. The jokes are bad, the stereotypes are tired, and the story is predictable and full of holes.
If you're part of the ever-growing audience that's looking for more in your movies than the latest TV show brought to the big screen - check this out.
movie_title: The Dangerous Lives of Altar Boys (2002)

movie_review_blurb: At two hours, this movie seems to drag on and on as the tragedies pile up. I found myself looking at my watch more than I was looking at the screen. If the town were a little more quiet, I would have taken a nap
movie_title: The Town Is Quiet (La Ville est tranquille) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: With Ang Lee as the director, you expect this to be more than just a comic book brought to the big screen - and it is.
Darker and scarier than the first (especially if you don't like spiders and snakes), but there's still humor and some whimsical magic elements that make Hogwarts such a cool place.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (2002)

movie_review_blurb: I felt sympathetic and disappointment at the same time with these priests... The end of the road is terribly sad, but the journey is never boring.
Amusing surface stuff with no depth. Or, in terms the characters can relate to - it's like 2 hours of foreplay with no payoff - it's rather nice while it lasts, but ultimately not very satisfying.
These are such empty-headed people doing trite things it's not a matter of who will be with whom, but a matter of how many people in the audience will stay through the whole movie to find out.
This is a great date movie - it's funny, sweet, and just the right amount of zaniness to keep it from being too sappy.
Some funny stuff, but the story fizzles out long before the movie does...worth a rental.

Not only does the documentary go 2 1/2 miles down to the wreckage of the Titanic, they also take us back in time - by superimposing images over the wreckage we get a glimpse of what the Titanic and the people on board might have been like.
A darker, French version of Ocean's 11, without the stars and without the subtitles.
Nobody expects too much depth in an action movie based on a comic book series, but we would like a little fun with the story - and that's hard when the characters don't seem to be having any.
There's a lot of fluff in this comedy, but it's mostly harmless fluff. Yes, there are times that the women seem objectified, but they also have moments of empowerment to balance the scales.
Funny is what these guys do best, with 'throwaway lines' with more punch than many scripted comedies could ever hope to have.
The story bogs down in several places and is almost too ambitious for a cartoon...but fans of the television show should still be thrilled.
movie_title: Cowboy Bebop: The Movie (Kaubôi Bibappu: Tengoku no Tobira) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: This is not like the cotton-candy stories that are traditionally served up as kids' fare, this story has bite. For anybody 9-12, this will be a big hit, for everybody else, it's not bad.

Starts out like an Asian-American version of The Breakfast Club, but quickly turns more towards Boyz N The Hood...shows what can happen when rich kids at private school and smart kids at public school get bored.
A visual experience not to be missed.
There are a lot of pros about the cons in this film.
If you find yourself wishing somebody would just hurry up and kill the rest of guests and get it over with, you're probably not alone.
The situations are absurd and melodramatic, the dialog is not believable, and the acting is over-the-top (apparently talent doesn't run in the family - at least not to the third generation).
Will you go ape over this movie? Well, it probably won't have you swinging from the trees hooting it's praises, but it's definitely worth taking a look.
Campbell Scott directs with a light touch, flowing from one scene to the next with an ease that never interferes, but manages to capture the magic of every moment.
A dark, compelling story with a segment that doesn't quite fit the period piece, but the costumes, make-up, and overall tone brings the dark ages to life.

It's da shiznit.

Something is rotten in the state of Denmark California. If this were a party, the crowd would clear out early because it's a bust.
What a girl wants may be to dance with her daddy, but what this film critic wants is a shorter, better movie that's not nearly so tedious.
If a picture was ever worth 1000 words, this is it (but I doubt there are 1000 words of dialog here) - minimalist filmmaking at its best.
The synopsis sounds melodramatic (which it is), but it's also funny, sweet, and surprisingly engaging.
I-n-t-e-r-e-s-t-i-n-g look behind the scenes of an American tradition. If you ever wondered how much work goes into winning a National Spelling Bee, now you'll know.
Funny moments, but few and far between...this cruise is all washed up before the ship ever leaves the harbor.
There is so much going on in this movie: first-love, painful adolescent moments, family drama [and comedy], -- and every aspect of it works.
I liked the premise and the basic storyline, it's a great mix of action and comedy, but it lacks focus.

This is a beautiful and powerful film that is an incredible memorial to all the heroes from 9/11...they paint a picture with words that is so clear you really have a sense of these men you never see.
Mind-numbing visuals...that left me with the incredible need to take a shower and brush my teeth.

It's hard to sit and listen to these people that are in their 50's speaking fondly of the good ole days when they had sex and drug parties and blew up stuff (yes, this is a huge exaggeration, but that's it in a nutshell - and nutty is how they sound).
Basically, this thriller has one plot twist too many - the last is like a sucker punch from left field. Up until the final zinger, it's compelling, non-stop action and the performances are terrific.
Four 'good ole boys' that all make me laugh - that doesn't mean I'm a redneck, but I will admit to knowing some personally.
movie_title: Blue Collar Comedy Tour: The Movie (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The movie has tons of charm and a light upbeat feeling. It's a coming-of-age story and a family story, mixed in with lots of soccer and one terrific wedding.
Once they bore into the earth, it's like being inside a multi-colored lava lamp for 2 hours.
The hills are alive with the sound of rock and roll, and the people of Laurel Canyon are learning new songs to live by.

This is the best that Chris Rock and Bernie Mac could come up with? In the words of Gilliam's campaign - 'That ain't right'.

Viva Javier Bardem!
If I was a kid, I'd want to hang out at Daddy Day Care and I'd probably recommend this movie, but my potty training days are behind me so I'm not quite there.

This fishing village is one cold, harsh, and colorless place - just like the people who live there.
Fine performances in a family melodrama that doesn't quite stand out as particularly special.
movie_title: Under the Skin of the City (Zir-e Poust-e Shahr) (2003)

When they started singing 'Should I Stay Or Should I Go' - we should have left.
This movie doesn't exactly soar to never-before-reached heights, but it gets off the ground and sure beats sitting in the airport for two hours.
There are moments that are brilliant, but I wouldn't put this film in the list of film noir classics.
To use Liam's words, it's f-ing brilliant.
Like a great piece of music played by an brilliant orchestra where everybody gives 110% to their part and it all comes together to make magic.
Not the perfect crime, but not a bad movie.

movie_title: The Man on the Train (L'homme du train) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Doesn't garner the sympathy you would expect (maybe because the troubled youth come across as more mouthy than troubled)...Extreme Dazed and Sedated

movie_title: Mondays in the Sun (Los Lunes al sol) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: This movie can be watched and appreciated on many levels - but the bottom line is the movie is really a hyper-realistic, 2 1/2 hour, 160 million dollar trailer for The Matrix Revolutions. That being said, it's a pretty darn cool trailer.
I'm not totally down with Down With Love, but it's easy entertainment and an alternative for the non-Matrix crowd.

movie_review_blurb: Terrific casting and solid execution give all three stories life.

movie_title: Akai Hashi No Shita Noo Nurui Mizu (2002)

movie_review_blurb: As impossible as it might seem, The Two Towers is even bigger in scope than The Fellowship.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Painfully real moments are mixed with humorous, light-hearted bits - whenever the movie needs a pick-me-up, all Schmidt has to say is two words - Dear Ndugu.

This is a charming fantasy, that would still be entertaining after you've seen it a few times - once on the big screen and then later at home with some good Chinese take out.

A stylish, good-looking movie (much like Leonardo Sbaraglia).

Movies like this are what make it so fun to go to the cinema.
In a perfect world you'd have pancakes every morning and every movie would be a 5. This is the real world and the movie is a 3.5
Like waiting for a New York cab - be patient, when it finally comes around, it's a wild ride.
What a great way to end a year of movies - on a high note, a low note, and all that jazz!
Sad, yet interesting.
movie_title: Comment j'ai tué mon père (My Father and I) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: The Lion King is a royal treat.
The movie is not as compelling as the story it's trying to tell, but it has some very powerful moments.
This has to be one of the most bizarre love stories ever to be filmed, not since Nine 1/2 Weeks has anybody done this much pampering for his 'girlfriend'.
This is such a high-energy movie where the drumming and the marching are so excellent, who cares if the story's a little weak.
Roman Polanski recreates this story with a great deal of passion.
A sweet film about two gentle souls - there is a genuine caring between them that feels like watching old friends.
The premise is overshadowed by the uberviolence of the Clericks as this becomes just another kung-fu sci-fi movie with silly action sequences.
The restoration of this 1946 film is a beauty, but I'm just not sure this beast of a movie is worth the trouble.
movie_title: Beauty and The Beast (La Belle et la bête) (1946)

movie_review_blurb: Visually this is dazzling which makes the harshness of the discrimination (race, gender and sexual preference) stand out even more. A pretty box filled with ugliness. Outstanding performances, but the ending is weak.

Roger's totally sleazy, yet still manages to come off smart, funny and likeable, so does the movie.

An interesting premise that's well executed (no pun intended) and works more often than not. The best part about this film is that it takes you places you have no idea you're going to go.
This documentary made me laugh, made me cry, and I had to bite my tongue to keep from singing along. It's informative, entertaining, and hard not to love.
movie_title: Standing in the Shadows of Motown (2002)

movie_review_blurb: It's a fun adventure movie for kids (of all ages) that like adventure.

Extreme Oops - oops, ops, no matter how you spell it, it's still a mistake to go see it.
We split on this one, but both agree it was pretty to watch.

We split on this one. It's either delightful or terribly overacted - you decide.

A bit of a downer and a little over-dramatic at times, but this is a beautiful film for people who like their romances to have that French realism.
movie_title: Les enfants du siècle (The Children of the Century) (1999)

An unoriginal, uninspired good cop/bad cop movie with one-dimensional characters.

Kevin Spacey and Laura Linney turn in fine performances.
God is great, the movie's not.
movie_title: God Is Great and I'm Not (2002)

movie_review_blurb: There are some unfunny gaps and the ending is a little weak, but if you check your brain at the door and turn off your political correctness sensibility, you might just enjoy this.
Incredible performances in a sleep-inducing mind-trip.
The movie jumps from romantic comedy to psychological thriller to mystery in a 'heartbeat'...I was engrossed every step of the way.
movie_title: He Loves Me, He Loves Me Not (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Interesting and entertaining documentary that proves dreams don't always come true.

Plot?...it's the means to get these guys together so they can fight, blow stuff up, compare testosterone levels, have car chases, some comic relief, and a little male-bonding...it delivers the goods.
This movie is not without problems, but when it's on, it's funny.
This may be a 'war' movie that has more appeal to women because it's not just about the battles, it's about the people caught in the struggle.

The adults may have some problems getting excited about this movie, but it's entertaining for the kids.
The military have a term for something this messed up - FUBAR. In this case it also means: Foul and Utterly Blantant Action Ripoff.

movie_review_blurb: [An] unpredictably graceful film (given its sometimes ugly material).
The film is lengthy -- almost three hours -- and without much plot, but I sat rapt for every minute.

In the Shadow of Women is a trifle: pretty, but lacking any substance.
As a coming-of-age tale, Liza, Liza, Skies Are Grey is inoffensive, as a reminiscence of the Cold War years, it's inert, as a whole it's completely inconsequential.
Fallen is It's nothing but a weaker version of everything that has come before it, the mythos is convoluted and ultimately uninteresting, the CGI is ropey at best.
The Wilde Wedding is not very good. There are too many characters, which leaves no room for character development, or any meaningful arcs.
Ava impresses with its sensitivity and visuals, and overall, remains an astonishingly accomplished debut.
Thirst Street deserves your attention thanks to its vividly assured visuals.
For ninety percent of its runtime, Elizabeth Blue is an affecting, heartfelt look at living with schizophrenia.
Abundant Acreage Available may be a small film, but it's a deep and rich one, worthy of your full attention.
Literally, Right Before Aaron is full of laughter and romance, with an impressively star-studded cast. Its recognition of the pain of enduring will keep it stuck in your head for days.
Lambert doesn't shy away from adding layers of pathos, but Brave New Jersey is essentially an uplifting romp, led by a lovely, delicate performance from Tony Hale.
Rocha weaves together a wide array of clips with a lyricism which illustrates how the individual movies made up the larger movement.
Though The Country Doctor often plods along like one of the doctor's elderly patients, the film has a stealthily endearing sweetness at its core.
Tracktown is a cutesy, generic, unfunny indie film, with an overgrown infant at its centre, and only the most surface-level interest in any of its other characters or themes.
There are so many other, better ways you could spend Footnotes' seventy-eight minutes.
There've been better and worse romcoms. Love at First Child is not a filmyou'll remember the week after you've watched it, but it's anice enough way to pass the time.
movie_title: Love at First Child (Ange et Gabrielle) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The Reagan Showis sometimes funny, sometimes frightening, and always fascinating.
The lack of an insightful screenplay, or well-drawn characters for Schwarzenegger and McNairy to work with leave Aftermath seeming empty and, frankly, dull.
The Cured has everything going for it, but ends up far less than the sum of its parts. It's a waste of a brilliant idea, a waste of some great actors, and ultimately, a waste of time.
The Student is a lively piece that grips from beginning to end. It's full of intensity, thoughtful discussion, righteous anger, and interesting, dynamic characters.
Harold And Lillian: A Hollywood Love Story is a beautiful tribute to those names that you don't know, but you should.
movie_title: Harold And Lillian: A Hollywood Love Story (2017)

movie_review_blurb: To get it as wrong as Rupture takes quite some skill.

movie_title: Robert Klein Still Can't Stop His Leg (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Although God Knows Where I Am deserves praise for bringing little-publicized issues to public attention, there doesn't seem to be enough fire here to bring change.
Rumley retreads the tired old beats that you've seen in every other below-average horror film of the last 30 years. A waste of material that other filmmakers would kill for.
I Don't Feel at Home in This World Anymore feels like the world right now: unpredictable, funny, frightening, confusing, unsettling, bizarre, and a little bit unreal.
movie_title: I don't feel at home in this world anymore. (2017)

movie_review_blurb: With enormous themes illustrated with the tiniest of creatures, the most characterful of characters, and some stunning photography, Uncertain is a phenomenal debut.
There's no spark to Road To The Well's dialogue, little sense of threat to propel the narrative forward, and the dark humour isn't ever particularly funny.
Barbet Schroeder's film presents a compellingly different take on the notorious party island.
There are a lot of great scenes in Ex Libris. And yet it is so punishingly long, by the time it is over, it's hard to feel anything but relieved.
movie_title: Ex Libris: New York Public Library (2017)

movie_review_blurb: For the most part Raymond Depardon's documentary is an engaging exploration into the lives of people at the very edge of society, filmed with warmth, humour and humanity.
Roller Dreams will make you furious, but glad that this important story is finally being told.
Princess Cyd is a low-key marvel; an elegant, warm-hearted examination of the ways that we relate to one another whilst dealing with our differences.

The beauty of the animation would have been enough to make Garden Party a worthy Oscar winner, but then to have the mystery aspect too, that slow-building sense of dread as the film approaches the inexorable conclusion, is why this a truly special work.

Their voice work, combined with some amusingly expressive animation, and of course, Dahl's peerless writing, means that aside from being just the longest of the nominees, Revolting Rhymes is also one of the very best.
It isn't as funny as Revolting Rhymes, it doesn't have the final scene kick of Garden Party, it's not as heartfelt as Dear Basketball, and it's not as creative as Negative Space.
The stop-motion gives the film a tactility lacking in some of the other shorts, and that gives the devastating final moments even more of an emotional punch.
The John Williams score is a bit too, well, John Williams, but Dear Basketball is made with deep feeling, and it really shows; you don't have to know a thing about basketball to find it touching.

Though the film is small in scope, and much more adept at comedy than romance, first-time writer-director Sophie Brooks tells her story with appealing simplicity, and Zosia Mamet's first lead performance makes you wonder why on earth it is her first.

Perfect Bid is a perfectly fine film. At seventy minutes long, it doesn't overstay its welcome, it's warmly presented, and offers up some interesting behind-the-scenes insights into one of the world's most famous game shows.
movie_title: Perfect Bid: The Contestant Who Knew Too Much (2017)

movie_review_blurb: though the grander themes will translate for audiences across the globe, Feng's Spielbergian desire to over-sentimentalise every scene means that overall, Youth is more frustrating than affecting.
24 Hours to Live is a bad movie. With a plot that shatters credulity and is packed with clichés, it's a loud, ridiculous disaster.
It's a gripping, atmospheric movie, with stellar acting and a characterful script. With a lengthier runtime (and better lighting), it would be pretty near perfect.
Between the awkward dialogue, needlessly complex form, and uninteresting story, Porto seems much longer than its seventy minutes.
It's a wonderful film; humanely acted, fiercely entertaining and commendably nuanced. It deserves a wide audience. The world would be better for it.
Rodents Of Unusual Size is a lesson in just how much a canny filmmaker can fit into a documentary that's barely an hour long.

David Heinz's excellent debut is an ardent plea for togetherness in a divided world. Aided by his leading actors, talented cinematographer, and ear-worm of a soundtrack, Joni and Elliott's journey is a privilege to share.
Whilst it has many problems, Maya Dardel is a fascinating film, if not an enjoyable one.
Twee indie movie tropes abound. If this film actually does have anything new to say, it's hard to fathom from under this sea of mumblecore conventions.
The Untamed, as a whole, is one of those films that needs to be seen to be believed. And once you've seen it, you won't forget it.
Truthful, compelling and personal, Bobbi Jene is a vital portrait of an inspiring artist.
Whilst as a piece of cinema it doesn't amount to very much, it's impossible to deny the charm and bravery of Liyana's young narrators.
There's not so much a story arc as a mess of ideas that are thrown at the screen; some stick, some don't, which means that This Is Our Land is only ever sporadically interesting.
Brawl In Cell Block 99 takes the gruesome horror and sustains it for what feels like forever. It is brutal, nauseating, unsparing... and excellent.

In Chavela, Catherine Gund and Daresha Kyi have crafted a documentary that works just as well as an introduction to the legendary ranchera singer as it does a fond remembrance for those who knew her well.
Last Flag Flying is far below the quality that Linklater is capable of.
Loving Vincent may look beautiful, but it sure is boring.
Crash Pad is a perfectly fine way to pass ninety minutes, but you'll soon forget you ever saw it.
Sitting through Journeyman was a dull and disheartening experience.
The Rider is a small film of great beauty and great resonance.
Though Call Me By Your Name overall is a little disappointing, especially after all the hype it has received, these final scenes are inarguably majestic.
The Accountant makes for a solid, yet unremarkable, action flick that can't live up to its higher aspirations.
Despite a fun premise, Keeping Up with the Joneses is a mildly entertaining comedy that's very generic.
Trolls is solid, visually-stunning entertainment for kids with a positive message, but there isn't much there for adults.
Billy Lynn's Long Halftime Walk is a well-intentioned misfire that cannot live up to its higher aspirations.
Bad Santa 2 is another late comedy sequel that fails to catch lightning in a bottle again with a poor script and weak characters.
Office Christmas Party is a decent studio comedy, but its entertaining parts do not add up to a cohesive whole.
Despite decent chemistry between the leads and a fascinating concept, Passengers is a bland, unsatisfying sci-fi story that fails to connect.
Monster Trucks is an OK kids movie that lacks most of the substance of the classic 1980s Amblin productions it tries to emulate.
Underworld: Blood Wars is a poorly-constructed slog of a sequel that fails to engage the audience in any impactful manner.
xXx: Return of Xander Cage serves up all the expected over-the-top action, but it won't win the series any new fans due to various shortcomings.
Rings is a mediocre horror sequel handicapped by poor writing that will only appeal to die hard fans of the genre and source material.
John Wick: Chapter 2 delivers plenty more of what fans want, while fleshing out the property's mythology and lore in fascinating ways.
A Cure for Wellness is a visually-stunning work, but the abundance of style adds up to an overall hollow experience that fails to connect.
Why Him? falls victim to its genre's clichés, but Cranston and Franco make for an entertaining odd couple comedic pairing.
Despite a strong performance by Emily Blunt, The Girl on the Train is a middling thriller without much to offer.
Ratchet & Clank has moments of humor, but is undercut by a generic story and thin characters that fail to leave a meaningful impact.
Snowden is a solid, yet unremarkable, portrayal of an intriguing incident that asks the audience to contemplate serious questions.
It toys with some interesting concepts, but Morgan ultimately favors generic action over developing its core ideas into something more fascinating.
Mechanic: Resurrection is a mindless B-movie with little substance of note, but those who enjoy Statham should have a fun time.
There is a timely message of tolerance and forgiveness, but Ben-Hur is a poorly-constructed historical epic that fails to leave an impact.
Sausage Party is definitely not for everyone, but it offers an amusing blend of humor and substance, providing viewers with heady food for thought.
Bad Moms deserves credit for mixing things up in the genre, but its reliance on caricatures prevents it from being as memorable as it could have been.
Star Trek Beyond is a highly entertaining summer blockbuster for fans and casual moviegoers that pays respect to the franchise legacy.
The Purge: Election Year is an OK sequel for die-hard fans of the series, but it won't win any new converts.
The Shallows serves up plenty of thrills and scares, but it prioritizes taut storytelling over character building.
It's a must-see for someone with even a passing interest in the Indiana Jones series or hopes of making their own films one day.
movie_title: Raiders!: The Story of the Greatest Fan Film Ever Made (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Despite some entertaining moments, Now You See Me 2 is largely an exercise of style over substance when it's all said and done.
Me Before You's reliance on formula prevents it from being as compelling as it could have been.
Despite fleeting moments of entertainment, The Angry Birds Movie comes across as a hollow viewing experience that doesn't have much to offer - even for kids.
Get Out smartly balances its tones to provide viewers with an entertaining and clever satire that is equal parts funny and terrifying.
Storks is an entertaining family film fueled by a series of powerful messages for everyone in the audience.
The Belko Experiment makes for a truly fascinating concept, but is dragged down by mundane execution that doesn't always engage the viewer.
Wonder is a touching tale of love and friendship, buoyed by strong performances from Jacob Tremblay and the rest of the cast.
The Boss Baby is generic animated fare, but it's bolstered by a unique visual flair and important lessons for children in the audience.
CHIPS is a generic buddy cop comedy that will leave both longtime fans and newcomers alienated with a weak story and thin characters.
Death Wish is woefully generic fare that's tonally confused in its storytelling, bland in its direction, and doesn't bring much new to the table.
Game Night is a madcap adventure packed with laughs, twists, and good performances that will keep audiences thoroughly entertained.
Early Man is technically-impressive and boasts strong visuals, but its simple story holds it back from reaching its full potential.
12 Strong works as a tribute to the real-life American heroes who lived it, but is an overall generic war film without much substance.
The Post is an expertly-crafted and compelling film brought to tantalizing life by a master director and an all-star ensemble cast.
The Greatest Showman is a disjointed, glossy, sugar-coated mess that just skates by on Jackman's natural charm and charisma.
Downsizing does the bare minimum with its out-of-the-box concept, telling a story that's dull and uninteresting in execution.
The Disaster Artist is an endearing tale of friendship and chasing your dreams that packs a surprisingly poignant punch.
Roman J. Israel, Esq. features another standout performance by Washington, but the story around him is mundane and fails to leave an impression.
Murder on the Orient Express is well-crafted entertainment whose flaws are covered up by great work from Branagh in multiple facets.
1922 is a fascinating exploration of what guilt does to a man, fueled by a strong lead performance from Jane and compelling direction.
Happy Death Day is a fun, if silly, blending of various genre tropes that is fueled by a strong lead performance from Rothe.
Winslet and Elba give it their all, but The Mountain Between Us is an absurd and forgettable affair that makes little impact with viewers.
I, Tonya is a wild and entertaining exploration of one of sport's most controversial figures, spearheaded by excellent performances from the cast.
The LEGO Ninjago Movie is an underwhelming series installment hamstrung by a thin script and weak characters that don't leave much of an impact.
Going in Style is a baffling blend of tones that ultimately plays as a harmless piece of fluff devoid of any significant stakes.
Flatliners is an unmemorable redux hampered by poor writing and a general lack of thrills that fails to capture the attention of its audience.
Free Fire is a stronger concept than film, hamstrung by poor storytelling and execution, despite the best efforts of the cast.
The Circle is bolstered by a fascinating premise and solid performances, but doesn't bring anything new to the table in regard to its discussions.
For something called Captain Underpants, there's more to it than meets the eye.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: 47 Meters Down is a decent, yet unremarkable, survival thriller that's little more than disposable summer entertainment.

Works best when Bekmambetov is let off the leash, and goes WAY over the top. Worth seeing as long as you go in with the right frame of mind.
Mostly hysterical, even if it falters a bit towards the end. A sure-fire stoner classic.
All due respect to Sam Raimi and Tobey Maguire, but this is QUITE A BIT better than any of the other Spider-Man films. Garfield and Stone are terrific.
A pretty good adaptation of an amazing book. The ending almost ruins it, but Del Toro, Travolta and even Kitsch pull it back from the brink.
Everything I hoped it would be and more...
Worth a few chuckles, but belly laughs are mostly absent. Ben Stiller's schtick is getting old.
Nice eye candy and a game cast doesn't make up for the utter lack of tension or excitement. This 2012 version of TOTAL RECALL is purely recycled, lifeless entertainment.
good, solid piece of counter-programing to a summer full of spectacle...Streep and Jones are both terrific.
It adheres pretty strictly to the BOURNE formula, but LEGACY is still a very entertaining spy thriller. Renner is shaping up to be an ace leading man.
2 DAYS IN PARIS is a really solid, accessible indie sleeper- and hopefully people will give it a chance
Disturbing in that it feels so damn real.
bigger and better than the first film...what it lacks in brains it makes up for in brawn...
A more elegant and thoughtful sci-fi film than we've gotten in many a year. The 3D is truly immersive, the scares well-earned, and the performances top-notch.
Puts the grim back in Brothers' Grimm. Overall, a very entertaining fantasy adventure, that probably owes more to GAME OF THRONES than Disney.
As a book, I'm sure COSMOPOLIS was fascinating. As a film, anchored by a dull lead, it borders on excrutiating.
A trainwreck.
Works reasonably well. Good for a few yuks. They're still a likable bunch.
Low-rent but fun eighties/nineties throwback. Guy Pearce makes a solid, sardonic hero.
It's about as good a THREE STOOGES movie as we're likely to get- but that's not very good at all.
Certainly no NOTEBOOK.
Harmless fun, with the occasional inspired gag.
Puts hair on the chest of even the most jaded action movie junkie...
Pitch-perfect chemistry between Segel and Blunt, along with a superb supporting cast makes FIVE YEAR ENGAGEMENT a strong follow-up to Apatow's BRIDESMAIDS.

Powerful, but incomplete. The focus is too narrow, and the bully side of the equation should have been examined. Only when we find some common ground between the bullies and the bullied can we begin to understand the problem.
Sure to please even the most die-hard fans, and just about everyone else.
THE DICTATOR doesn't measure up to BORAT, but is still wildly funny at times.
Terrific, low-key indie sleeper with a tinge of sci-fi.
Not quite as bad as NEW YEAR'S EVE- but still not very good. Other than good performances by Anna Kendrick and Elizabeth Banks, don't expect much.
movie_title: What to Expect When You're Expecting (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Too cool for WHAT TO EXPECT WHEN YOU'RE EXPECTING? Here's a much better date movie alternative.
Much chastened by time, Williams is an easy guy to like, which is key to this documentary being as effective as it is.
While they probably needed the decade-long gap between films to make us forget MIB2- this third installment is actually quite decent.
Not only one of the best documentaries of the year, but one of the best films period.
Wildly entertaining for it's first hour. More successful as a comedy than gothic horror.
Gorgeous. Like a lost Terrence Mallick movie from the seventies.
A much darker take on the Superman mythos than we're used to. The casting is perfect in all respects. This is an action packed start to what should be an exciting new franchise.
Lots of fun. Hoult and Palmer make an enaging, likable pair- even if one of them is "undead".
Has it's moments, and Giamatti & Rudd are always worth watching. Overall though, it's uneven and draggy.
Bad Milo is tremendously silly, but it's the kind of thing you either go with, or you don't. It's not perfect, but I had a pleasant time with it.
Lightweight and predictable. A waste of time.
Good, silly fun. Works better than the first one.
Up there with Hanks' very best performances.
Redford gives the kind of career-capping performance many of his contemporaries could only dream of.
Just another rehash, both slavishly devoted to DePalma's original, and lacking any of that film's style. Watch the older movie or read the book instead.
Not perfect, but it's a fun-filled eighties-style action throwback that should delight fans of both icons.
This is a great film to watch curled up with a date on a dark and stormy night. One thing's for sure- you won't be eager to go on any road trips right after.
Both one of the best AND one of the worst movies of the season.
The sexiest movie since 9 1/2 WEEKS. At it's heart, a sensitive- even innocent- love story.
Typically mushy Richard Curtis entry, but his movies are nothing if not heartfelt. ABOUT TIME is an enjoyable romp, and will likely put a smile on your face.
Actually quite a good film. Well-acted by Asa Butterfield, who makes a great Ender.
Just awful. Princess Di's life reimagined as a subpar soap opera.
A tad familiar, with Marvel franchise fatigue setting in, but overall it's enjoyable.
Disturbing and thought-provoking.
A great premise, solid acting, and some really interesting shots from director Matti make this well worth watching.
An intriguing portrait of the reclusive genius. Very accessible.
Excellent acting and a fresh avant-garde approach make this an arresting debut for helmer Moors.
Given the surprising sweetness of the story, HORNS could have a lot of appeal beyond horror fans.
Manages to turn a thoroughly gripping true story into an absolutely pedestrian, very dull film.
The beautifully choreographed and shot fights make up for the predictable plot and stale acting.
Best indie rom-com since 500 DAYS OF SUMMER.
One of the sleeper hits of TIFF 2013. Jude Law is fantastic.
Will leave a smile on the face of even the most cynical viewers. Impossible not to like.
A staggering failure.
It's not a terrible film by any stretch, but it's just not very good either.
A great piece of southern gothic storytelling. A return to form for both David Gordon Green and Nicolas Cage, in his best performance in years.
While it's not quite BRAZIL, THE DOUBLE feels like Ayoade- sooner rather than later- just may have what it takes to create something on that level.
Interesting fact-based adventure with a potentially awards-worthy performance by Wasikowsa.
Good but not great. Streep and Roberts feel a little too much like stunt-casting.
Hilarious "take-no-prisoners" black comedy. Bateman is terrific.
Relatively sophisticated and intriguing.
The best prison movie since A PROPHET. Jack O'Connell is a star in the making.
Exceptionally clever.
Frustrating but occasionally brilliant. Some arresting visuals.
The top-notch chemistry between the leads and a few solid laughs can't overcome the preachy, overly religious climax.
A well-crafted, effective family drama.
Undeniably entertaining. Jennifer Lawrence is as good as ever.
Worth seeing for Aubrey Plaza alone.
Could be subtitled "the lighter side of manic depression". Ruffalo is terrific, and the film is ultimately great family entertainment.
The cast (including Reynolds) is terrific, and the direction is occasionally inspired, but in the end THE VOICES is far too morbid to work as a comedy.
The best serial killer thriller since I SAW THE DEVIL.
Uneven and self-indulgent.
One of the best films to emerge from this year's Sundance, with an unexpectedly great performance by Bill Hader.
Wain's best film since WET HOT AMERICAN SUMMER. Let's put it this way, if you get the double-entendre of the title and you think it's funny, this is for you.
Coogan and Brydon are endlessly entertaining. Watching these two have a go at each other is a pleasure.
A likely future cult-favorite. Fassbender gives the best performance ever given by an actor in a papier-mâché head mask.
John Hawkes and Elle Fanning are outstanding. Possibly the most harrowing tale of drug addiction since REQUIEM FOR A DREAM.
Too many awkward moments make for a bad film. All three leads deserve better.
Funny and surprisingly wise.
Like a lost Hammer horror film from the seventies, only intentionally funny.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A deliberately old-fashioned WW2 adventure that shines a light on a little known chapter of the war and never ceases to entertain.

Hard to believe the same Daniel Waters who wrote HEATHERS wrote this. The mythology here is hilariously convoluted. Also- the subtext about the Dhampirs being content servants (slaves even) is more than a little odd.
Good direction isn't able to overcome a really bad script that feels like it was written by committee.
Tries to squeeze a little too much into a relatively scant running time, but overall YOUNG ONES is a pretty intriguing sci-fi effort. Michael Shannon is outstanding.
if you want an absolutely brutal experience that's tough to endure, just like CANNIBAL HOLOCAUST, this is probably the movie for you.
Brendan Gleeson is magnificent.
The best action sequel since Terminator 2. Contains some of the most gripping action sequences ever shot.
One of the best movies of the year. Casey Affleck is Oscar worthy.
A fun retro-style sci-fi/horror hybrid. Like a lost eighties Alien-clone, but in a good way.
This year's ARGO in that it's a smart, adult caper that has the potential to both score major awards and major box office. It's a blast from start to finish.
Better than the first film, but still too long and drawn out.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Idris Elba and Naomie Harris give brilliant performances even if the film falls short of being the epic big-screen treatment Mandela deserved.
A tired GRUMPY OLD MEN retread. A waste of time and talent.
Surprisingly thoughtful and introspective. Gorgeous cinematography.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A fitting tribute to one of the giants of film criticism.
One of the better entries in the series.
Tom Hardy is brilliant in what's essentially a one-man show.
Pretty dull, although the performances are excellent.
Feels like a lost eighties John Carpenter movie- and I mean that in the best way. Don Johnson is stunningly good.
Strangely uneven but Philip Seymour Hoffman is a le Carre natural.
So much fun. Wingard shows serious action chops, and DOWNTON ABBEY star Dan Stevens completely reinvents himself as a sort of Jason Bourne by way of THE TERMINATOR & Michael Myers.
Compelling and often thought-provoking.
A truly original revenge thriller.
Award-worthy performances by J.K. Simmons and Miles Teller.
A fresh, invigorating look at the Beat Poets.
A sweeping, romantic change-of-pace for director Jason Reitman.
While it maybe tries to pack a little too much in, PARKLAND is often quite fascinating.
Super stylish- this is Boyle having fun in his first straight-up thriller since SHALLOW GRAVE.
Imagine THE BIG CHILL crossed with RIGHT AT YOUR DOOR. Cleverly written and well-acted. If you like your comedy ultra-dark, this is worth checking out.
Reasonably good, but a better Robinson biopic could- and should- be made.

When you find yourself wishing there was more Lindsay Lohan in a movie, you know it's bad. SCARY MOVIE 5 is so bad that a DJ spinning a pizza instead of a record is what passes for a sight gag. Or a woman having sex with a microwave...
An arresting mix of visuals and music (the M83 score is excellent) is boosted by a more ambitious and cerebral plot than you'd expect. Cruise and Riseborough are excellent.
Fishburne's not enough to save this recycled, post-apocalyptic actioner.

This is like a bad eighties-sitcom, with the characters acting in a way that suggests the film was written by aliens who've only ever heard humans speak though watching DVDs they found in a trash bin outside a suburban Wal-Mart.
Should have been thought-provoking, but the protagonist remains frustratingly enigmatic.
Even though some purists may object to some of the twists and turns Black and company have managed to incorporate, for me, these twists are what makes IRON MAN 3 standout from the pack a bit
This one gets a marginal pass on the basis of Luhrmann's innovative use of 3D, the frenzied energy of the set-pieces, and DiCaprio's performance.
Better than pretty much everything else associated with Tyler Perry, but that's still not saying much. A talented cast is wasted.

Loaded with wall-to-wall action, STAR TREK INTO DARKNESS is a blast of summer movie fun. While it's probably geared to a more mainstream audience, if Trekkies go in with an open mind, they'll probably love it.

this latest film seems like an honest effort to finally put a definitive end to a series that's been the victim of it's own success. Too bad this definitive end means making a movie that's so bad absolutely no one will have any desire to see a Part 4.
it's better than M. Night's last couple of movies. At times it actually comes close to being relatively decent movie. Sadly, those moments are all within the first twenty minutes.
Good light summer fun, but frustrating. The Four Horsemen should have been the focus rather than Mark Ruffalo's cartoonishly dogged FBI agent.
Dark and nasty. More of a companion piece to Raimi's original than an all-out remake. Very well done. Not for the faint of heart.
If you're a skeptic like myself, this won't convince you, but it will provide some interesting insight into the type of people that spread these stories.
Not as excruciating as The Twilight Saga, but totally ludicrous, and packed with dopey dialogue.
A super solid action flick. Strong and McAvoy are terrific, and the film oozes style. Fans of Michael Mann or vintage John Woo need to check this out.
A bit familar, but the acting is excellent- especially from Guy Pearce.
A campy riff on 8 1/2 that doesn't really work, despite a cool visual style, and game performances from Sheen and Murray.
movie_title: A Glimpse Inside the Mind of Charles Swan III (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Maybe the books are a fun read for kids, but the movie is pretty dull.
Even as a date movie it's a failure. Stay home and rent The Notebook instead.
Easily the worst of the series- by a long shot. Makes LIVE FREE OR DIE HARD look like a classic.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A surprisingly gritty, low-key thriller. Highly recommended
Good fun, with lots of swashbuckling and a scene-stealing turn by Stanley Tucci.
Might as well call it Google: The Movie. Take the company out, and The Internship isn't only thin, it's non-existent.
A rehash of other, better movies- but for what it is, it's not bad.
Great visuals, but Franco is miscast as a silver-tongued huckster. The story is also fairly blah.
Three great action scenes and stellar acting from Farrell and Rapace make this a very solid thriller.
Better than you'd think. Two-thirds of a great thriller, but let down by a poor ending.
An absolute assault on the audience Korine seems to be trying to court, but is really subverting at every turn. Brilliant.
Fey and Rudd are always likable, but ADMISSION is pretty safe and uninspired.
...all action, and r-rated to boot!
Silly, but fun. Much better than the first movie. Dwayne Johnson is the ideal hero for a larger-than-life movie like this one.
Inconsistent, but mostly funny.
Enough laughs for half-a-dozen movies. You'll laugh so much it'll hurt.
Masterful. HOW GREEN WAS MY VALLEY, meets WINCHESTER '73, meets THE BLACK STALLION, meets ALL QUIET ON THE WESTERN FRONT. I loved every second of it.
Pretty tepid for Pixar. Basically it's REVENGE OF THE NERDS,
A fun, affectionate tribute to b-movie creature features.
A tepid sequel no one was really clamouring for.
Extremely well-written, with a unique and original plot. A great showcase for writer-director-star Lake Bell.
Just about as good as the first film, meaning- if you'll forgive the cliché- it kicks ass!
PARANOIA probably would have gone straight to DVD were it not for Ford ad Oldman's contributions. It's a relentlessly boring thriller with an incredibly bland performance by star Hemsworth.
Like THE CONJURING, proves that horror movies can be ambitious, sophisticated, and R-rated without being schlock. Highly recommended.
Virtually incomprehensible, but a beautiful mess.
A fun addition to the found-footage horror subgenre.
The best indie of the year. Brie Larson gives a career-making performance.
With its tongue firmly planted in cheek, Bounty Killer makes up in style what it lacks in resources.
Very lackluster thriller. Even the car chases- which are the whole reason this movie exists- are monotonous.
A masterpiece. The movie everyone's going to be talking about this fall. Jackman deserves an Oscar nomination.
Takes an exceedingly complicated story- the Wiki-Leaks saga- and boils it down into a compact two hour movie that's consistently entertaining and easy-to-follow.
A great, exceedingly well-cast, throwback to seventies cinema. Clive Owen's best part since CHILDREN OF MEN.

A film that will no doubt come to be known as the definitive movie on slavery in America. It's something everyone should be obligated to see, as it conveys the nightmare of that period in a real, affecting, personal way.
Extremely entertaining. Ron Howard's best movie in years.
Not bad at all. Nicolas Cage gives his best performance in years.

Every once in a while, a film comes along that pushes the form to such an extent that it throws down the gauntlet to other filmmakers, daring them to be as audacious in their craft. This is one of those.

BIG BAD WOLVES had me simultaneously doubling over with laughter and averting my eyes and cringing in disgust and fear, usually in the same scene. The best movie of this year's Fantasia Film Festival.
TAXI DRIVER for fanboys!
While it's no VIRGIN SUICIDES or LOST IN TRANSLATION, THE BLING RING is still a sad glimpse into our fascination with fame.
It's 2/3's of a decent movie. The reworked ending kills it's momentum and ends it on a very sour, underwhelming note.

A serious, somber character study marred by a handful of quick action scenes probably shoehorned in to allow the studio to market this as an action film, which it's not. Statham's performance is excellent.
Totally ridiculous, but also tons of fun. This is the best "check your brain at the door" actioner since FURIOUS 7.
Depressingly mediocre. Even the gags that worked in the red-band trailer fall flat.
Just another long, bloated, would-be epic.
Familiar tale of indie-suburban angst.
Dark, thrilling and heartfelt. Just as uncompromising and imaginative as DISTRICT 9.
A pop-masterpiece, and one of the finest pieces of pure action cinema ever made.
From the time this sucker started I had an ear-to-ear grin on my face that was so wide my cheeks are still killing me hours later, It'll make you feel like a kid again.
On the surface the substance seems thin, but if you look past they admittedly flashy style, you'll see that there's something deeper and more profound going on here than you might think.
Whatever it was that made the first film work is really lacking here.
Solid horror film that pays hommage to the great character-driven horror classics of the sixties and seventies.
A would-be blockbuster gone horribly awry. The summer of 2013's biggest fiasco.
Lean and mean for the most part. A nicely scaled-down superhero movie, and a great stand-alone adventure for Jackman.

A fun throwback to eighties-nineties R-rated action movies. This is the kind of movie Don Simpson or Joel Silver would have done in their heyday. Not terribly clever, but very entertaing. Washington and Wahlberg's roles are tailor-made.
It's pretty sad that Sandler's sunk so far that a movie being merely bad is somehow a success.
Not quite as fresh as the first film, but still good fun. Jared Harris makes an ideal Moriarty.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: An engrossing snapshot of dirty campaign politics.
The Bard meets THE HURT LOCKER. Redgrave deserves some Oscar love.
Tons of fun. Cruise is great, and Diaz can still rock a bikini!
Pretty much a perfect film...
About as bad as it gets
Everything about this film is so mind-bogglingly stupid, I barely know where to begin!
It's definitely a film worth seeing.
I enjoyed the heck out of Karate Kid, and if you like Chan, and can get over the fact that this is a remake of a childhood favorite, you should check it out.
Definitely worth seeing if you like a good gross-out film/ sex comedy.
While it's more than a tad derivative, it's a stylish, and well constructed flick, benefiting enormously from the lead performances from Adrien Brody and Sarah Polley.
A very entertaining character study.
[It] feels like a movie designed as a cash machine, with little real entertainment value other than a couple of cameos, and about a half dozen chuckles.
The massage is important, and the acting from Harrelson is incredible.
Ladies and gentlemen- this is it. This is the moment where Will Ferrell's shtick (already wearing thin after his last couple of films) officially got old.
[Rec] 2 is probably the most effective horror sequel I've seen since 28 Weeks Later.
Just another mediocre fantasy flick, but if you enjoyed the books, I'm sure you'll enjoy the film.
movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A much need shot of adrenaline in a summer dominated by emo-vampires, and ten year old action heroes.
Goes downhill after a promising first hour.
Filled with lame Niqab jokes that could have been lifted out of ISHTAR, or a bad episode of FAMILY GUY.
More DEATH WISH than GRAN TORINO, which isn't a bad thing. Caine is downright iconic!
Of the dozens of chick flicks to come out this year, THIS is the one that's not bad!
an emotional roller-coaster ride that you won't be able to shake for days afterwards
a delightful and timely comedy
the best film I've seen since THE HURT LOCKER
don't plan on taking any ski trips afterwards
I've said it once, and I'll say it again; Farrell's the real deal, and easily one of the best actors to come along in the last decade.
Not top-tier Scorsese, but still a nicely atmospheric thriller.
Shame on them!
Charming CGI toon, that takes a page out of the Pixar playbook.
Even worse than the trailers make it look...
An intriguing erotic thriller undone by a silly, generic ending.
For what it is, it's a good time at the movies.
Mindless, but mostly fun.
More like IRON MAN 1.5
Do we really need a movie about SHREK's midlife crisis? Really?
Pee-your-pants funny AND a solid action flick to boot!
Only a NIGHTMARE for fans of the franchise.
KICK-ASS kicks ass! A rockin' good ride...
While it's not among the best films I saw at Sundance, it's still quite entertaining, and well worth seeing
Fairly fun, and occasionally exciting, but so bombastic that you'll feel more like you're being bombarded, than actually watching a film.
A gripping piece of Gothic horror.
Paints a mental hospital as a charming place for a teen to come of age. Incredible that the directors of HALF-NELSON could get this so wrong.
movie_title: It's Kind of a Funny Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Another great film from Danny Boyle featuring a potentially Oscar-worthy performance from James Franco.
A fun action flick distinguished by the stunning visuals.
Slowly paced but worthwhile film.
Not the return to form fans of director John Carpenter are hoping for.
Depressing, but beautifully crafted.
Pitch perfect superhero satire that probably has more in common with TAXI DRIVER than KICK ASS.
A superb British comedy, and the sleeper hit of the Toronto International Film Festival.
While Stone may not be a film you'll want to rush out to once it opens in a few weeks, if you want to see a somewhat unconventional thriller, this would make a solid rental.
Astoundingly bad. Unfathomably bad. As bad as any film Uwe Boll's ever made, and then some.
It's not particularly scary, but it's still a very moody and effective flick.
It had potential, but the execution is all wrong, as it should have been handled with more sensitivity.
Creativity always trumps cash, and nowhere is that more evident than here.
Not on par with the first film, but still worth seeing. Douglas is incredible.
Pleasant throwback to eighties John Hughes flicks.
One of the best remakes to come along in quite some time.
Proves GONE BABY GONE was no fluke, and also that Affleck's rebirth works IN FRONT of the camera too.
Inspiring, and wholly entertaining, THE KING'S SPEECH is an example of the type of film that isn't made enough anymore.
It's as if Aronofsky has a direct pipeline into my nightmares.
Like the obscure Vampire musical, ROCKULA- but, you know-good.
It's like a psychotic re-imagining of PRETTY IN PINK!
Bloody good R-Rated fun. A perfect film to kick back and watch with a couple of beers and buds!
An excellent, albeit harrowing piece of work featuring a standout performance from Noah Taylor.
The film PUBLIC ENEMIES should have been. An incredible gangster tale full of ball-to-the-wall action!
The film PUBLIC ENEMIES should have been. An incredible gangster epic packed with balls-to-the-wall action!
The film PUBLIC ENEMIES should have been. An incredible gangster epic packed with balls-to-the-wall action!
It's hard to be frightened by something when you're too busy laughing at it.
More or less on par with other McKay/Ferrell collaborations, THE OTHER GUYS delivers big laughs, and a surprisingly sharp comedic performance from Mark Wahlberg.
Exactly the kind of cheese I love!
Not bad bad as the poster makes it out to be, but not good either.
More like a good TV movie than a full-on film, but still a good adaptation of the novel. Rapace is excellent.
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Definitely worth a look.
movie_title: Hugh Hefner: Playboy, Activist and Rebel (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Michael Mann should sue!
I had a good enough time.
Assuming this is a hoax, Phoenix gives one of his greatest performances. If it's real, then he's a disgrace.
Stallone grabs you by the balls and doesn't let go for until the credits roll!
Heavily flawed, but better than a lot of the critics are claiming.
a highly entertaining, even somewhat moving comedy
Stewart & Fanning are both great, but Michael Shannon as Kim Fowley steals the show.
Passable entertainment -- but definitely not on par with the usual DiCaprio, Crowe, or Ridley Scott output.
Ladies and gentlemen: believe the buzz! WALL-E is a bona-fide, all out masterpiece.
Yt another example of Disney's slick movie making machine- designed to churn out sleek family flicks with the sole objective of making mountains of money.
It's a safe, inspirational film, but it's an exceedingly well crafted one.
While it wasn`t quite the train-wreck I expected, it was still a pretty average superhero flick, and definitely not a film I`ll be revisiting anytime soon.
I almost loved STATE OF PLAY
Here we go again...
TERMINATOR: SALVATION is a decent enough summer action flick but I can't help but feeling seriously let down.
The film, while being sold as a hit-man drama, is really just a series of vignettes, with Bankolé's blank slate character encountering various people in Spain.
This cast a spell over me, hitting all the right notes, and reminding me once again, why I love films so much in the first place.
Wow, count this as one film that completely took me by surprise!
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: your typical middle of the road, summer action/thriller
a nice bit of counter-programming for folks that might be suffering from a bit of Blockbuster fatigue
I know this is supposed to be a comedy, but the film does not even have a single moment of truth or substance.
I find it interesting that that the two best films about men that I've seen this summer (The Hurt Locker being the other) have been directed by women.
Ranks among the best films of the year.
Well worth seeing if only for another great Eastwood performance.
Oh, great -- another kiddie fantasy film. How exciting!
It deserves to be a major hit.
Cusack is pretty much the only reason to see this.
This is probably one of the best movies I have ever seen, and easily the best of the summer.
I honestly cannot believe how much I enjoyed this film, which is a surprise as I walked into this film with a lot of baggage.
While I'm most definitely disappointed with the film- I still enjoyed it once I accepted the fact that it bares no resemblance to the Bond franchise that I know and love
AUSTRALIA is a film that's simply way too earnest for our cynical age.
the action scenes are cut so tight that it's nearly impossible to tell what's going on
It's truly a film everyone can take something positive from, and a film that, for me at least, is one of the top films of the year
F**k I loved this movie!
Overall, I really liked this film, and I hope that people check it out in the admittedly crowded holiday season.
I had a lot more fun at Bolt than I initially thought I would.
Despite my problems with The Reader, it's still a film well worth seeing, although far from Oscar worthy.
Lumet is still one of the best directors in the business.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: While it doesn't really break any new ground in the realm of teen comedy, and certainly isn't side-splitting funny, it's still a pretty pleasant way to spend ninety minutes, and good for a few belly laughs.
While I think ultimately this film is unnecessary, it's still fairly entertaining and it's certainly better than the recent Pink Panther reboot with Steve Martin.
There are a few other clever pokes at Hollywood, but many of the jokes, including a subplot about a Sean Penn thriller that needs fixing, falls flat.
Not a bad tearjerker for the holiday season and as Smith's in it, it'll probably make a mint.
It has a nice message, and despite the fact that I feel he's been totally emasculated over the years, Cube remains a solid actor.
At times I was entertained, and even moved by it. It's just damn frustrating, as this could have been a MUCH better film
there are a few good jokes, but for me a few laughs here and there aren't enough
movie_title: The Goods: Live Hard, Sell Hard (2009)

movie_review_blurb: really can't recommend this one enough and it should be considered a must see
[It's] not something you should say bah humbug to.
"You'll be thoroughly entertained throughout, but hate yourself for liking it afterwards"
"This feels way too manipulative to be taken seriously"
"At the risk of sounding a bit cheesy, THE FANTASTIC MR. FOX is fantastic!"
AVATAR is not the kick-ass, mind-blowing James Cameron movie I was hoping for, but it's a perfectly serviceable sci-fi adventure that's well worth seeing
I have no idea why, whenever a studio decides to do a big musical, they never actually hire singers to act in the films
a ripping good time at the movies
A great, thoroughly enjoyable film, and one which I`m sure will get some Oscar attention towards the end of the year.
A film well worth seeing.
exactly the kind of film I was hoping I'd see at Sundance
Many with loathe it, but hopefully, just as many will love it.
Great hillbilly horror comedy!
Like a modern day John Cassavetes film
destined to take its place among classics like HALF-BAKED and UP IN SMOKE
A solid, claustrophobic thriller anchored by a great performance from Reynolds.
A SERIOUS MAN meets GO.
A missed opportunity.
Incredible action setpieces more than make up for the slow gaps.
movie_title: Legend of the Fist: The Return of Chen Zhen (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Worth checking out if you`re a big MJ fan...
A solid fantasy flick, with a great role for star Purefoy.
In the space of ninety minutes, we get a body count that has to be in the triple digits, loads of T & A, and even a full on musical number
This is easily one of the worst films I've ever had to review.
Does it live up to the hype? Hell yeah!
It's highly entertaining, wildly unconventional, and oddly thought provoking.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: "Horror fans should be looking forward to this one."
Cera's best work since ARRESTED DEVELOPMENT
Solid- but not great.
While it probably doesn't hold up to much scrutiny, it's still a solid, entertaining thriller.
A disapointment- but still worth seeing.
Damon has never been better!
Surely this is not meant to be taken seriously?
movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A wonderful comedic adventure. Is Dany Boon the new Chaplin?
I still enjoyed watching Ong Bak 2 even if I was a little disappointed in the fight scenes
Probably the film's only real saving grace is Ben Foster, who tries hard in the lead, but doesn't have a heck of a lot to work with.
Whip It ended up being a total blast. For her first film as a director, Barrymore's done a bang-up job.
It's gory, action packed, well-written, and most importantly- FUN!
A journey worth taking.

Turns out- Fincher was right all along. Rooney Mara is a perfect Salander. Her performance, combined with the Reznor/Ross score, makes this a perfect adaptation of Stieg Larsson's entertaining novel. A must-see.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: James Caan and Vera Farmiga are great, but they can't overcome a mediocre premise.
Errol Morris is one of the true masters of the documentary form.
Not a perfect film, but a damn fun one.
A stunning debut for writer/director/actor Evan Glodell. My favorite- so far, of 2011.
While I'd love to see Favreau tackle a straight-up western, minus the aliens, COWBOYS & ALIENS is still a fun-filled summer blockbuster. Craig and Ford are great.
A genuinely great film.
It's not a horrible film, but it's nowhere near as good as it could (or should) have been.

Despite a few plot holes, and some goofy shout-outs to the 1968 original, RISE is a rock-solid summer blockbuster. The Weta effects work, coupled with Andy Serkis's mo-cap performance as Caesar make this a must-see.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Has it's moments thanks to winningly raunchy performances by Reynolds and Bateman, but overall not as funny as it should have been. The premise is also rather tired.
While it's a little too Disney-fied for my tastes, Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer make it worth seeing. Both should be remembered during Oscar season.
It comes frustratingly close to being a good film, but doesn't quite make it. The ending (or lack thereof) is at best lazy, at worst insulting.
Hollywood dreck at its worst.
A surprising tasty late-summer treat!
It's 100 percent pure adrenaline, and phenomenally entertaining.
Gory but pedestrian reboot.
Lukewarm late-summer horror flick. Too tame to please hardcore horror fans, and too ham-fisted to please anyone else.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: WARRIOR made me want to get on my feet and cheer. Move over BRIAN'S SONG- this is going to become a "guy cry" classic.
A fitting final chapter.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Uneven, but funny.
Defiantly optimistic, but phony.
This is pure, turn-your-brain-off, munch some popcorn, enjoy the explosions- summer fun.
A slam-bang start to the summer.
Great summer fun, anchored by a star-making performance from Chris Hemsworth.
One thing's for sure -- I'll never watch Iron Man the same way again.
movie_title: POM Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's definitely something worth seeking out, and a must-see if you have any interest in the ethics of modern reporting.
Just terrible. A by-the-numbers, paycheck film if ever there was one.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's still worth seeing, if only for Gibson's performance.
May be a rehash, but it's a funny rehash.
Scarier than any traditional horror film you're likely to see.
About as good as the first one. Not exactly Pixar, but it does the trick.
Probably the best movie about kids since STAND BY ME.
Woody's most inspired comedy in years. Charming, and very enjoyable- even if you're not normally a Woody Allen fan.
A textbook example of movie-making by committee. All the money in the world can't save a film with a script THIS bad.
This is Carrey phoning it in, without any of the usual Carrey hi-jinx that makes these films worth watching.
Cameron Diaz looks like she's having a blast in her best role in years.
Mediocre Pixar is still way better than what any other animation studios are doing.
This is a huge step up for director Mills.
One of the most energetic superhero movies to come along in ages. The summer of 2011 has a new king!
Nearly a great film. Sadly, Robert Pattinson's charisma-free performance is a liability.
Works not only as entertainment, but also as art. And make no mistake, DRIVE is art.
A top-notch action flick that stands out. Statham's best movie since THE BANK JOB.
A film's that's at least occasionally excellent.
It's certainly lightweight, but there's nothing at all wrong with that. I thoroughly enjoyed it.
Should be called "THE THREE MUSKETEERS FOR MORONS"

For Depp, this is a welcome return to the rebellious character actor he used to be (long before he became a billion-dollar savior for Disney), and I'd like to see him continue to explore Thompson's work on-screen.
Although the film lacks momentum, the premise and Timberlake's appeal makes it a more thsn decent watch.
It's a fun heist flick and a great showcase for Murphy, Pena and Broderick.
Somewhat academic, and deliberately paced, J. EDGAR is still a measured, thoughful biopic, featuring a surprisingly uncanny performance from DiCaprio.
Trashy fun.
Not a bad little Christmas fable. The Aardman Animation wit is in full-effect anytime Bill Nighy's great Grandsanta is onscreen.
An infectious ode to the early days of cinema. Scorsese's use of 3D is inspired, although it might be more interesting for parents than their children.
If Crowe's films radiate one thing, it's kindness, which is something not a lot of filmmakers can claim.
Totally overrated- just like the play.
The subversive streak and a hilarity courtesy of Sam Rockwell makes it worth seeing.
I think I read about this somewhere in the Book of Revelations (ya know, somewhere between forty years of darkness, and the dead walking the Earth).
Boasts one of best casts in recent memory. It's like the anti-Bond or Mission: Impossible. A ruthless and realistic look at life in the spy game. Easily one of the best films of the year.
A hare-brained excuse for a satire.
Hokum that belongs on DVD rather than in theaters. A sad comedown for Cage, Kidman, and Schumacher.
Hard to believe such a hokey, stupid film could attract so much talent.
It's probably more something to be endured rather than enjoyed. However, it's certainly something deserving of attention.
movie_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Another winner for Clooney and Payne. Warmly funny, and life-affirming.
A smarter-than-average crowd pleaser. Hill and Pitt are fantastic.
For 90% of the film, I thought I knew what TAKE THIS WALTZ was up to, before Polley pulled the carpet out from under me in the final act- and bless her for that!
A harrowing look at sexual addiction. McQueen follows in the footsteps of John Cassavetes with this blistering portrait. A must-see.
This amazing true story is somewhat let down by workman-like direction, but Butler's performance, coupled with the undeniably powerful story make this worth watching.
A warm-hearted tale that's tough to dislike.
A pitch-perfect blend of comedy and tragedy that will leave you with a lump in your throat, and a tear in your eye.
Casts a spell- right from the first frame. For anyone that truly loves film.
The twist will likely infuriate many, but Fresnadillo's effort to give audiences something different has to be appreciate. Owen is excellent.
Anonymous is a fun costume drama, and one of Emmerich's better films.
A highly charged action adventure/comedy drama.
A new classic to fit in among the hallowed ranks of THE WICKER MAN and THE SHINING.
It's certainly the type of work that demands a lot from the audience, but I found it to be a stunning, altogether worthwhile film.
God Bless America is exactly the kind of comedy we need. It's funny in an incredibly dark way, but it also turns a critical eye on the many problems within our society.

Distinguished from other "cop on the edge" dramas by both Harrelson's Oscar-caliber performance, and Moverman's refusal to judge his characters, or spoon feed an easy-to-digest ending to the audience.
Essentially a filmed play, but McConaughey's performance is too good to ignore.
A charming and sophisticated comedy.
A solid black comedy, with scene stealing performances from Laura Linney, and Ray Liotta.
A very entertaining examination of Hicks' life and legacy.
Regardless of how badly it goes in the home-stretch, it's still worth seeing.
A scaled-back, rather dull addition to the NARNIA franchise. Good for VERY young children, but no one else.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The screenplay is a mess, but visually it's a perfect film. The soundtrack by Daft Punk is one of the best scores to come along in a long time.
Lean and mean, with a killer performance from Jeff Bridges, and star-making role for Halie Steinfeld.
Feels like three bad movies instead of one good one. Not as bad as SPANGLISH, but stil...
Focking atrocious!
Not a good film by any stretch of the imagination, but far from Cage's worst.
Good buddy-buddy chemistry between Chou and Rogan, along with some inspired carnage in the last half hour make THE GREEN HORNET a rare treat in a traditionally slow month.
A very worthwhile drama and well worth seeing.
