This is a good film, and well-worth seeing, even if it's not one of the real Oscar contenders some have been pegging it as.
It's about as crappy as the trailers make it seem- and if you found them as painful to sit through as I did, you should avoid this like the plague.
It's well shot, and Dorff is good enough to make me hope he starts popping up in higher profile fare again.
At times it's grueling, and even difficult to watch, but it's a remarkably powerful film.
Frustratingly inconsistent.
Heavy on both the laughs and the heart.
Like BLUE VALENTINE for college kids, and I don't mean that as a bad thing. Potentially a star-making role for Felicity Jones. LIKE CRAZY is an extremely likable film.
Undeniably the big misfire of the season. Good looking locations, and sexy stars don't make up for a lack of chemistry, and a tepid plot.
A phenomenal piece of work. Wahlberg, Bale, Adams, and Leo are all Oscar-worthy. Ranks with RAGING BULL, ROCKY and BODY & SOUL as one of the greatest boxing movies ever made.
Hardcore, but also heavily flawed action flick. Johnson seems to be playing a supporting role in his own movie.
Stands alongside THE LAST AIRBENDER as one of the worst films of the year.
This is a late-night cable watch at most.
Possibly the film of the year. Much more than just a facebook movie.
It's as lame as can be, and despite sitting on the shelf for four years, it's not even bad enough to be unintentionally funny.
While it's not really something I can see myself revisiting any time soon, it's a solid, well made film that should please hardcore horror fans.
I truly loathed just about every second of Life as We Know It.
Laced with enough laughs to make this work as both an action ride, and a comedy. Mirren and Malkovich steal the show.
While it doesn't strike me as a major Oscar contender, it's still an enjoyable true life tale that would make a solid DVD rental at some point.
A film that will polarize audiences, but nonetheless one that I found rather profound. Perfectly cast and scored, I MELT WITH YOU is like a post-FIGHT CLUB Chuck Palahniuk novel come to life.
If you like watching guys subject themselves to insanely stupid and dangerous stunts and pranks, than by all means, this is the film for you. Just keep a vomit bag handy.
Even in it's watered-down 2 1/2 hour cut, CARLOS remains a stunning piece of work. This is a star-making performance for Edgar Ramirex.
A finely crafted political thriller, with superb performances from Naomi Watts and Sean Penn.
Very inconsistent, but when it's funny, it's DAMN funny.
It's truly an incredible piece of work, and something that needs to been seen, and actually feels essential. It's truly, for better or worse, a film of our times.

Of all the young actresses to come along over the last few years, McAdams feels like the one that's got the best chance to become the next Julia Roberts, and nowhere is that clearer than in MORNING GLORY
I'm anxiously awaiting the next Harry Potter, and this is probably the only film series I can think of where each film is better than the last.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: One of the rare remakes that improves upon the original, THE NEXT THREE DAYS is a fun, exciting thriller in the vein of THE FUGITIVE and FRANTIC. Crowe & Banks are phenomenal.
Pretty much a carbon copy of the first film. Full of cheap scares, and goofy connections to part 1 in a misguided effort to build a "mythology" so this cash cow can keep churning out milk.
Almost a great film, SON OF NO ONE is ruined by some truly boneheaded editorial tricks during the conclusion.
A good Sunday afternoon cable watch, but not much more than that.
At times I found myself doubled over in hysteria at the complete insanity of the carnage I was watching on-screen. HOBO was a blast!
About as bad as it could be. Gary Oldman chews a bit of scenery, but even he can't save this disasterous new spin of the Brothers Grimm classic.
While I admired the acting, it just never really came together into a cohesive whole that I could appreciate, but it's still an interesting, laudable attempt at making something different.
A mess. Starts off great, but ruined by a ridiculous second half. There may be a good movie on a cutting room floor somewhere, but this ain't it.
A solid, adult thriller. McConaughey's best role since A TIME TO KILL.
Not on the level of SHAUN OF THE DEAD, or HOT FUZZ, but PAUL is still a whole lot of fun. Kristen Wiig makes an inspired addition to the Pegg/Frost team.
I thoroughly enjoyed it, and I hope we get to see more quality mob movies sooner rather than later.
More like an adolescent fanboy's wet dream come to life than a film.
The writing is atrocious, but BATTLE: LOS ANGELES is still a fun ride for action junkies.
It's quite a good film, and well-worth seeing even if you don't normally go for this type of thing.
Strong, extraordinarily disciplined horror flick. No cheap scares here.

An entertaining sci-fi thriller that's not affraid to invest some emotion into the proceedings- which makes it all the more unique compared to some of the cold blockbusters we've been getting. Duncan Jones is a superstar director in the making.
Without a doubt, the best killer tire movie you'll ever see.
It's probably one of the most important films of the year.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Brilliantly executed, art-house/action mash-up. Truly unique.
Funny, Mel Brooks-style spoof of eighties sword and sorcery tales. Probably owes more to KRULL & BEASTMASTER than LOTR.
Ugh, Arthur is everything that's wrong with remakes wrapped up in a one hundred minute package.
This one's strictly for the youngsters, but that doesn't change the fact that it's a very well-made kid's film.
More fun from the director of NOT QUITE HOLLYWOOD. A total blast.
A surprisingly affecting sci-fi romance, aided immensely by the chemistry between stars Matt Damon and Emily Blunt.
A tongue in cheek look at Roger Corman's legacy, it's every bit as fun as you'd expect given Corman's oeuvre.
movie_title: Corman's World: Exploits Of A Hollywood Rebel (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The finest film of the 2011 Sundance film fest. One of the few films I've seen in a while that truly filled me with dread.
This is a profoundly depressing film at times, but in the end, it also proves to be a surprisingly hopeful one. If you have the stomach for it, TYRANNOSAUR is an intensely rewarding film
Well-worth seeing for a couple of good chuckles.
The film WALL STREET: MONEY NEVER SLEEPS should have been.
Michael Shannon is brilliant. One of the big discoveries of this year's Sundance.
A side-splitting tour de force for Brendan Gleeson, who's award worthy. If you enjoyed IN BRUGES, THE GUARD is the film for you!
Somewhat vanilla JUNO-clone. Not an awful film, but nothing that sticks out, especially at Sundance.
A terrific Saturday matinee for pretty much anyone.
An authentic, truthfull family film, and a nice change of pace for Paul Giamatti.
It's painfully unfunny, and the type of immediately disposable junk one wouldn't expect to see on cable, much less the Sundance Film Festival.
A searing look at the modern family dynamic, and the way love and hate can be inter-changable at times. Ellen Barkin is Oscar worthy.
TAKEN meets SILENCE OF THE LAMBS. A perfect blend of action and horror- proving once again the South Koreans are the masters of the modern thriller.
This could have been a great survival epic, but instead it's just a mediocre piece of eye-candy.
Perfectly servicable sword n' sandal action flick. Channing Tatum continues to evolve as a leading man, but Jamie Bell steals the show.
This is NOT a movie, it's simply slick product designed to make money, rather than entertain.
DRIVE ANGRY is a real treat, just as long as you go in with the right attitude. This is a beer (or Nic Cage approved Jack Daniels) swiggin' movie if ever there was one.
A real missed opportunity.
Hilariously ill-conceived. Works on a "so bad it's good" level.
Hilariously foul. Best hockey comedy since SLAP SHOT.
Like a bad Tarantino clone from the mid-nineties. Just awful.
Funny in bits and pieces but can't sustain a film.
TV movie fare at best.
Works only when Thornton and Brett Kelly (returning as the now grown Thurman) are paired. Otherwise, a pale imitation of the original.
Not as good as it could, or should, have been but still an entertaining WW2 yarn.
Exceptionally well-acted, with a powerhouse performance from Keaton.
Overall, MISS SLOANE suffers from a maudlin conclusion that spoon-feeds a resolution to the audience, but for ninety percent of the running time its an excellent, character-driven drama.
It's a sexy, adult thriller that doesn't pander and never feels artificial. This one will likely find an appreciative audience and makes for a promising debut for writer/director Ross.
Only OK, but given how bad a year this has been for comedies, I guess OK is good enough.
This is exactly what Edwards always said he was going to make - a STAR WARS war film. People die, and tears will be shed. Anyone who thought it would be watered-down should think again.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: the ingredients are all here, making it even more puzzling that the movie falls as flat as it does
hopelessly corny and oh so silly
A stylish, neo-noir/western with a standout performance by Ian McShane.
Kurzel and Fassbender will both go on to make many more good movies, but neither is a good fit for a piece of escapism.
Another dynamic, real-life thriller for Berg/Wahlberg, with a standout performance by Alex Wolff.
A terrific throwback gangster flick in the mold of WB's James Cagney/ Humphrey Bogart classics. Great action, excellent writing/acting.
It's thoroughly enjoyable and a guaranteed crowd-pleaser
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Beatty's made an entertaining film. It's not REDS, but it doesn't try to be. RULES DON'T APPLY proves that the man they used to call "The Pro" hasn't lost his touch.
Nic Cage gives it a real effort, but Army of One goes horribly awry right from the start.
A stunning achievement... This is a movie about a gentle man, but it's not a gentle film.
It's a half-good film, but that's a small comfort when up to a certain point I thought I was watching something really special.
Very hokey and old-fashioned in its sensibilities, but Eddie Murphy's performance is excellent.
Desperately unfunny. Should have stayed on the shelf.
An inspiring true story with great performances.
Conventional, but brilliantly acted and intriguing.
A poorly-made thriller that wastes a terrific cast. Not even Blunt can save this one.
Silly but has its moments.
Thoroughly entertaining with terrific performances all around.
At least a half-hour too long, but also daring and original.
One can't help but be mortified for Cage. A bargain-basement would-be WW2 epic with hilariously poor CGI and an abysmal script.
Simple, but action-packed. Cruise is in top-form and Smulders makes for a terrific action star in her own right.
A fun riff on spaghetti westerns. Ethan Hawke and (especially) Jumpy the Dog are outstanding.
How could a movie packed with so much talent go so awry?
Some interesting work (particularly from Renee Zellweger and James Belushi) is marred by some lazy narrative devices, specifically the constant voice-over narration.
a tough watch despite the odd moment of inspiration
A dull end to a very uneven trilogy.
A real treat for action fans and a terrific vehicle for Ben Affleck.
Lesser Tim Burton, but worth seeing for Eva Green.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Incredible performances all around, and Wilson's play is given a reverential big screen adaptation.
Some inspired lunacy from Nicolas Cage isn't quite enough to save this modest crime melodrama.
Conventional, but entertaining.
Of the four stories, only one of them really works. The others range from mediocre to bad.
Gonzo but surprisingly sweet. A major big-screen debut for Kyle Mooney.
Good action design isn't able to compensate for a predictable script.
Artful and disturbing. Teresa Palmer's best performance to date.
A great star-turn from the perennially underrated Sam Elliot.
Pretentious art-house posing.
Demented and hilarious. Alexander Skarsgard's best role to date.
Butterfield and Oldman aren't enough to save this too cheesy sci-fi road movie.
Well-directed, dynamic and action-packed sequel that emphasizes the insanity of the John Wick universe.
At least a half hour too long and self-indulgent, but also visually sumptuous and mostly entertaining.
Perfect for families, but it almost feels like Batman fanboys are the real target demo here.
Matt Damon is badly miscast in this silly period fantasy.
Uneven but worthwhile due to a strong last act.
The movie fans have been asking for ever since Hugh Jackman first put on his claws.
Beautifully-shot and Matt Bomer is great in an unusual part.
Experimental and utterly compelling.
A fun, fast-paced true crime tale. Jack Black's best performance since BERNIE.
WOLF OF WALL STREET-lite, but a fun, fast-paced tale.
It's the type of film one submits to rather than watches, but if there's any living filmmaker I'd submit to, it's Scorsese.
Not as bad as it looks. A harmless, fast-paced kids flick.
An atypically sympathetic portrayal by Fassbender.
A fun midnight movie mash-up of Pasolini by way of Mel Brooks.
Less impactful than the original, but a much needed word of encouragement for those who've taken up Gore's challenge.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A dazzling, comic neo-noir.
movie_title: I don't feel at home in this world anymore. (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A superior thriller distinguished by a strong premise, superb action and one of star Jeremy Renner's best ever performances.
This is really a wonderful adventure-comedy.
Uneven, but thoughtful and always intriguing.
A solid war drama gets bogged down in a routine mystery.
A too predictable comedy distinguished only by some of the performances.
A star-making comedy for Kumail Nanjiani.
With influences ranging from Dario Argento to THE STEPFORD WIVES, Jordan Peele's directorial debut is smart, stylish and scary.
if Sundance has a raison d'etre, it's to give movies like this a platform, andthis isa movie well-worthy of the opportunity to break out.
A sumptuously filmed, beautifully acted love story with Armie Hammer's best performance to date.
To the Bone is for sure a movie I hoped I would like, as a good, gritty story about anorexia is needed, although this isn't that film. Even still, Collins's performance is too good to overlook.
A little too self-consciously quirky.
A relatively enjoyable little thriller.
An impressive, sharply written and acted coming-of-age flick.
A terrific true-life tale packed with great performances.
Classy, big-budget horror done right!
something akin to an American epic, and possibly the greatest long-form documentary of its type ever made
Very low-key but extremely well-acted.
All in all, this is pretty fascinating stuff and a must see for any real film fanatic.
movie_title: Raiders!: The Story of the Greatest Fan Film Ever Made (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Surprisingly dull but very well acted.
Buschel really is turning out to be a solid indie craftsman, and The Phenom is a nice example of his evolving style. I'm eager to see what he does next.
Too goofy to be taken seriously, although Lively's performance is quite decent.
Well-cast if a tad uninspired. A solid, if unspectacular comeback for the vine-swinging hero.
It's cute enough that it won't drive parents up the wall when they take their kids to see it in theaters
An unexpected summer highlight. Probably the best all-around blockbuster since Captain America: Civil War.
Underrated nineties gem!
A suitably affectionate, warm-hearted tribute. Catnip for Trekkies.
Dopey and disposable, but fun.
A back-to-basics Trek that puts the franchise back on solid ground.
Clearly a franchise that ran out of steam a long time ago.

Optimized for international success, with far-flung locations and a new heist-movie vibe that's clearly trying to do for this hopeful series what FAST FIVE did for Vin Diesel and company. Sadly, the gimmick doesn't work as a franchise.
One thing it's not - thank God - is another Nicholas Sparks adaptation
THIS IS SPINAL TAP for millennials - a knowing and often hilarious satire of the already state of pop stardom.
Well-made but ultimately dull.
Derivative of American Psycho but entertaining.
A surefire mood-booster. Destined to become a cult-classic, with a top notch cast.
Ultimately minor but Walken is great in a tailor-made part.
movie_title: One More Time (When I Live My Life Over Again) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Not the usual lighthearted Barbershop installment, but also intelligent and highly relevant.
The cast is excellent but considering the subject matter, Colonia should have been much more compelling.
An incredibly dull sequel to a movie no one really liked in the first place. Chastain and Blunt are wasted, while Theron at least has some fun in a surprisingly small part.
If you like gunfights, car chases, George Michael and kitty-cats, this is for you!
Silly but fun, even if the romance between thirty-year-old Dave Franco and a seventeen-year-old character carries an ick vibe.
Maybe the best big-screen Jane Austen adaptation ever!
All style over substance, but the movie is gorgeous and Ralph Fiennes is excellent.
A better-than-average cop thriller with fun performances by Nicolas Cage, Elijah Wood and Jerry Lewis (of all people).
A very tepid, uninspired John Wick clone.
Absolutely the most fun you'll have in a movie theater this summer.
Not even Sean Penn's grunts can save this stinker.
Far better than the early buzz suggests, even if the last act is a bit of a mess. Some terrific set-pieces.
By the time Alice says to The Mad Hatter, "I feel like I shall never see Wonderland again," you'll be saying to yourself "God, I hope she's right."
Spoon-fed financial caper. Suffers greatly in comparison with The Big Short.
A totally abysmal MIDNIGHT RUN rip-off, only salvaged by okay fight choreography and some nifty location shooting.
The kind of serious, A-quality horror studios shy away from. A throwback to movies like THE EXORCIST and THE SHINNING.
A perfect cast, an absence of gross-out humor and some solid observations about moms from the writer/directors makes BAD MOMS a cut above the rest of the summer comedies and well worth checking-out.
Deliciously entertaining
A surprisingly uplifting boxing pic with terrific performances.
More hit-and-miss than Guest's other efforts, but still (mostly) funny.
A solid fight flick in the vein of THE FIGHTER.
An incredibly compelling white-knuckle thriller.
Pretty but also vacuous and self-indulgent.
Old-fashioned but shines a light on an important, too often ignored part of history.
A dazzling, magical film.
Interesting premise but marred by a low-rent production. Sigourney Weaver makes it almost worth watching.
A staggering work.
A solid neo-noir actioner with a charismatic lead performance from Chadwick Boseman.
Totally demented but so much fun.
Bryan Cranston is fantastic.
Old-fashioned and archaic next to other movies about the same era, like JACKIE & ALL THE WAY.
Hilarious and charming. Bill Nighy should be in every movie.
A crowd-pleasing jukebox musical.
Good enough to make Portman this year's best actress Oscar front-runner.
A top-notch cast (including standout Sennia Nanua) makes this zombie drama well worth checking out.
movie_title: The Girl With All the Gifts (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Sophisticated sci-fi - stunningly well-crafted and acted.
An absolutely blast from beginning to end, FREE FIRE works as both a rip-snorting action flick, while simultaneously serving as a savvy send-up of the gangster genre.
Probably the best straight-up action flick of the year. Mel Gibson's best vehicle in a long time.
Well-acted and directed but falls apart towards the end.
It's not bad, but it's not great either.
The casting is spot-on, with Margot Robbie instantly iconic as Harley Quinn, a breakout character that could easily launch a franchise of her own.
NINE LIVES is so bad that it seems the only way it could have gotten made is if it was randomly selected from a pile of unproduced scripts by a chimpanzee.
Would do down real easy on a Sunday afternoon.
A really solid late-summer surprise and a gem of a crime caper.
SNOWDEN is neither the triumphant return-to-form Stone fans might have been hoping for, nor is it as real miss.
This new BEN-HUR can't even begin to compete with the spectacle of the previous versions.
An OK genre entry - better than average Labor Day weekend fare.
An ambitious but failed oddball genre entry with no clear-cut audience.
A fun reboot of the classic ensemble western. Denzel Washington is at his best as the gun-slinging leader.
A very strong effort for Nichols, who's truly proving himself to be one of the great American directors.
A strong return-to-form for Verhoeven and a potentially award-worthy performance by Huppert.
A cathartic, brilliantly conceived and executed blend of fantasy and drama.
A thoroughly original take on the kaiju genre.
Fairly standard Jason Statham punch-up fare.

Unfairly maligned, Snyder's dark vision is impressive and starkly different from the competition. The plot is perhaps too ambitious but the film delivers more often than it doesn't with Affleck's Bruce Wayne and Gal Gadot being highlights.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: WOLVES ultimately may be a simple underdog story, done in a straightforward, uncomplicated way, but it tells a good yarn and the performances elevate it.
A blast from start-to-finish that's paced with eye-candy, and features a stand-out performance by John C. Reilly.
A sturdy action-adventure with an intriguing real-life hook.
It's awful but also kind of amazing.
How did such an amazing roaster of talented people go so horribly awry?
Arguably superior to the genuinely creepy original.
Will probably rank highly in the Marvel canon for fans, while even those somewhat worn down by the many entries will find a lot of things to like about it. A great "soft" reboot for the character.

It's fairly harmless as far as these things go, and Gibson, Lithgow and Cena wring a few laughs out of the tired formula. It's not a great comedy, but it says something about how dire the landscape is when "just ok" or "not awful" is good enough.
A solid thriller with a top-notch Christopher Abbott performance.
Feels very much like a movie made by committee rather than the fully realized version of a sole director. It's fun for what it is but also forgettable.
Plays more like good TV than a feature, but a well-acted, unique spin on the classic tale.
Visually striking - one of Woody's better recent efforts.
Second-tier Spielberg, but truly compelling.
Not half-bad as far as these things go.

As the titular character, John Cena is pretty perfect. He's taken a page from Dwayne Johnson, in the way he totally subverts people's impressions of him by playing a softie - in the mold of the greatest of them all - Arnold Schwarzenegger.
Arguably the most beautifully directed film of the series so far. About as good as it gets for four-quadrant, tent-pole film-making. Wonderful.
Good family entertainment for the holidays, with a well-cast ensemble playing to their strengths.
A significant coup for Netflix, sporting a Sandler's best performance since PUNCH-DRUNK LOVE.
Tragically unfunny despite the enthusiastic cast.
Slick and well done, but ties a complicated story up in too convenient a package.
Visually stunning and soaked in atmosphere.
An urgent retelling of a pivotal moment in world history.
A terrific first hour gives way to a messy, unfocused second half.
A familiar, but well-conceived part for Stiller.
A deeply human story, beautifully shot as an epic.
Boasts a subtle, nuanced turn by Christian Bale.
A darkly comic masterpiece, with towering performances from Frances McDormand and Sam Rockwell.
As minor entertainment, it'll do, but lacks the anarchic spirit of the first, feeling familiar and rather safe.

While the real-life resolution of the case was far more interesting than the Hollywood version depicted, this is a good thriller with an excellent performance by Plummer made all the more impressive considering the circumstances that surround it.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A slick American updating of INTOUCHABLES, which improves upon the original in one significant way.
Timely insight into the mind of Wonder Woman's creator!
Straightforward but engaging.
movie_title: Mark Felt: The Man Who Brought Down the White House (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Pales next to the authenticity of NARCOS.
Louis C.K. doing Woody Allen-lite. Has it's moments, but not his best work.
An intriguing take-down of the Kennedy mythos.
Cruise's best movie in about a decade - a return to the type of role that made him a star in the first place.
a horrific failure for Niels Arden Oplev, whose THE GIRL WITH THE DRAGON TATTOO, DEAD MAN DOWN, and the pilot for "Mr. Robot", suggested a certain boldness that's utterly absent here.
What could have been a routine romantic drama is elevated by stunning location photography and excellent performances.
A new action classic with a career-redefining part for Vince Vaughn.
Long and draggy, with a punishingly slow pace in the first act.
A trashy, Tap-Out remake of HEAT, or at least as close as they can get without getting sued.
t's an intriguing tale that's fairly well-told, and the performances more than pick up the slack whenever it veers a little too sharply into corny territory.
Despite not screening for critics, this is a perfectly serviceable Gothic thriller.
Well-intentioned but a bore. Would have been much better as a documentary.
Brilliantly cast and impeccably directed - the most exciting MCU entry in years.
Bargain basement. If it was made in the nineties would have been a routine skin-e-max programmer.
Intelligent sci-fi done right.
The three leads really do exceptional work, with Kaniehtiio Horn, who's actually Mohawk, making a strong protagonist, as a First Nations woman fully liberated and ready to fight for what's hers.
It's another unconventional choice by an actress who refuses to be pigeonholed, and she's cast to perfection in this solid thriller.
Tedious but occasionally interesting. Paul Rudd is excellent.
Bruce Willis sleepwalks through this simple remake that lacks the ambiguity that made the original so interesting. More like one of the cheap sequels.
Worth watching for Michael Caine's performance.
Well-intentioned, well-acted, but a bit of a mess.
Generic but not uninteresting, with a good performance from Leto.
If the words "hurricane" and "heist" translate into the words "must" and "see", this is the movie for you.
Silly but fun. No more, no less.
A lovely tribute to a man who was a surrogate father to pretty much anyone born in the second half of the 20th century.
Uneven, but Charlize Theron is undeniably excellent.
A solid VOD actioner, with good action and solid performances from Jason Momoa & Stephen Lang.
Arguably among the finest films of the decade, with career-best work from Phoenix and masterful direction by Ramsay.
This is a good one that marks a strong comeback for [director Tamara] Jenkins, and gives Hahn a breakout part playing someone more down-to-earth than she's usually allowed to.
The mix of comedy and drama occasionally falls a little flat, with the drama often working better than the comedy, as do the occasional doses of surrealism via director Carlos Lopez Estrada.
A shaggy, but solid return to form by Gus Van Sant. Jonah Hill steals the show.
movie_title: Don't Worry, He Won't Get Far on Foot (2018)

movie_review_blurb: The last forty minutes of MANDY ranks as maybe Cage's most hardcore trip into the dark side yet.
The Catcher Was a Spy is a good vehicle for Rudd, and an entertaining watch, although it's maybe a little old-fashioned to really catch-on in a theatrical way (it feels like a made-for-cable movie).
It's interesting that AMERICAN ANIMALS is one of the few movies in recent memory where I didn't feel the leads had to be likable.
A vital and provocative work that should get people talking.
Disposable but better-than-average Neeson actioner.
Impeccably made, although the clinical approach is cold and off-putting.
A smart, entertaining adult thriller - a throwback to a pre-superhero era in blockbuster filmmaking.
A provocative, gonzo debut for director Boots Riley.
While inconsistent, this is still a good sci-fi, end of the world tale with a different flavor from most.
Tries to be ROSEMARY'S BABY for the 21st century and, incredibly, more-or-less succeeds!
A timely, button-pushing satire.
A heartbreaking look at Williams's life and art.
movie_title: Robin Williams: Come Inside My Mind (2018)

movie_review_blurb: A hip, pleasant indie comedy with lovely performances from Offerman and Clemons.
A strong, confident follow-up to TURBO KID with a killer climax.
A fun, audience-friendly slice of nostalgia not unlike AMERICAN HUSTLE.
A hilarious love-letter to Tommy Wiseau. You don't have to have seen THE ROOM to enjoy it, but you - ya know - should.
A beautifully made pop-culture pastiche, with the best ensemble cast of the year.
Well-shot, but too self-indulgent to come off as anything more than experimental.
One or two truly great moments are buried in a self-indulgent, plot-less mess.
Doubles down on the things that made the first film a hit
A fast, entertaining flick, and a fun entry into Lynch's growing body of work.
Good, raunchy fun with a great comeback role for Goldie Hawn.
The xenomorphs feel like an afterthought in this predictable PROMETHEUS sequel, but it's still an entertaining ride with some memorable moments.
Netflix's first, genuine, studio-level effort. A strong way to kick off their new run of films.
Relatively entertaining and well-acted until one twist too many. at the very end.
Better than the last one, but that's not saying much. Time for Jack Sparrow to retire, although Geoffrey Rush occasionally livens things up, and Kaya Scodelario is one to watch.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: BAND AID is another solid example of how rom-coms, while dead on a studio level, have become a niche in lo-fi indie cinema, where things don't have to be so cookie-cutter, and where the leads can be a bit more personable.
Cruise is badly miscast in one of the worst films of his career.
a pretty solid summer sleeper that should find a receptive audience among animal lovers
Worth checking-out for old-school action fans.
Much better than the first, abysmal, sequel.
Similar to HARDCORE HENRY, in that it's like watching someone else play a video game for ninety minutes.
Goes off the rails after an excellent first half hour, but Eastwood's performance is quite good, and the movie has its moments.
The payoff is big, and the journey is never less than absorbing, and this, along with GET OUT, proves that horror as a genre for legit A-level work is back in full-fo
A thriller without any thrills.
SAND CASTLE is another Netflix movie that doesn't really feel like a movie
A potent martial arts actioner, and another great vehicle for THE RAID's Iko Uwais.
A sadistic, punishingly long neo-western I couldn't quite bring myself to dislike.
Just as good as the first, with first-time director Jay Baruchel showing some real flair behind the camera.
A good showcase for Kristen Stewart's consistently underrated talents. She's well on her way to becoming one of the greats.
Bill Paxton steals the show in his last completed film.
Plays-out like a $100 million version of a CW pilot, but not bad for what it is.
Certainly a best-case scenario as far as sequels to iconic classics go. McGregor, Miller, Bremmer, Carlyle and Boyle haven't missed a beat in the twenty plus years since the first.
Uneven and not especially funny, but at least Willis seems to be making an honest effort.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Venice (2017)

movie_review_blurb: An abysmal ALIEN-clone with no genuine tension or scares. The talented cast is wasted.
Despite interesting visuals, GHOST IN THE SHELL is a hollow bore.
While it never quite lives up to the terrific first act, MINE is worth watching for Armie Hammer's performance alone.
While Fred, the one-eyed cat, almost makes GIFTED worth checking out, it's ultimately a too simplistic and watered-down child custody tale.
Arnold's performance is unexpectedly brilliant.
Feels like a feature-length sitcom, but the three leads make it a pleasant enough watch.
A very peculiar misfire for Herzog, but still kinda interesting.

Lucky for Universal, for whom this series has been the proverbial golden goose, THE FATE OF THE FURIOUS proves star Vin Diesel and the rest of his crew still have enough NOS in their engines to keep the franchise going for at least a few more films.
The action is decent, but the comedy is puerile.

"THE BOOK OF HENRY, in 100 minutes, covers terminal illness in children, and sexual abuse, probably the two most troubling things you could ever make a movie about short of genocide, but plays it for whimsy. FOR WHIMSY."
A glossy, but entertaining biopic that could have used more nuance.
If not the best movie of the year, it's definitely the most fun. The premise may be familiar, but we've never seen it done quite like this before.
Silly, fast-paced, fun. Noomi Rapace hasn't been this charismatic since THE GIRL WITH THE DRAGON TATTOO.
Outside the miscalculated ending, just as fun as the other two installments.
A routine BOURNE IDENTITY clone despite the starry cast.
Evocative, well-cast, Hammer horror-style thriller.
Straightforward and reasonably entertaining, but would have worked better as a documentary.
A dazzlingly off-kilter black comedy/thriller.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Despite some creative mayhem, frustratingly uneven.
An updated, more sophisticated take on those old Burt Reynold's seventies good ol'boy flicks.
Not the return to form John Woo fans are hoping for, and quite bad at times.
More a black comedy than straight-up horror, and definitely only for more adventurous filmgoers.
A gritty, inspiring tale of perseverance
A raunchy, hilarious history lesson.
Overall Roman J. Israel, Esq. is another iconic Denzel Washington movie, and one that seems sure to get him some Oscar attention this fall.
Guillermo del Toro's masterpiece.
Beautifully written and acted.
A demented blast
A strong remake that improves upon the original in some (but definitely not all) ways.
Serviceable teen drama, distinguished by smart direction and an excellent performance by star Zoey Deutch.
A stark, uncompromising prison drama.
a modest character piece that aims to be closer to THE NAME OF THE ROSE than "Game of Thrones".
WAR FOR THE PLANET OF THE APES is what a big summer movie should be - beautifully crafted, visceral, exciting, but also filled with substance.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Fluctuates from being sublime to tedious throughout
A career-worst for all involved.
It's definitely an interesting contrast to the 1971 film, and both fascinating for what it explores, but also for what it leaves out.
one can't deny that all involved have delivered exactly the movie that hardcore fans wanted
Another low-rent paycheck job for Willis.

From the first frame to the last, it's a propulsive ride that wrings so much tension out of the audience that by the time the credits roll, there's little you can do but stare at the screen in stunned silence.
Visually sumptuous but a deadly bore.
Out-does AVATAR as far as sheer visual spectacle goes, but Dane DeHaan is badly miscast in a part that demanded a larger-than-life presence.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Repellent family drama with a "hero" you hope will end up in handcuffs by the time the movie ends.
A horrifically misguided exercise in movie-star narcissism.
At least there's Halle Berry in the driver's seat, and the force of her performance is enough to push to make this a half-decent recommendation for someone looking for a quickie genre thriller.
a hallucinogenic late summer treat
people will walk out of this one and change their social media profiles to private
Uneven, as the film is much better at depicting Walls's childhood than her adult life, but overall a solid piece of summer counter-programming.
An uneven blend of comedy and action, but the chemistry between the leads makes it worthwhile.
The 3D facelift is well done, and doesn't distract from what's arguably the greatest action film ever made. Nice to see it back in theaters - where it belongs.
Pee-wee's still Pee-wee - thank God!
At a mere ninety minutes, it feels like one of those YouTube fan edits of an entire series.
Byrne leaves his native Australia behind for Austin, Texas where he's made a deliciously over-the-top satanic horror flick with heavy doses of gore, metal and most surprisingly - heart.
A fun, old-fashioned Val Lewton-style thriller. Sturgess, Beckinsale, Caine and Kingsley are always worth watching.
A poorly made micro-budget horror movie designed to quickly cash-in on non-discerning audiences. And sell board games.
Keanu Reeves hasn't been this cool since THE MATRIX
A relatively mild thriller, but the cast is excellent and the direction is slick and classy.
A roller-coaster for the mind and spirit... Twenty years from now we may think of it as a classic, even if it takes a bit of time for it to sink in.
If you're looking for nostalgia, just put on some Butthole Surfers or Crash Test Dummies while you try to dig up your old DVD copy of the original
Nothing more than a prelude to next year's finale. The material is way too thin to sustain two movies.
Another super-solid indie thriller along the lines of Blue Ruin & Cold in July. Highly recommended.
At its best it feels like a mediocre episode of HOMELAND, and at its worst it's barely comprehensible
SERENA has entertainment value, just not likely in the way the filmmakers hoped. It's a fun film, but I don't know that I'd say it's a good one.
Wild and often hilarious. I bet it gets even better the second time around
THE CAPTIVE is a disaster, but I must admit that it's at least entertaining in a "wow, I can't believe this exists" kind of way
Feels cheap and lacks creativity
Lacks the energy of the first two but should still please the kiddies. Still, the franchise seems to have run out of gas.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

movie_review_blurb: One of the most important films of the year.
Schlocky, low-rent fun.
A future cult-classic. Like an L.A noir version of AFTER HOURS.
LAST HIJACK isn't an especially entertaining film, but it's a troubling one and worth seeing even if only for the insight into this phenomenon that it provides.
A visually stunning, creative debut for an intriguing new director.
So well-intentioned that it's hard to entirely dislike.
A strong mainstream effort by director Noah Baumbach. Ben Stiller hasn't been this funny in years.
Too evocative of other, much better movies like the BEFORE series or LOST IN TRANSLATION.
Too many goofy lapses into broad comedy ruin an already too-familiar tale.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A very compelling true crime tale. Like the flipside of THE FRENCH CONNECTION.
A total blast with the potential to become a favorite of pre-teen boys the world over.
Could go toe-to-toe with the very best of Rock's standup. The movie he's been working towards his entire career.
Eastwood's best film in a long time, and further proof that Cooper is both a great actor and a great star
Could be called THE WOLF OF WALL STREET: THE OXFORD YEARS.
Demands a lot of the viewer, but it's one of the most sobering American films ever made about homelessness. Richard Gere is incredible.
Let's be nice and call this an acquired taste.
A perfect historical thriller. Jack O'Connell is a future mega star.
Good performances can't save a bland, instantly forgettable film.
The premise can't quite sustain a feature but Allen and LaPaglia are excellent.
Bargain-basement Evangelical stuff. Notice the devout Muslim passenger gets "left behind". Belongs in a church basement, not a movie theater.
Just a low-budget quickie designed to cash-in and cash-out. Nothing you haven't seen a million times before.
Flawed but timely.
Warm and uplifting, but with an edge. Reese Witherspoon has never been better.

This remake is just a watered-down version that hits all of the same beats as the original, only judges its nominal hero far less harshly, and emerges an oddly amoral film with an ending that borders on being ludicrous
It's an ambitious experiment that paid off big-time, both for Linklater and his audience. I can't say I've ever seen anything quite like it.
Imagine if Sam Peckinpah had directed an Amblin movie with a screenplay by Jim Thompson. That's COP CAR in a nutshell.
has so much potential but winds up being instantly disposable thanks to some truly bizarre artistic choices that are bound to alienate about 90% of the audience
pretty rock n'roll, aiming for a fun aesthetic that's right in line with the brand
movie_title: Drunk Stoned Brilliant Dead: The Story of the National Lampoon (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Lacks any real insight into this phenomena or scares.
It's not Sundance without Joe Swanberg, and this is one of his best.
Quirky fun. Sam Rockwell, Leslie Bibb and Jermaine Clement are great.
Thrilling euro-western with a darkly comic twist.
One of the best movies to hit Sundance this year, with an awards-worthy performance by Cynthia Nixon.
Gets you right inside Cobain's head - not always a pleasant place to be. Obviously a must-see.
Like an urban Risky Business. I gotta say it - DOPE is dope!
Very likable. Cobie Smulders is excellent.
Sebastian Silva's a maniac, but he's MY kind of maniac.

It remains to be seen how the MPAA will react to THE DIARY OF A TEENAGE GIRL's frankness, but hopefully it won't be too restrictive as there's more value in this for younger people than in mainstream YA fare.
movie_title: The Diary Of A Teenage Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Lacks the heart and soul, and especially the visual ingenuity the Wachowskis usually bring to their work.
A gonzo-fun take-off on old-school super-spy yarns. Smashing!
Brie is always a delight, but SLEEPING WITH OTHER PEOPLE is a fairly bland rom-com that too often brings to mind the superior WHEN HARRY MET SALLY.
One of Statham's better vehicles.
A delight to watch.
Arresting visuals and a magnificent performance by Ewan McGregor make this a cut above most religious fare.
So low-rent that it feels like everyone involved - from the writers to the director to the star - just decided to put as little effort into the follow-up as possible.
Bruce Willis phones it in and Thomas Jane isn't given enough to do in this low-budget DTV actioner.
Strictly as a Patrick Stewart showcase, MATCH succeeds.
Not top-tier Mann, but at times it comes close enough and a slightly diminished Mann is still better than just about everybody else. The action scenes are impeccable.
A strong change-of-pace for McGregor and well-worth checking out for action fans.
A totally absorbing art-film.
THE BRONZE feels like a film that had all the ingredients for a breakout indie comedy, but just totally screwed up the recipe nonetheless.
Terrific performances and a strong script add up to Tim Burton's best movie in a long time.
A career redefining part for Jason Segel - emotionally absorbing and always entertaining.
A low-key but intriguing sci-fi morality tale. Margot Robbie is excellent.
Very John Hughes - right down to the eighties setting and the compassion for its troubled teen characters. Well-worth seeing.
it should allow audiences to see a different side of Mendelsohn, and fully appreciate how effective Reynolds can be in the right role
Franco and Quinto are great, but I AM MICHAEL should have been way more compelling given the subject matter.
Too campy to be scary. Reeves is badly miscast.
like a post-sexual revolution's BOB, TED, CAROL & ALICE.
A strong showcase for Jonah Hill's dramatic chops.
More like WILD HOGS than WILD.
Considering the premise, this could and SHOULD have been great.
Catnip for fans of The Beach Boys. Three great performances by Paul Dano, John Cusack and Elizabeth Banks.
Like a bad episode of 21 Jump Street.
A little dull, but beautifully shot and acted.
movie_title: Age of Uprising: The Legend of Michael Kohlhaas (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Charming, but not up to the Quebec original.
Feels antiquated - like a Bob Hope comedy from the forties.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The date movie of the summer. Should do for a generation of kids what GHOST did for their parents.
A surprisingly tough little movie about the reality of child actors in Hollywood.
The perfect summer blockbuster. Funnier than you'd think. Cruise's image is both satirized and celebrated. Blunt is terrific.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Like a nice-guy version of The Kid Stays in the Picture. Proves that you don't have to be a jerk to get ahead in showbiz.
movie_title: Supermensch: The Legend of Shep Gordon (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Not perfect, but still a fun ride through the Four Seasons' ups and downs. More of a straight biopic than a musical.
Bleak but beautiful. An arty, ultra-realistic take on the post-apocalyptic genre.
Despite the name, there's very little hard driving in DRIVE HARD. A dull, amateurish wannabe buddy-comedy.
Elevated by strong production values and an excellent cast.
The rare summer blockbuster with both brains and brawn. The best APES movie since Charlton Heston first slapped on a loincloth.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Probably the closest they could have made to a Punisher movie without getting sued. Much better than the first film. Frank Grillo makes for a cool hero.
Smart, cerebral sci-fi. The perfect antidote to a mediocre summer of tentpoles.
A terrific debut for director Riley Stearns. Amazing performances from Leland Orser and Mary Elizabeth Winstead.
Darkly funny. The best Irvine Welsh has been done on-screen since Trainspotting. James McAvoy is terrific.
Once upon a time I was a fan of his (Sandler), but alas you can't be sixteen forever.
The film X-Men fans have been waiting for. It lives up to their expectations and then some. A truly epic installment.
Often brilliant, with tremendous performances by Marion Cotillard and Joaquin Phoenix.
Very preachy and very cliched, although Garner's performance is solid.
Very silly, but overall a fun B-level actioner. In the pantheon of Liam Neeson action-flicks, it's a notch below TAKEN, better than UNKNOWN, and way better than TAKEN 2.
Melodramatic but often visually striking, One of the best uses of 3D in film since AVATAR.
A very dull sequel that cries our for the same kind of larger-than-life hero played by Butler in the original. Worth watching only for Eva Green.
Perfectly captures the magic of the show. A great follow-up.
While the tween and teen target audience will probably love it and make it a hit, it fails to measure up to THE HUNGER GAMES. That said, it's far better than any of the TWILIGHT's.
Challenging, thought-provoking, and always entertaining.
Not one of Terry Gilliam's better films, but his misfires are still nothing if not interesting. Waltz is excellent.
Even audiences who've never heard of Alan Partridge (although they should have) will get a lot of laughs out of this.
The best found-footage movie since CHRONICLE. Ambitious, and beautifully shot.
A very solid MONEYBALL-esque sports drama, with the emphasis on the business side. Costner's best role in years. A major comeback part.
Depressingly inert. A sad waste of talent.
An intriguing first half gives way to a really generic, dumb second half that all but eliminates any of the good will the film had going for it.
Suffers badly from comparison to THE RAID. The inept JAWS 3D style FX don't help. A back-to-basics approach would have been much better.
The good outweighs the bad, but this is a frustratingly inconsistent sequel. The white-hot chemistry between Stone and Garfield saves the day, and the visuals are often striking.
Worth seeing for the last half hour, but too much of the film is dull. Waiting to reveal Godzilla would have been fine if the characters had heart or if the film had tension.
Fairly low rent, but the location photography is good, and Carano is fun to watch when she does her thing.
Worse than any Uwe Boll movie. Just terrible.
Truly eccentric. Imagine TREE OF LIFE (right down to the dinosaurs) re-imagined as an eighty-minute action movie and you've got an idea of what Besson is going for. It works better than you'd think.
Excellent performances can't save The Harvest, which is riddled with too many plot holes.
Truly unsettling. One of the best horror movies to come along in a while.
A pleasant adventure-comedy with a winning performance from Simon Pegg.
movie_title: Hector And The Search For Happiness (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Bill Murray is award-worthy in a tailor-made part.
A full-on masterpiece. Darkly funny, frightening, and action-packed. An intriguing neo-noir take on a world most of us are happily oblivious to.
A little slow-going but overall a solid character-driven underworld tale. Tom Hardy is terrific.
Batsh*t crazy, but in the best way possible. An exciting new chapter for Smith, who seems reinvigorated and at the top of his game.
One of the best american actions films in years. Rock-solid action with a heart. Washington is cast to perfection.
Better than COSMOPOLIS but goes off the rails in the second half. Has some brilliant moments.
While not as compelling as BOBBY FISCHER AGAINST THE WORLD, still a very worthwhile film.
A decent premise is ruined by poor execution and a ridiculous ending.
Utterly absorbing true-life spy thriller. Cumberbatch is wonderful.
Flawed but engaging, with an excellent performance by Kevin Costner.
An incredibly entertaining, affectionate look at Cannon Films. Very rewarding for anyone who grew up watching the Chuck Norris-fueled studio output.
movie_title: Electric Boogaloo: The Wild, Untold Story of Cannon Films (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A sweet film. Eddie Redmayne and Felicity Jones are remarkable.
While not a true Escobar biopic, it's still a solid thriller with a strong turn by Benicio Del Toro.
Grabs you from the first frame and doesn't let go until the credits roll. Shanoon and Garfield are electric.
Career best performances by Steve Carell and Channing Tatum.
A curio that will likely only appeal to Spike Lee's most devoted fans - or those that contributed to the Kickstarter campaign that financed it.

Annihilation is a remarkable achievement. It lingers, burned into your thoughts, branded on the brain. It is nothing short of a masterpiece, and the fact that it exists at all is something worth celebrating.
Mute is a disjointed, nihilistic trip through two distinct storylines that have almost nothing to do with each other.
Braven is not high-art, but gosh almighty is it highly entertaining.
Mom and Dad is just wild enough to draw in a midnight movie crowd, and fans of crazy Nicolas Cage performances won't go away unsatisfied.
The long-delayed Inside remake is finally ready to see the light of day. What this review presupposes is...maybe that's not such a good thing?
Voice from the Stone wants to pay homage to the great gothic horror films and stories that came before it, but you'd probably be better off just watching and reading them instead.

Where does Thor: Ragnarok fit into the ever-growing ranking of the MCU? Somewhere in the middle. It's funny enough, colorful enough, and entertaining enough to strike a chord, but it's ultimately hollow.
The Current War may not break new ground, but it finds exciting ways to make the old seem new.
78/52 is both a loving tribute to the work Hitchcock did as well as a sharp, enlightening lesson in what makes Psycho so special.
The true highlight of Killing Ground is the editing, courtesy of Katie Flaxman, which weaves together the multiple narratives in a concise manner.
Suburbicon looks like it should be wonderful.
At the very least, though, you won't be bored.
Haneke helms Happy End with a deft hand.
Fans of the musician will find plenty to tune into here, and the uninitiated will likely go away wanting to scoop up as much of Coltrane's music as they can get their hands on.
movie_title: Chasing Trane: The John Coltrane Documentary (2017)

movie_review_blurb: American Fable signals the arrival of an exciting new filmmaker, Anne Hamilton.
There's much to like here.
The Dark Tower shows some meager promise, but as the first in a proposed series it leaves much to be desired.
In the end, Another Evil feels more like a funny idea that would've killed as an SNL skit, but as a feature-length film it doesn't stand a ghost of a chance.
Bad news: The Mummy has risen from the tomb, and it stinks!
It's the script that isn't doing Don't Knock Twice any favors.
Mostly ... you can't really shake the Made-For-TV vibe that The Wizard of Lies throws off.
... a memorable piece of modern big budget filmmaking.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: ... there's enough originality here, mixed with truly stunning cinematographer, to make Lake Bodom stand out from the pack.
There's more inventiveness, and more honest to goodness heart in this film than the last four MCU films combined. And the soundtrack isn't too bad, either.
Like a true religious experience, you will be in awe of what you've witnessed.
Still, there's enough talent on display here, from direction to performances, to warrant a watch.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: ... this is a fascinating film, simply because it's so out of character for Schwarzenegger. The actor may not have the range to carry such a film, but it's commendable that he's still willing to try even at this point in his career.
First-semester social-science students would wince at the overreaching metaphors in Donnie Darko director Richard Kelly's latest Rorschach test.
It's easy to root against these coming-of-agers, who wear their confusion on their vintage T's and walk the line between self-persecution and deliberate outward agitation.
movie_title: Taqwacore: The Birth of Punk Islam (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Like most of Perry's treasures, Why Did I Get Married Too? seems to have been shot with no script and on a single take; the majority of dialogue overheard at your local mall's food court is leagues more entertaining.
movie_title: Why Did I Get Married Too (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Only one thing might be worse: the thought of Comedy Central's airing this bomb four times a day.
Without adding too much cheese, director John Lee Hancock channels genuine emotion from the Michael Lewis book (and the reality) that prompted this moving chronicle.
Serious Tezuka fans will likely appreciate the sharp multi-dimensional presentation, even as they resent Osamu's being pimped out for Obama.
Quote not available.
Lee's contribution should fit well into the Woodstock-tribute canon. It smartly avoids overused period references.
It's not often that documentaries pack as much suspense as action flicks (and even rarer that one does so without re-enactments), but The Cove is a mighty exception.

If Fleck weren't such a gracious soul chasing the spirit of Sankofa, this could have been an exercise in exploitation of Graceland-ian proportions. But that's hardly the case on his magical musical mystery tour.

In addition to the expected shots of Ali and Don King in all their megalomania, the intimate portraits of James Brown, Bill Withers, and B.B. King in his triumphant homecoming are as powerful as their performances.
Unfortunately, a man died (from cancer) in the making of this explicitly introspective life tome; it was the only way he saw to complete his masterpiece.
For a documentary about D-movie mavens, It Came from Kuchar is expertly edited, and it serves as both a comprehensive archival overview for diehard fans and a thorough introduction for beginners.

Had someone fire-bombed an annual college-Republicans' meeting in the early 1980s, he would have spared this country a lot of pain and strife.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The Mormon Proposition is about as subjective as documentaries get. The good news is that Cowan and Greenstreet are compelling enough to convince you that only one side of this debate deserves a voice.
Concentrated in such alterna-scenes as Boston, Austin, and Seattle, this repulsive bunch [of poster artists] exude more counter-culture geek clichés than Comic Book Guy.
Myth convinces that St. Louis failed Pruitt-Igoe, and not the other way around.
movie_title: The Pruitt-igoe Myth: An Urban History (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Canty is hardly an ignorant Jenny McCarthy-style alarmist. Rather, she's a concerned citizen asking questions about why federal and state food regulators are less interested in science than Texas Republicans.
There will be tears shed over this deep look at Chicago's grisliest streets and the benevolent soldiers who fight to keep them safe.
Although kind to the plights of activists who face hard time for victimless crimes, this film is balanced -- conservatives could easily interpret it as validation of the group's persecution.
movie_title: If a Tree Falls: A Story of the Earth Liberation Front (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Either mandatory rap-nerd masturbation material or the most boring movie imaginable about that group with the song you liked in middle school.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It would have worked much better as a gritty drama about the most toxic non-violent criminal in Texas history.
An expert documentary, a responsible yet lighthearted film about the absurd things that folks do in the face of death.
It's the feel-bad film of the year.
Although skillfully overhyped, this asinine exercise is little more than a way for Affleck and Phoenix to write off blow and hookers.

Notwithstanding that it's an anti-hate advocacy piece, this YouTube-spawned documentary gives plenty of voice to the depraved foot soldiers and their opportunistic enablers. It just so happens that they look like race-baiting rednecks ...
Almost two-dimensional, definitely heartfelt, and absolutely funny.
For a growing legion of YouTube boobs and mouse potatoes, Winnebago Man is all the medication we need to laugh away overdue bills and genital infections.
If physical comedy's overriding purpose is to make fools laugh out loud, then the first two Jackass films should be regarded alongside Buster Keaton's slapstick classics.
Walk Hard looks and sounds so much like a real musical biopic that you could make a good drinking game out of naming all the movies that get spoofed.
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: This movie is a lot like going on vacation and only eating at chain restaurants: familiar and bland, despite the beautiful surroundings.
The problem is, even as mindless violence, the movie fails.
Even if we see the happy ending from miles away, it's still a happy ending.
There's not too much original or surprising in the film.
The movie really snaps when Hanks and Hoffman are firing screenwriter Aaron Sorkin's dialogue back and forth, discussing arms deals with deadpan humor.
Maybe not the most uplifting choice for a holiday flick, but Smith's riveting performance and tight action scenes make this a smart, gripping view of the end of the world.
Pretty touching and kindhearted...for a movie about a guy in love with a sex doll.
Writer-director Frank Darabont hits every color in the feel-bad rainbow in this powerful adaptation of one of Stephen King's scariest works.

Until now, the story of Beowulf has been the most excruciatingly dull part of English Lit 101. But plenty of swordplay, monster-slaying and a naked Angelina Jolie turn the centuries-old poem into a bitching action movie.
The only scary part about this is that someone out there might actually love it.
Good performances from Redford, Meryl Streep and Tom Cruise are wasted in what's basically a dorm-room debate with a couple of action scenes.
It's more like a holiday fruitcake: a lot of different chunks of stuff -- some bitter, some sweet, some awful -- half-baked and sent to people low on the Christmas list.

Powering through this story on an Xbox would be far more fun.
movie_title: The Seeker: The Dark Is Rising (2007)

movie_review_blurb: This adaptation is a gorgeous, overstuffed contender for the box-office crown of Harry Potter.
The talented cast is largely wasted.
The power of the film's key scenes can make you forget the long, long, long trip it takes to get to them.

It's all entertaining, especially with the Apatow-patented dialogue, in this case from screenwriters Kristofor Brown and Seth Rogen.
A dull repeat of The Sopranos, only without any character development.
Just like good porn, the movie delivers scene after scene of tension and release, and you leave the theater happy. And maybe a little tired.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The movie avoids any nuance or shading in Collins. It starts in black-and-white, and that's where it ends.
Whatever your political bent, we can all come together as Americans and agree on one thing: The movie just isn't very good.

De Niro and Pacino hit every step so perfectly, they make even the standard cop-movie moments shine.
The beautiful locations and production values can't compensate for all the thin characters and lack of originality.

Hulk smash? Let's put it like this: He uses police cars as boxing gloves. Yeah. Hulk smash.
Fortunately, a smart script and great set pieces make this tale of Soviet spies, weird artifacts and a lost city a worthy capstone to the series.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This scores high on the ass-kickery meter, and what could have been another generic fight film is elevated into a thinking-man's Rocky by writer-director David Mamet.
It probably looked great on paper. Oh, sure, the concert scenes in this documentary about the Stones' show in New York are top-of-the-line, but it's nothing new.

A breezy, smart and sometimes surprising commentary on capitalism, gender roles and idealism disguised as a romantic comedy.

As a manual for handling animals - and people, for that matter - Brannaman's common-sense teachings broaden his story's appeal.

movie_title: Everyday Sunshine: The Story of Fishbone (2011)

movie_review_blurb: "Restless" teeters close to so many screen clichés that, even when it treads in uncharted territory, it feels like you've been there before.
A boisterous, almost scene-for-scene remake of the 1984 jukebox-musical-dance hit.
While it sometimes slips into annoying clichés, "Like Crazy's" simplicity and messy honesty keep it from sliding into B-grade melodrama.
Casadesus - at 97, a French national treasure who has been wowing stage and screen audiences since the 1930s - tenderly manages to make great literature sound like conversation, and vice versa.
movie_title: La tête en friche (My Afternoons with Margueritte) (2011)

Always engaging, if disjointed, and dotted with pleasant surprises.

movie_review_blurb: Just when City Island makes you want to say "Enough with the yelling already!" it does, and the characters' stories get softer, less wacky, more nuanced -- and more interesting.
Even with Spector's dark obsessions and current prison address, you can't dismiss his music's power, or its influence.
movie_title: The Agony and the Ecstasy of Phil Spector (2010)

Clarkson, as always, is genuine and terrific.
An earnest and well-acted, if occasionally flat, drama about what it means to be a parent.
Writer-director Michael Matzdorff, a Green Bay native, clearly has an affection for Door County ... But that makes the weather and other up-nort clichés all the more disappointing.
Unfortunately, "Cool It," even with its better ideas, too often feels like just more talking.

Don't let its Nicholas Sparks-like title fool you.
Kline's prickly character is hard to warm to, but his bumbling hides a spirit broken by life, and it's a credit to Kline's performance that you string along hoping he'll find a way to mend.

Birbiglia's easygoing style makes even his oft-told tales affecting on the big screen.
